[Elizabeth]88-elizabeth took leave of the whole party in the liveliest spirits . [They]647-they were not welcomed [home]3288-home very cordially by [[their]647-they mother]433-their mother . [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet wondered at [their]647-they coming , and thought [them]647-they very wrong to give so much trouble , and was sure [Jane]89-jane would have caught cold again . But [[their]647-they father]252-their father , though very laconic in [his]252-their father expressions of pleasure , was really glad to see [them]647-they ; [he]252-their father had felt [their]647-they importance in [the family circle]653-the family circle . The evening conversation , when [they]647-they were all assembled , had lost much of its animation , and almost all its sense , by the absence of [Jane]89-jane and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth . [They]647-they found [Mary]94-mary , as usual , deep in the study of thorough bass and human nature ; and had some new extracts to admire and some new observations of threadbare morality to listen to . [Catherine]93-lady catherine and [Lydia]90-lydia had information for [them]647-they of a different sort . Much had been done , and much had been said in [the regiment]654-the regiment since the preceding Wednesday ; [several of [the officers]452-the officers]655-several of the officers had dined lately with [[their]655-several of the officers uncle]3314-their uncle ; [a private]658-a private had been flogged ; and it had actually been hinted that [Colonel Forster]113-colonel forster was going to be married . [ [[Illustration ] CHAPTER XIII]132-illustration ] chapter xiii]659-illustration ] chapter xiii [ Illustration ] “ [I]81-mr. bennet hope , [[my]81-mr. bennet dear]3066-my dear , ”[81-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet to [[his]81-mr. bennet wife]236-his wife , as [they]661-they were at breakfast the next morning , “ that [you]236-his wife have ordered a good dinner to - day , because [I]81-mr. bennet have reason to expect an addition to [[our]661-they family party]3465-our family party . ”[81-mr. bennet] “ Who do [you]236-his wife mean , [[my]81-mr. bennet dear]3066-my dear ? [I]81-mr. bennet do not believe [she]107-charlotte often sees such at [home]3288-home . ”[81-mr. bennet] “ [The person of whom]3469-the person of whom [I]92-mrs. bennet speak is [a gentleman]3470-a gentleman and [a stranger]3471-a stranger . ”[92-mrs. bennet] [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet ’s eyes sparkled . “ [A gentleman]3470-a gentleman and [a stranger]3471-a stranger ! It is [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley , [I]92-mrs. bennet am sure . Why , [Jane]89-jane -- [you]89-jane never dropped a word of this -- [you]89-jane sly thing ! But -- [good Lord]3474-good lord ! how unlucky ! there is not a bit of fish to be got to - day . [Lydia]90-lydia , [[my]92-mrs. bennet love]3127-my love , ring the bell . [I]92-mrs. bennet must speak to [Hill]133-hill this moment . ”[92-mrs. bennet] “ It is not [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley , ”[260-her husband] said [[her]92-mrs. bennet husband]260-her husband ; “ it is [a person whom [I]260-her husband never saw in the whole course of [my]260-her husband life]3476-a person whom i never saw in the whole course of my life . ”[260-her husband] This roused a general astonishment ; and [he]260-her husband had the pleasure of being eagerly questioned by [[his]260-her husband wife]236-his wife and [five daughters]664-five daughters at once . After amusing [himself]260-her husband some time with [their]665-their curiosity , [he]260-her husband thus explained -“About a month ago [I]236-his wife received this letter , and about a fortnight ago [I]236-his wife answered it ; for [I]236-his wife thought it a case of some delicacy , and requiring early attention . It is from [[my]236-his wife cousin]3477-my cousin , [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , who , when [I]236-his wife am dead , may turn [you]3478-you all out of [this house]3479-this house as soon as [he]134-mr. collins pleases . ”[236-his wife] “ Oh , [[my]236-his wife dear]3066-my dear , ”[236-his wife] cried [[his]260-her husband wife]236-his wife , “ [I]236-his wife can not bear to hear that mentioned . Pray do not talk of [that odious man]3481-that odious man . [I]236-his wife do think it is the hardest thing in [the world]304-the world , that [[your]3478-you estate]3483-your estate should be entailed away from [[your]3478-you own children]3097-your own children ; and [I]236-his wife am sure , if [I]236-his wife had been [you]3478-you , [I]236-his wife should have tried long ago to do something or other about it . ”[236-his wife] [Jane]89-jane and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth attempted to explain to [her]236-his wife the nature of an entail . [They]667-they had often attempted it before : but it was a subject on which [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet was beyond the reach of reason ; and [she]92-mrs. bennet continued to rail bitterly against the cruelty of settling an estate away from [a family of five daughters]668-a family of five daughters , in favour of [a man whom [nobody cared anything about]670-nobody cared anything about]669-a man whom nobody cared anything about . “ It certainly is a most iniquitous affair , ”[81-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet ; “ and nothing can clear [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins from the guilt of inheriting [Longbourn]7-longbourn . But if [you]3478-you will listen to [his]134-mr. collins letter , [you]3478-you may , perhaps , be a little softened by [his]134-mr. collins manner of expressing [himself]134-mr. collins . ”[81-mr. bennet] “ No , that [I]92-mrs. bennet am sure [I]92-mrs. bennet shall not : and [I]92-mrs. bennet think it was very impertinent of [him]134-mr. collins to write to [you]3478-you at all , and very hypocritical . [I]92-mrs. bennet hate [such false friends]3485-such false friends . Why could not [he]134-mr. collins keep on quarrelling with [you]3478-you , as [[his]134-mr. collins father]339-his father did before [him]134-mr. collins ? ”[92-mrs. bennet] “ Why , indeed , [he]134-mr. collins does seem to have had some filial scruples on that head , as [you]3478-you will hear . ”[81-mr. bennet] / * RIGHT “ [Hunsford]15-hunsford , near [Westerham]16-westerham , [Kent]17-kent , 15th October . * / “[92-mrs. bennet] [Dear Sir]135-dear sir , “ The disagreement subsisting between [yourself]3478-you and [[my]92-mrs. bennet late honoured father]3487-my late honoured father always gave [me]92-mrs. bennet much uneasiness ; and , since [I]92-mrs. bennet have had the misfortune to lose [him]134-mr. collins , [I]92-mrs. bennet have frequently wished to heal the breach : but , for some time , [I]92-mrs. bennet was kept back by [my]92-mrs. bennet own doubts , fearing lest it might seem disrespectful to [his]134-mr. collins memory for [me]92-mrs. bennet to be on good terms with anyone with whom it had always pleased [him]134-mr. collins to be at variance . ”--‘There[92-mrs. bennet] , [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet . ’--“My mind , however , is now made up on the subject ; for , having received ordination at Easter , [I]137-william collins have been so fortunate as to be distinguished by the patronage of [the Right Honourable Lady Catherine de Bourgh]93-lady catherine , widow of [Sir Lewis de Bourgh]136-sir lewis de bourgh , whose bounty and beneficence has preferred [me]137-william collins to [the valuable rectory of [this parish]3489-this parish]3488-the valuable rectory of this parish , where it shall be [my]137-william collins earnest endeavour to demean [myself]137-william collins with grateful respect towards [[her]93-lady catherine Ladyship]3490-her ladyship , and be ever ready to perform those rites and ceremonies which are instituted by [the Church of England]3491-the church of england . As [a clergyman]3492-a clergyman , moreover , [I]137-william collins feel it [my]137-william collins duty to promote and establish the blessing of peace in [all families]3493-all families within the reach of [my]137-william collins influence ; and on these grounds [I]137-william collins flatter [myself]137-william collins that [my]137-william collins present overtures of good - will are highly commendable , and that the circumstance of [my]137-william collins being next in the entail of [Longbourn estate]3494-longbourn estate will be kindly overlooked on [your]3495-your side , and not lead [you]3495-your to reject the offered olive branch . [I]137-william collins can not be otherwise than concerned at being the means of injuring [[your]3495-your amiable daughters]3496-your amiable daughters , and beg leave to apologize for it , as well as to assure [you]3495-your of [my]137-william collins readiness to make [them]3496-your amiable daughters every possible amends ; but of this hereafter . If [you]3495-your should have no objection to receive [me]137-william collins into [[your]3495-your house]3326-your house , [I]137-william collins propose [myself]137-william collins the satisfaction of waiting on [you]3495-your and [[your]3495-your family]3498-your family , Monday , November 18th , by four o’clock , and shall probably trespass on [your]3495-your hospitality till the Saturday se’nnight following , which [I]137-william collins can do without any inconvenience , as [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine is far from objecting to [my]137-william collins occasional absence on a Sunday , provided that [some other clergyman]3499-some other clergyman is engaged to do the duty of the day . [I]137-william collins remain , [dear sir]3500-dear sir , with respectful compliments to [[your]3495-your lady]3437-your lady and [daughters]3502-daughters , [[your]3495-your well - wisher]3503-your well - wisher and friend , “[137-william collins] [WILLIAM COLLINS]137-william collins . ” “[137-william collins] At four o’clock , therefore , [we]671-we may expect [this peace - making gentleman]672-this peace - making gentleman , ” said [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet , as [he]0-i folded up the letter . “[672-this peace - making gentleman] [He]672-this peace - making gentleman seems to be [a most conscientious and polite young man]673-a most conscientious and polite young man , upon [my]0-i word ; and , [I]0-i doubt not , will prove a valuable acquaintance , especially if [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine should be so indulgent as to let [him]672-this peace - making gentleman come to [us]671-we again . ” “[93-lady catherine] There is some sense in what [he]672-this peace - making gentleman says about [the girls]3082-the girls , however ; and , if [he]672-this peace - making gentleman is disposed to make [them]3082-the girls any amends , [I]0-i shall not be the person to discourage [him]672-this peace - making gentleman . ” “[672-this peace - making gentleman] Though it is difficult , ” said [Jane]89-jane , “[672-this peace - making gentleman] to guess in what way [he]672-this peace - making gentleman can mean to make [us]671-we the atonement [he]672-this peace - making gentleman thinks [our]671-we due , the wish is certainly to [his]672-this peace - making gentleman credit . ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was chiefly struck with [his]672-this peace - making gentleman extraordinary deference for [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine , and [his]672-this peace - making gentleman kind intention of christening , marrying , and burying [[his]672-this peace - making gentleman parishioners]3504-his parishioners whenever it were required . “[672-this peace - making gentleman] [He]672-this peace - making gentleman must be an oddity , [I]0-i think , ” said [she]88-elizabeth . “[0-i] [I]0-i can not make [him]672-this peace - making gentleman out . [We]671-we can not suppose [he]672-this peace - making gentleman would help it , if [he]672-this peace - making gentleman could . Can [he]672-this peace - making gentleman be [a sensible man]675-a sensible man , [sir]3234-sir ? ” “[672-this peace - making gentleman] No , [[my]0-i dear]3066-my dear ; [I]0-i think not . [I]0-i have great hopes of finding [him]672-this peace - making gentleman quite the reverse . [I]0-i am impatient to see [him]672-this peace - making gentleman . ” “[0-i] In point of composition , ” said [Mary]94-mary , “[0-i] [his]672-this peace - making gentleman letter does not seem defective . The idea of the olive branch perhaps is not wholly new , yet [I]0-i think it is well expressed . ” To [Catherine]93-lady catherine and [Lydia]90-lydia neither the letter nor [its writer]3505-its writer were in any degree interesting . It was next to impossible that [[their]671-we cousin]3506-their cousin should come in a scarlet coat , and it was now some weeks since [they]671-we had received pleasure from the society of [a man in any other colour]3507-a man in any other colour . As for [[their]671-we mother]433-their mother , [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins ’s letter had done away much of [her]433-their mother ill - will , and [she]433-their mother was preparing to see [him]134-mr. collins with a degree of composure which astonished [[her]433-their mother husband]260-her husband and [daughters]3502-daughters . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins was punctual to [his]134-mr. collins time , and was received with great politeness by [the whole family]312-the whole family . [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet indeed said little ; but [the ladies]254-the ladies were ready enough to talk , and [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins seemed neither in need of encouragement , nor inclined to be silent [himself]134-mr. collins . [He]134-mr. collins was [a tall , heavy - looking young man of five - and - twenty]3513-a tall , heavy - looking young man of five - and - twenty . [His]134-mr. collins air was grave and stately , and [his]134-mr. collins manners were very formal . [He]134-mr. collins had not been long seated before [he]134-mr. collins complimented [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet on having so fine [a family of daughters]3514-a family of daughters , said [he]134-mr. collins had heard much of [their]3514-a family of daughters beauty , but that , in this instance , fame had fallen short of the truth ; and added , that [he]134-mr. collins did not doubt [her]92-mrs. bennet seeing [them]3514-a family of daughters all in due time well disposed of in marriage . This gallantry was not much to the taste of [some of [[his]134-mr. collins hearers]3516-his hearers]3515-some of his hearers ; but [Mrs. Bennet , who quarrelled with no compliments]92-mrs. bennet , answered most readily,-- “[678-you] [You]678-you are very kind , [sir]3234-sir , [I]0-i am sure ; and [I]0-i wish with all [my]0-i heart it may prove so ; for else [they]680-they will be destitute enough . Things are settled so oddly . ” “[678-you] [You]678-you allude , perhaps , to the entail of [this estate]681-this estate . ” “[678-you] Ah , [sir]3234-sir , [I]0-i do indeed . It is a grievous affair to [[my]0-i poor girls]683-my poor girls , [you]3234-sir must confess . There is no knowing how estates will go when once they come to be entailed . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am very sensible , [madam]3346-madam , of the hardship to [[my]0-i fair cousins]686-my fair cousins , and could say much on the subject , but that [I]0-i am cautious of appearing forward and precipitate . [They]680-they were not the only objects of [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins ’s admiration . [The hall]3519-the hall , [the dining - room]3520-the dining - room , and all [its]3520-the dining - room furniture , were examined and praised ; and [his]0-i commendation of everything would have touched [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet ’s heart , but for the mortifying supposition of [his]0-i viewing it all as [[his]0-i own future property]3521-his own future property . The dinner , too , in its turn , was highly admired ; and [he]0-i begged to know to which of [[his]0-i fair cousins]3522-his fair cousins the excellence of its cookery was owing . But here [he]0-i was set right by [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet , who assured [him]0-i , with some asperity , that [they]688-we were very well able to keep [a good cook]3523-a good cook , and that [[her]92-mrs. bennet daughters]242-her daughters had nothing to do in [the kitchen]3525-the kitchen . [He]0-i begged pardon for having displeased [her]92-mrs. bennet . In a softened tone [she]92-mrs. bennet declared [herself]92-mrs. bennet not at all offended ; but [he]0-i continued to apologize for about a quarter of an hour . [ Illustration ] CHAPTER XIV [ Illustration ] During dinner , [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet scarcely spoke at all ; but when [the servants]3526-the servants were withdrawn , [he]81-mr. bennet thought it time to have some conversation with [[his]81-mr. bennet guest]3527-his guest , and therefore started a subject in which [he]81-mr. bennet expected [him]0-i to shine , by observing that [he]0-i seemed very fortunate in [[his]0-i patroness]3528-his patroness . [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]93-lady catherine ’s attention to [his]0-i wishes , and consideration for [his]0-i comfort , appeared very remarkable . [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet could not have chosen better . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins was eloquent in [her]92-mrs. bennet praise . The subject elevated [him]134-mr. collins to more than usual solemnity of manner ; and with a most important aspect [he]134-mr. collins protested that [he]134-mr. collins had never in [his]134-mr. collins life witnessed such behaviour in [a person of rank]3529-a person of rank -- such affability and condescension , as [he]134-mr. collins had [himself]134-mr. collins experienced from [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine . [She]92-mrs. bennet had been graciously pleased to approve of both the discourses which [he]134-mr. collins had already had the honour of preaching before [her]92-mrs. bennet . [She]92-mrs. bennet had also asked [him]134-mr. collins twice to dine at Rosings , and had sent for [him]134-mr. collins only the Saturday before , to make up [her]92-mrs. bennet pool of quadrille in the evening . [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine was reckoned proud by [many people]3530-many people , [he]134-mr. collins knew , but [he]134-mr. collins had never seen anything but affability in [her]93-lady catherine . [She]92-mrs. bennet had always spoken to [him]134-mr. collins as [she]92-mrs. bennet would to [any other gentleman]3531-any other gentleman ; [she]92-mrs. bennet made not the smallest objection to [his]134-mr. collins joining in [the society of [the neighbourhood]3088-the neighbourhood]3532-the society of the neighbourhood , nor to [his]134-mr. collins leaving [[his]134-mr. collins parish]3534-his parish occasionally for a week or two to visit [[his]134-mr. collins relations]3535-his relations . [She]92-mrs. bennet had even condescended to advise [him]134-mr. collins to marry as soon as [he]134-mr. collins could , provided [he]134-mr. collins chose with discretion ; and had once paid [him]134-mr. collins a visit in [[his]134-mr. collins humble parsonage]3536-his humble parsonage , where [she]92-mrs. bennet had perfectly approved all the alterations [he]134-mr. collins had been making , and had even vouchsafed to suggest some herself,--some shelves in the closets [upstairs]3537-upstairs . “[689-she] That is all very proper and civil , [I]0-i am sure , ” said [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet , “[689-she] and [I]0-i dare say [she]689-she is [a very agreeable woman]690-a very agreeable woman . It is a pity that [great ladies in general]691-great ladies in general are not more like [her]689-she . And what sort of [young lady]704-young lady is [she]689-she ? Is [she]689-she handsome ? ” “[689-she] [She]689-she is [a most charming young lady]705-a most charming young lady , indeed . [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine [herself]93-lady catherine says that , in point of true beauty , [Miss de Bourgh]138-miss de bourgh is far superior to the handsomest of [her]138-miss de bourgh sex ; because there is that in [her]138-miss de bourgh features which marks [the young woman of distinguished birth]706-the young woman of distinguished birth . [She]689-she is unfortunately of a sickly constitution , which has prevented [her]689-she making that progress in many accomplishments which [she]689-she could not otherwise have failed of , as [I]0-i am informed by [the lady who superintended [her]689-she education , and who still resides with [them]708-them]707-the lady who superintended her education , and who still resides with them . But [she]689-she is perfectly amiable , and often condescends to drive by [[my]0-i humble abode]694-my humble abode in [her]689-she little phaeton and ponies . ” “[689-she] Has [she]689-she been presented ? [[Her]689-she Ladyship]3490-her ladyship seemed pleased with the idea ; and [you]714-you may imagine that [I]0-i am happy on every occasion to offer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable to [ladies]275-ladies . [I]0-i have more than once observed to [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine , that [[her]93-lady catherine charming daughter]716-her charming daughter seemed born to be [a duchess]717-a duchess ; and that the most elevated rank , instead of giving [her]689-she consequence , would be adorned by [her]689-she . These are the kind of little things which please [[her]689-she Ladyship]3490-her ladyship , and it is a sort of attention which [I]0-i conceive [myself]0-i peculiarly bound to pay . ” “[714-you] [You]714-you judge very properly , ” said [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet ; “[714-you] and it is happy for [you]714-you that [you]714-you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy . May [I]0-i ask whether these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the moment , or are the result of previous study ? ” “[0-i] They arise chiefly from what is passing at the time ; and though [I]0-i sometimes amuse [myself]0-i with suggesting and arranging such little elegant compliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions , [I]0-i always wish to give them as unstudied an air as possible . ” [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet ’s expectations were fully answered . [[His]81-mr. bennet cousin]3538-his cousin was as absurd as [he]81-mr. bennet had hoped ; and [he]81-mr. bennet listened to [him]3538-his cousin with the keenest enjoyment , maintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance , and , except in an occasional glance at [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , requiring [no partner]3539-no partner in [his]3538-his cousin pleasure . By tea - time , however , the dose had been enough , and [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet was glad to take [[his]81-mr. bennet guest]3527-his guest into [the drawing - room]524-the drawing - room again , and when tea was over , glad to invite [him]0-i [ Illustration : “[0-i] Protested that [he]0-i never read novels ” H.T Feb 94 ] to read aloud to [the ladies]254-the ladies . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins readily assented , and a book was produced ; but on beholding it ( for everything announced it to be from a circulating library ) [he]0-i started back , and , begging pardon , protested that [he]0-i never read novels . [Kitty]93-lady catherine stared at [him]0-i , and [Lydia]90-lydia exclaimed . Other books were produced , and after some deliberation [he]0-i chose “[139-fordyce] [Fordyce]139-fordyce ’s Sermons . ” [Lydia]90-lydia gaped as [he]0-i opened the volume ; and before [he]0-i had , with very monotonous solemnity , read three pages , [she]90-lydia interrupted [him]0-i with,-- “[139-fordyce] Do [you]719-you know , [mamma]3106-mamma , that [[my]0-i uncle]721-my uncle [Philips]117-mrs. philips talks of turning away [Richard]140-richard ? and if [he]721-my uncle does , [Colonel Forster]113-colonel forster will hire [him]721-my uncle . [[My]0-i aunt]3279-my aunt told [me]0-i so [herself]3279-my aunt on Saturday . [I]0-i shall walk to [Meryton]9-meryton to - morrow to hear more about it , and to ask when [Mr. Denny]141-denny comes back from [town]268-town . ” [Lydia]90-lydia was bid by [[her]90-lydia two eldest sisters]3543-her two eldest sisters to hold [her]90-lydia tongue ; but [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , much offended , laid aside [his]0-i book , and said,-- “[141-denny] [I]0-i have often observed how [little young ladies]724-little young ladies are interested by books of a serious stamp , though written solely for [their]724-little young ladies benefit . It amazes [me]0-i , [I]0-i confess ; for certainly there can be nothing so advantageous to [them]724-little young ladies as instruction . But [I]0-i will no longer importune [[my]0-i young cousin]725-my young cousin . ” Then , turning to [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet , [he]0-i offered [himself]0-i as [[his]0-i antagonist]3544-his antagonist at backgammon . [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet accepted the challenge , observing that [he]81-mr. bennet acted very wisely in leaving [the girls]3082-the girls to [their]3082-the girls own trifling amusements . [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet and [[her]92-mrs. bennet daughters]242-her daughters apologized most civilly for [Lydia]90-lydia ’s interruption , and promised that it should not occur again , if [he]0-i would resume [his]0-i book ; but [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , after assuring [them]3082-the girls that [he]134-mr. collins bore [[his]134-mr. collins young cousin]3547-his young cousin no ill - will , and should never resent [her]3547-his young cousin behaviour as any affront , seated [himself]134-mr. collins at another table with [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet , and prepared for backgammon . [ Illustration ] CHAPTER XV . [ Illustration ] [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins was not [a sensible man]675-a sensible man , and the deficiency of nature had been but little assisted by education or society ; the greatest part of [his]134-mr. collins life having been spent under the guidance of [an illiterate and miserly father]3549-an illiterate and miserly father ; and though [he]134-mr. collins belonged to [one of [the universities]3551-the universities]3550-one of the universities , [he]134-mr. collins had merely kept the necessary terms without forming at it any useful acquaintance . The subjection in which [[his]0-i father]339-his father had brought [him]0-i up had given [him]0-i originally great humility of manner ; but it was now a good deal counteracted by the self - conceit of a weak head , living in retirement , and the consequential feelings of early and unexpected prosperity . [A fortunate chance]3553-a fortunate chance had recommended [him]0-i to [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]93-lady catherine when the living of [Hunsford]15-hunsford was vacant ; and the respect which [he]0-i felt for [her]93-lady catherine high rank , and [his]0-i veneration for [her]93-lady catherine as [[his]0-i patroness]3528-his patroness , mingling with a very good opinion of [himself]0-i , of [his]0-i authority as [a clergyman]3492-a clergyman , and [his]0-i right as [a rector]3556-a rector , made [him]0-i altogether a mixture of pride and obsequiousness , self - importance and humility . Having now [a good house]342-a good house and a very sufficient income , [he]0-i intended to marry ; and in seeking a reconciliation with [[the Longbourn]7-longbourn family]3558-the longbourn family [he]0-i had [a wife]229-a wife in view , as [he]0-i meant to choose [one of [the daughters]3561-the daughters]3560-one of the daughters , if [he]0-i found [them]3561-the daughters as handsome and amiable as [they]3561-the daughters were represented by common report . This was [his]0-i plan of amends -- of atonement -- for inheriting [[[their]3561-the daughters father]252-their father ’s estate]3563-their father ’s estate ; and [he]0-i thought it an excellent one , full of eligibility and suitableness , and excessively generous and disinterested on [his]0-i own part . [His]0-i plan did not vary on seeing [them]3561-the daughters . [Miss Bennet]90-lydia ’s lovely face confirmed [his]0-i views , and established all [his]0-i strictest notions of what was due to seniority ; and for the first evening [she]90-lydia was [his]0-i settled choice . The next morning , however , made an alteration ; for in a quarter of an hour ’s tête - à - tête with [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet before breakfast , a conversation beginning with [[his]0-i parsonage - house]3564-his parsonage - house , and leading naturally to the avowal of [his]0-i hopes , that [a mistress for it]3565-a mistress for it might be found at [Longbourn]7-longbourn , produced from [her]726-she , amid very complaisant smiles and general encouragement , a caution against the very Jane [he]0-i had fixed on . “[726-she] As to [[her]726-she younger daughters]727-her younger daughters , [she]726-she could not take upon [her]726-she to say -- [she]726-she could not positively answer -- but [she]726-she did not know of any prepossession -her eldest daughter [she]726-she must just mention -- [she]726-she felt it incumbent on [her]726-she to hint , was likely to be very soon engaged . ” [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins had only to change from [Jane]89-jane to [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth -- and it was soon done -- done while [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet was stirring the fire . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , equally next to [Jane]89-jane in birth and beauty , succeeded [her]92-mrs. bennet of course . [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet treasured up the hint , and trusted that [she]92-mrs. bennet might soon have [two daughters]3566-two daughters married ; and [the man whom [she]92-mrs. bennet [could not bear to speak of the day before]3568-could not bear to speak of the day before]3567-the man whom she could not bear to speak of the day before , was now high in [her]92-mrs. bennet good graces . [Lydia]90-lydia ’s intention of walking to [Meryton]9-meryton was not forgotten : [every sister]3569-every sister except [Mary]94-mary agreed to go with [her]90-lydia ; and [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins was to attend [them]3566-two daughters , at the request of [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet , who was most anxious to get rid of [him]134-mr. collins , and have [[his]81-mr. bennet library]263-his library to [himself]81-mr. bennet ; for thither [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins had followed [him]81-mr. bennet after breakfast , and there [he]134-mr. collins would continue , nominally engaged with one of the largest folios in the collection , but really talking to [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet , with little cessation , of [[his]81-mr. bennet house and garden at [Hunsford]15-hunsford]3571-his house and garden at hunsford . Such doings discomposed [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet exceedingly . In [[his]81-mr. bennet library]263-his library [he]81-mr. bennet had been always sure of leisure and tranquillity ; and though prepared , as [he]81-mr. bennet told [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , to meet with folly and conceit in [every other room in [the house]3075-the house]3573-every other room in the house , [he]81-mr. bennet was used to be free from [them]3575-them [there]306-there : [his]81-mr. bennet civility , therefore , was most prompt in inviting [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins to join [[his]81-mr. bennet daughters]430-his daughters in [their]430-his daughters walk ; and [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , being in fact much better fitted for [a walker]3578-a walker than [a reader]3579-a reader , was extremely well pleased to close [his]134-mr. collins large book , and go . In pompous nothings on [his]134-mr. collins side , and civil assents on that of [[his]134-mr. collins cousins]3580-his cousins , [their]430-his daughters time passed till [they]430-his daughters entered [Meryton]9-meryton . The attention of [the younger ones]3581-the younger ones was then no longer to be gained by [him]134-mr. collins . [Their]3581-the younger ones eyes were immediately wandering up [the street]3582-the street in quest of [the officers]452-the officers , and nothing less than a very smart bonnet , indeed , or a really new muslin in a shop window , could recall [them]3581-the younger ones . But the attention of [every lady]3584-every lady was soon caught by [a young man , whom [they]3581-the younger ones had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with [an officer on the other side of the way]3586-an officer on the other side of the way]3585-a young man , whom they had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with an officer on the other side of the way . [The officer]3587-the officer was [the very Mr. Denny]141-denny concerning whose return from [London]5-london [Lydia]90-lydia came to inquire , and [he]134-mr. collins bowed as [they]430-his daughters passed . [All]3588-all were struck with [the stranger]323-the stranger ’s air , all wondered who [he]323-the stranger could be ; and [Kitty]93-lady catherine and [Lydia]90-lydia , determined if possible to find out , led the way across [the street]3582-the street , under pretence of wanting something in [an opposite shop]3591-an opposite shop , and fortunately had just gained [the pavement]3592-the pavement , when [the two gentlemen]3593-the two gentlemen , turning back , had reached the same spot . [Mr. Denny]141-denny addressed [them]3593-the two gentlemen directly , and entreated permission to introduce [[his]141-denny friend]288-his friend , [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham , who had returned with [him]141-denny the day before from [town]268-town , and , [he]141-denny was happy to say , had accepted a commission in [[their]3593-the two gentlemen corps]3596-their corps . This was exactly as it should be ; for [the young man]3597-the young man wanted only regimentals to make [him]3597-the young man completely charming . [His]3597-the young man appearance was greatly in [his]3597-the young man favour : [he]3597-the young man had all the best parts of beauty , a fine countenance , a good figure , and very pleasing address . The introduction was followed up on [his]3597-the young man side by a happy readiness of conversation -- a readiness at the same time perfectly correct and unassuming ; and [the whole party]525-the whole party were still standing and talking together very agreeably , when the sound of horses drew [their]3593-the two gentlemen notice , and [Darcy]96-mr. darcy and [Bingley]85-mr. bingley were seen riding down [the street]3582-the street . On distinguishing [the ladies of the group]3600-the ladies of the group [the two gentlemen]3593-the two gentlemen came directly towards [them]3593-the two gentlemen , and began the usual civilities . [Bingley]85-mr. bingley was [the principal spokesman]3602-the principal spokesman , and [Miss Bennet]90-lydia the principal object . [He]85-mr. bingley was then , [he]85-mr. bingley said , on [his]85-mr. bingley way to [Longbourn]7-longbourn on purpose to inquire after [her]90-lydia . [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy corroborated it with a bow , and was beginning to determine not to fix [his]96-mr. darcy eyes on [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , when [they]3593-the two gentlemen were suddenly arrested by the sight of [the stranger]323-the stranger ; and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth happening to see the countenance of both as [they]3593-the two gentlemen looked at [each other]3216-each other , was all astonishment at the effect of the meeting . Both changed colour , one looked white , the other red . [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham , after a few moments , touched [his]142-wickham hat -- a salutation which [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy just deigned to return . What could be the meaning of it ? It was impossible to imagine ; it was impossible not to long to know . In another minute [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley , but without seeming to have noticed what passed , took leave and rode on with [[his]85-mr. bingley friend]288-his friend . [Mr. Denny]141-denny and [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham walked with [the young ladies]264-the young ladies to the door of [[Mr. Philips]116-mr. philips ’s house]3607-mr. philips ’s house , and then made [their]3593-the two gentlemen bows , in spite of [Miss Lydia]90-lydia ’s pressing entreaties that [they]3593-the two gentlemen would come in , and even in spite of [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips ’s throwing up the parlour window , and loudly seconding the invitation . [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips was always glad to see [[her]117-mrs. philips nieces]3117-her nieces ; and [the two eldest]395-the two eldest , from [their]395-the two eldest recent absence , were particularly welcome ; and [she]117-mrs. philips was eagerly expressing [her]117-mrs. philips surprise at [their]395-the two eldest sudden return [home]3288-home , which , as [[their]395-the two eldest own carriage]3611-their own carriage had not fetched [them]395-the two eldest , [she]117-mrs. philips should have known nothing about , if [she]117-mrs. philips had not happened to see [[Mr. Jones]125-mr. jones ’s shopboy]3612-mr. jones ’s shopboy in [the street]3582-the street , who had told [her]117-mrs. philips that [they]395-the two eldest were not to send any more draughts to [Netherfield]2-netherfield , because [the Miss Bennets]105-the bennets were come away , when [her]117-mrs. philips civility was claimed towards [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins by [Jane]89-jane ’s introduction of [him]134-mr. collins . [She]117-mrs. philips received [him]134-mr. collins with [her]117-mrs. philips very best politeness , which [he]134-mr. collins returned with as much more , apologizing for [his]134-mr. collins intrusion , without any previous acquaintance with [her]117-mrs. philips , which [he]134-mr. collins could not help flattering [himself]134-mr. collins , however , might be justified by [his]134-mr. collins relationship to [the young ladies who introduced [him]134-mr. collins to [her]117-mrs. philips notice]3614-the young ladies who introduced him to her notice . [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips was quite awed by such an excess of good breeding ; but [her]117-mrs. philips contemplation of [one stranger]3615-one stranger was soon put an end to by exclamations and inquiries about the other , of whom , however , [she]117-mrs. philips could only tell [[her]117-mrs. philips nieces]3117-her nieces what [they]3117-her nieces already knew , that [Mr. Denny]141-denny had brought [him]134-mr. collins from [London]5-london , and that [he]134-mr. collins was to have [a lieutenant]3617-a lieutenant ’s commission in [the ----shire]20-the ----shire . [She]117-mrs. philips had been watching [him]134-mr. collins the last hour , [she]117-mrs. philips said , as [he]134-mr. collins walked up and down the street,--and had [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham appeared , [Kitty]93-lady catherine and [Lydia]90-lydia would certainly have continued the occupation ; but unluckily [no one]3336-no one passed the windows now except [a few of [the officers]452-the officers , who , in comparison with [the stranger]323-the stranger , were become “[726-she] stupid , [disagreeable fellows]728-disagreeable fellows . ” [Some of [them]3117-her nieces]3622-some of them]3619-a few of the officers , who , in comparison with the stranger , were become “ stupid , disagreeable fellows . ” some of them were to dine with [the Philipses]143-the philipses the next day , and [[their]3117-her nieces aunt]442-their aunt promised to make [[her]117-mrs. philips husband]260-her husband call on [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham , and give [him]142-wickham an invitation also , if [[the family]414-the family from [Longbourn]7-longbourn]3626-the family from longbourn would come in the evening . This was agreed to ; and [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips protested that [they]3117-her nieces would have a nice comfortable noisy game of lottery tickets , and a little bit of hot supper afterwards . The prospect of such delights was very cheering , and [they]3117-her nieces parted in mutual good spirits . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins repeated [his]134-mr. collins apologies in quitting [the room]255-the room , and was assured , with unwearying civility , that [they]3117-her nieces were perfectly needless . As [they]3117-her nieces walked [home]3288-home , [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth related to [Jane]89-jane what [she]88-elizabeth had seen pass between [the two gentlemen]3593-the two gentlemen ; but though [Jane]89-jane would have defended either or both , had [they]3593-the two gentlemen appeared to be wrong , [she]89-jane could no more explain such behaviour than [[her]89-jane sister]328-her sister . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins on [his]134-mr. collins return highly gratified [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet by admiring [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips ’s manners and politeness . [He]134-mr. collins protested that , except [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine and [[her]93-lady catherine daughter]461-her daughter , [he]134-mr. collins had never seen [a more elegant woman]3632-a more elegant woman ; for [she]92-mrs. bennet had not only received [him]134-mr. collins with the utmost civility , but had even pointedly included [him]134-mr. collins in [her]92-mrs. bennet invitation for the next evening , although utterly unknown to [her]92-mrs. bennet before . Something , [he]134-mr. collins supposed , might be attributed to [his]134-mr. collins connection with [them]3633-them , but yet [he]134-mr. collins had never met with so much attention in the whole course of [his]134-mr. collins life . [ Illustration ] [CHAPTER XVI]144-chapter xvi . [ Illustration ] As no objection was made to [the young people]3634-the young people ’s engagement with [[their]3634-the young people aunt]442-their aunt , and all [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins ’s scruples of leaving [Mr.]3636-mr. and [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet for a single evening during [his]134-mr. collins visit were most steadily resisted , [the coach]3290-the coach conveyed [him]134-mr. collins and [[his]134-mr. collins five cousins]3638-his five cousins at a suitable hour to [Meryton]9-meryton ; and [the girls]3082-the girls had the pleasure of hearing , as [they]3082-the girls entered [the drawing - room]524-the drawing - room , that [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham had accepted [[their]3082-the girls uncle]3314-their uncle ’s invitation , and was then in [the house]3075-the house . When this information was given , and [they]3082-the girls had all taken [their]3082-the girls seats , [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins was at leisure to look around [him]134-mr. collins and admire , and [he]134-mr. collins was so much struck with the size and furniture of [the apartment]3643-the apartment , that [he]134-mr. collins declared [he]134-mr. collins might almost have supposed [himself]134-mr. collins in [the small summer breakfast parlour at [Rosings]19-rosings]3644-the small summer breakfast parlour at rosings ; a comparison that did not at first convey much gratification ; but when [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips understood from [him]134-mr. collins what [Rosings]19-rosings was , and who was [[its]19-rosings proprietor]3645-its proprietor , when [she]117-mrs. philips had listened to the description of only one of [[Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine ’s drawing - rooms]3646-lady catherine ’s drawing - rooms , and found that the chimney - piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds , [she]117-mrs. philips felt all the force of the compliment , and would hardly have resented a comparison with [[the housekeeper]3647-the housekeeper ’s room]3648-the housekeeper ’s room . In describing to [her]117-mrs. philips all the grandeur of [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine and [[her]93-lady catherine mansion]3649-her mansion , with occasional digressions in praise of [[his]134-mr. collins own humble abode]3650-his own humble abode , and the improvements it was receiving , [he]134-mr. collins was happily employed until [the gentlemen]292-the gentlemen joined [them]292-the gentlemen ; and [he]134-mr. collins found in [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips a very attentive listener , whose opinion of [his]134-mr. collins consequence increased with what [she]117-mrs. philips heard , and who was resolving to retail it all among [[her]117-mrs. philips neighbours]3652-her neighbours as soon as [she]117-mrs. philips could . To [the girls]3082-the girls , who could not listen to [their]3082-the girls [cousin , and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument]3654-cousin , and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument , and examine [their]3082-the girls own indifferent imitations of china on the mantel - piece , the interval of waiting appeared very long . It was over at last , however . [The gentlemen]292-the gentlemen did approach : and when [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham walked into [the room]255-the room , [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth felt that [she]88-elizabeth had neither been seeing [him]142-wickham before , nor thinking of [him]142-wickham since , with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration . [The officers of the ----shire]3657-the officers of the ----shire were in general [a very creditable , gentlemanlike set]3658-a very creditable , gentlemanlike set and the best of [them]3657-the officers of the ----shire were of [the present party]3448-the present party ; but [Mr , Wickham]142-wickham was as far beyond [them]3657-the officers of the ----shire all in person , countenance , air , and walk , as [they]3657-the officers of the ----shire were superior to [the broad - faced stuffy uncle [Philips]117-mrs. philips , breathing port wine , who followed [them]3657-the officers of the ----shire into [the room]255-the room]3660-the broad - faced stuffy uncle philips , breathing port wine , who followed them into the room . [ Illustration : “[3657-the officers of the ----shire] [The officers of the ----shire]3657-the officers of the ----shire ” [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham was [the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned]3662-the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned , and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was [the happy woman by whom [he]142-wickham finally seated [himself]142-wickham]3663-the happy woman by whom he finally seated himself ; and the agreeable manner in which [he]142-wickham immediately fell into conversation , though it was only on its being a wet night , and on the probability of a rainy season , made [her]88-elizabeth feel that the commonest , dullest , most threadbare topic might be rendered interesting by the skill of [the speaker]3664-the speaker . With [such rivals for the notice of the fair as [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham and [the officers]452-the officers]3665-such rivals for the notice of the fair as mr. wickham and the officers , [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins seemed to sink into insignificance ; to [the young ladies]264-the young ladies [he]142-wickham certainly was nothing ; but [he]142-wickham had still at intervals a kind listener in [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips , and was , by [her]117-mrs. philips watchfulness , most abundantly supplied with coffee and muffin . When the card tables were placed , [he]142-wickham had an opportunity of obliging [her]88-elizabeth , in return , by sitting down to whist . “[0-i] [I]0-i know little of the game at present , ” said [he]142-wickham , “[0-i] but [I]0-i shall be glad to improve [myself]0-i ; for in [my]0-i situation of life---- ” [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips was very thankful for [his]142-wickham compliance , but could not wait for [his]142-wickham reason . [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham did not play at whist , and with ready delight was [he]142-wickham received at the other table between [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth and [Lydia]90-lydia . At first there seemed danger of [Lydia]90-lydia ’s engrossing [him]142-wickham entirely , for [she]90-lydia was [a most determined talker]3668-a most determined talker ; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets , [she]90-lydia soon grew too much interested in the game , too eager in making bets and exclaiming after prizes , to have attention for [anyone in particular]3669-anyone in particular . Allowing for the common demands of the game , [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham was therefore at leisure to talk to [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , and [she]88-elizabeth was very willing to hear [him]142-wickham , though what [she]88-elizabeth chiefly wished to hear [she]88-elizabeth could not hope to be told , the history of [his]142-wickham acquaintance with [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy . [She]88-elizabeth dared not even mention [that gentleman]3371-that gentleman . [Her]88-elizabeth curiosity , however , was unexpectedly relieved . [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham began the subject [himself]142-wickham . [He]142-wickham inquired how far [Netherfield]2-netherfield was from [Meryton]9-meryton ; and , after receiving [her]88-elizabeth answer , asked in a hesitating manner how long [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy had been staying [there]306-there . “[730-his] About a month , ” said [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ; and then , unwilling to let the subject drop , added , “[730-his] [he]730-his is [a man of very large property in [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire]731-a man of very large property in derbyshire , [I]0-i understand . ” “[730-his] Yes , ” replied [Wickham]142-wickham ; “[730-his] [[his]730-his estate]732-his estate there is a noble one . A clear ten thousand per annum . [You]733-you could not have met with [a person more capable of giving [you]733-you certain information on that head than [myself]0-i]734-a person more capable of giving you certain information on that head than myself -- for [I]0-i have been connected with [[his]730-his family]373-his family , in a particular manner , from [my]0-i infancy . ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth could not but look surprised . “[733-you] [You]733-you may well be surprised , [Miss Bennet]88-elizabeth , at such an assertion , after seeing , as [you]733-you probably might , the very cold manner of [our]736-our meeting yesterday . Are [you]733-you much acquainted with [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ? ” “[96-mr. darcy] As much as [I]0-i ever wish to be , ” cried [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , warmly . “[96-mr. darcy] [I]0-i have spent four days in [the same house]737-the same house with [him]96-mr. darcy , and [I]0-i think [him]96-mr. darcy very disagreeable . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i have no right to give [my]0-i opinion , ” said [Wickham]142-wickham , “[0-i] as to [his]96-mr. darcy being agreeable or otherwise . [I]0-i am not qualified to form one . [I]0-i have known [him]96-mr. darcy too long and too well to be [a fair judge]738-a fair judge . It is impossible for [me]0-i to be impartial . But [I]0-i believe [your]733-you opinion of [him]96-mr. darcy would in general astonish -- and , perhaps , [you]733-you would not express it quite so strongly anywhere else . Here [you]733-you are in [[your]733-you own family]739-your own family . ” “[733-you] Upon [my]0-i word [I]0-i say no more here than [I]0-i might say in [any house in [the neighbourhood]3088-the neighbourhood]740-any house in the neighbourhood , except [Netherfield]2-netherfield . [He]96-mr. darcy is not at all liked in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire . [Everybody]305-everybody is disgusted with [his]96-mr. darcy pride . [You]733-you will not find [him]96-mr. darcy more favourably spoken of by [anyone]3174-anyone . ” “[3174-anyone] [I]0-i can not pretend to be sorry , ” said [Wickham]142-wickham , after a short interruption , “[0-i] that [he]96-mr. darcy or that [any man]744-any man should not be estimated beyond [their]745-their deserts ; but with [him]96-mr. darcy [I]0-i believe it does not often happen . [The world]304-the world is blinded by [his]96-mr. darcy fortune and consequence , or frightened by [his]96-mr. darcy high and imposing manners , and sees [him]96-mr. darcy only as [he]96-mr. darcy chooses to be seen . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i should take [him]96-mr. darcy , even on [my]0-i slight acquaintance , to be [an ill - tempered man]747-an ill - tempered man . ” [Wickham]142-wickham only shook [his]142-wickham head . “[747-an ill - tempered man] [I]0-i wonder , ” said [he]142-wickham , at the next opportunity of speaking , “[747-an ill - tempered man] whether [he]96-mr. darcy is likely to be in [this country]748-this country much longer . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do not at all know ; but [I]0-i heard nothing of [his]96-mr. darcy going away when [I]0-i was at [Netherfield]2-netherfield . [I]0-i hope [your]0-i plans in favour of [the ----shire]20-the ----shire will not be affected by [his]96-mr. darcy being in [the neighbourhood]3088-the neighbourhood . ” “[0-i] Oh no -- it is not for [me]0-i to be driven away by [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy . If [he]96-mr. darcy wishes to avoid seeing [me]0-i [he]96-mr. darcy must go . [We]750-we are not on friendly terms , and it always gives [me]0-i pain to meet [him]96-mr. darcy , but [I]0-i have no reason for avoiding [him]96-mr. darcy but what [I]0-i might proclaim to all [the world]304-the world -- a sense of very great ill - usage , and most painful regrets at [his]96-mr. darcy being what [he]96-mr. darcy is . [[His]96-mr. darcy father]339-his father , [Miss Bennet]88-elizabeth , [the late Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , was one of [the best men that ever breathed]753-the best men that ever breathed , and [the truest friend [I]0-i ever had]754-the truest friend i ever had ; and [I]0-i can never be in company with [this Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy without being grieved to the soul by a thousand tender recollections . [His]96-mr. darcy behaviour to [myself]0-i has been scandalous ; but [I]0-i verily believe [I]0-i could forgive [him]96-mr. darcy anything and everything , rather than [his]96-mr. darcy disappointing the hopes and disgracing the memory of [[his]96-mr. darcy father]339-his father . ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth found the interest of the subject increase , and listened with all [her]88-elizabeth heart ; but the delicacy of it prevented further inquiry . [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham began to speak on more general topics , [Meryton]9-meryton , [the neighbourhood]3088-the neighbourhood , [the society]3673-the society , appearing highly pleased with all that [he]0-i had yet seen , and speaking of the latter , especially , with gentle but very intelligible gallantry . “[0-i] It was the prospect of constant society , and good society , ” [he]0-i added , “[0-i] which was [my]0-i chief inducement to enter the ----shire . [I]0-i know it to be [a most respectable , agreeable corps]756-a most respectable , agreeable corps ; and [[my]0-i friend]3416-my friend [Denny]141-denny tempted [me]0-i further by [his]141-denny account of [[their]758-their present quarters]759-their present quarters , and the very great attentions and excellent acquaintance [Meryton]9-meryton had procured [them]758-their . Society , [I]0-i own , is necessary to [me]0-i . [I]0-i have been [a disappointed man]760-a disappointed man , and [my]0-i spirits will not bear solitude . [I]0-i must have employment and society . A military life is not what [I]0-i was intended for , but circumstances have now made it eligible . [The church]761-the church ought to have been [my]0-i profession -- [I]0-i was brought up for [the church]761-the church ; and [I]0-i should at this time have been in possession of a most valuable living , had it pleased [the gentleman]287-the gentleman [we]764-we were speaking of just now . ” “[287-the gentleman] Indeed ! ” “[287-the gentleman] Yes -- [the late Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy bequeathed [me]0-i the next presentation of the best living in [his]96-mr. darcy gift . [He]96-mr. darcy was [[my]0-i godfather]765-my godfather , and excessively attached to [me]0-i . [I]0-i can not do justice to [his]96-mr. darcy kindness . [He]96-mr. darcy meant to provide for [me]0-i amply , and thought [he]96-mr. darcy had done it ; but when the living fell , it was given elsewhere . ” “[96-mr. darcy] Good heavens ! ” cried [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ; “[96-mr. darcy] but how could that be ? How could [his]96-mr. darcy will be disregarded ? Why did not [you]0-i seek legal redress ? ” “[0-i] There was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to give [me]0-i no hope from law . [A man of honour]766-a man of honour could not have doubted the intention , but [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy chose to doubt it -- or to treat it as a merely conditional recommendation , and to assert that [I]0-i had forfeited all claim to it by extravagance , imprudence , in short , anything or nothing . Certain it is that the living became vacant two years ago , exactly as [I]0-i was of an age to hold it , and that it was given to [another man]767-another man ; and no less certain is it , that [I]0-i can not accuse [myself]0-i of having really done anything to deserve to lose it . [I]0-i have a warm unguarded temper , and [I]0-i may perhaps have sometimes spoken [my]0-i opinion of [him]96-mr. darcy , and to [him]96-mr. darcy , too freely . [I]0-i can recall nothing worse . But the fact is , that [we]768-we are [very different sort of men]769-very different sort of men , and that [he]96-mr. darcy hates [me]0-i . ” “[96-mr. darcy] This is quite shocking ! [He]96-mr. darcy deserves to be publicly disgraced . ” “[96-mr. darcy] Some time or other [he]96-mr. darcy will be -- but it shall not be by [me]0-i . Till [I]0-i can forget [[his]96-mr. darcy father]339-his father , [I]0-i can never defy or expose [him]96-mr. darcy . ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth honoured [him]96-mr. darcy for such feelings , and thought [him]96-mr. darcy handsomer than ever as [he]96-mr. darcy expressed them . “[0-i] But what , ” said [she]88-elizabeth , after a pause , “[96-mr. darcy] can have been [his]96-mr. darcy motive ? what can have induced [him]96-mr. darcy to behave so cruelly ? ” “[96-mr. darcy] A thorough , determined dislike of [me]0-i -- a dislike which [I]0-i can not but attribute in some measure to jealousy . Had [the late Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy liked [me]0-i less , [[his]96-mr. darcy son]771-his son might have borne with [me]0-i better ; but [[his]96-mr. darcy father]339-his father ’s uncommon attachment to [me]0-i irritated [him]96-mr. darcy , [I]0-i believe , very early in life . [He]96-mr. darcy had not a temper to bear the sort of competition in which [we]773-we stood -- the sort of preference which was often given [me]0-i . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i had not thought [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy so bad as this -- though [I]0-i have never liked [him]96-mr. darcy , [I]0-i had not thought so very ill of [him]96-mr. darcy -- [I]0-i had supposed [him]96-mr. darcy to be despising [his]96-mr. darcy fellow - creatures in general , but did not suspect [him]96-mr. darcy of descending to such malicious revenge , such injustice , such inhumanity as this ! ” After a few minutes ’ reflection , however , [she]3674-she continued , “[96-mr. darcy] [I]0-i do remember [his]96-mr. darcy boasting one day , at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , of the implacability of [his]96-mr. darcy resentments , of [his]96-mr. darcy having an unforgiving temper . [His]96-mr. darcy disposition must be dreadful . ” “[96-mr. darcy] [I]0-i will not trust [myself]0-i on the subject , ” replied [Wickham]142-wickham ; “[0-i] [I]0-i can hardly be just to [him]96-mr. darcy . ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was again deep in thought , and after a time exclaimed , “[0-i] To treat in such a manner [the godson]774-the godson , [the friend]775-the friend , [the favourite of [[his]96-mr. darcy father]339-his father]776-the favourite of his father ! ” [She]88-elizabeth could have added , “[3165-a young man] [A young man]3165-a young man , too , like [you]0-i , whose very countenance may vouch for [your]0-i being amiable . ” But [she]88-elizabeth contented [herself]88-elizabeth with--“And[3165-a young man] one , too , who had probably been [[his]96-mr. darcy own companion]779-his own companion from childhood , connected together , as [I]0-i think [you]0-i said , in the closest manner . ” “[0-i] [We]780-we were born in [the same parish]781-the same parish , within [the same park]782-the same park ; the greatest part of [our]780-we youth was passed together : [inmates of [the same house]737-the same house]783-inmates of the same house , sharing the same amusements , objects of the same parental care . [[My]0-i father]3323-my father began life in the profession which [[your]0-i uncle]3438-your uncle , [Mr. Philips]116-mr. philips , appears to do so much credit to ; but [he]3323-my father gave up everything to be of use to [the late Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , and devoted all [his]3323-my father time to the care of [the Pemberley property]787-the pemberley property . [He]3323-my father was most highly esteemed by [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , [a most intimate , confidential friend]788-a most intimate , confidential friend . [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy often acknowledged [himself]96-mr. darcy to be under the greatest obligations to [[my]0-i father]3323-my father ’s active superintendence ; and when , immediately before [[my]0-i father]3323-my father ’s death , [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy gave [him]96-mr. darcy a voluntary promise of providing for [me]0-i , [I]0-i am convinced that [he]96-mr. darcy felt it to be as much a debt of gratitude to [him]96-mr. darcy as of affection to [myself]0-i . ” “[96-mr. darcy] How strange ! ” cried [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth . “[96-mr. darcy] How abominable ! [I]0-i wonder that the very pride of [this Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy has not made [him]96-mr. darcy just to [you]791-you . If from no better motive , that [he]96-mr. darcy should not have been too proud to be dishonest,--for dishonesty [I]0-i must call it . ” “[0-i] It is wonderful , ” replied [Wickham]142-wickham ; “[0-i] for almost all [his]96-mr. darcy actions may be traced to pride ; and pride has often been [[his]96-mr. darcy best friend]792-his best friend . It has connected [him]96-mr. darcy nearer with virtue than any other feeling . But [we]793-we are none of [us]793-we consistent ; and in [his]96-mr. darcy behaviour to [me]0-i there were stronger impulses even than pride . ” “[793-we] Can such abominable pride as [his]96-mr. darcy have ever done [him]96-mr. darcy good ? ” “[793-we] Yes ; it has often led [him]96-mr. darcy to be liberal and generous ; to give [his]96-mr. darcy money freely , to display hospitality , to assist [[his]96-mr. darcy tenants]794-his tenants , and relieve [the poor]795-the poor . Family pride , and filial pride , for [he]96-mr. darcy is very proud of what [[his]96-mr. darcy father]339-his father was , have done this . Not to appear to disgrace [[his]96-mr. darcy family]373-his family , to degenerate from the popular qualities , or lose the influence of the [Pemberley House]21-pemberley house , is a powerful motive . [He]96-mr. darcy has also brotherly pride , which , with some brotherly affection , makes [him]96-mr. darcy [a very kind and careful guardian of [[his]96-mr. darcy sister]565-his sister]798-a very kind and careful guardian of his sister ; and [you]800-you will hear [him]96-mr. darcy generally cried up as [the most attentive and best of brothers]801-the most attentive and best of brothers . ” “[96-mr. darcy] What sort of [a girl]802-a girl is [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy ? ” [He]0-i shook [his]0-i head . “[128-miss darcy] [I]0-i wish [I]0-i could call [her]128-miss darcy amiable . It gives [me]0-i pain to speak ill of [a Darcy]128-miss darcy ; but [she]128-miss darcy is too much like [[her]128-miss darcy brother,--very]803-her brother,--very , very proud . As [a child]804-a child , [she]128-miss darcy was affectionate and pleasing , and extremely fond of [me]0-i ; and [I]0-i have devoted hours and hours to [her]128-miss darcy amusement . But [she]128-miss darcy is nothing to [me]0-i now . [She]128-miss darcy is [a handsome girl]805-a handsome girl , about fifteen or sixteen , and , [I]0-i understand , highly accomplished . Since [[her]128-miss darcy father]249-her father ’s death [[her]128-miss darcy home]351-her home has been [London]5-london , where [a lady]3226-a lady lives with [her]128-miss darcy , and superintends [her]128-miss darcy education . ” After many pauses and many trials of other subjects , [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth could not help reverting once more to the first , and saying,-- “[3226-a lady] [I]0-i am astonished at [his]809-his intimacy with [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley . How can [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley , who seems good - humour [itself]85-mr. bingley , and is , [I]0-i really believe , truly amiable , be in friendship with [such a man]230-such a man ? How can [they]811-they suit each other ? Do [you]0-i know [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley ? ” “[0-i] Not at all . ” “[0-i] [He]85-mr. bingley is [a sweet - tempered , amiable , charming man]812-a sweet - tempered , amiable , charming man . [He]85-mr. bingley can not know what [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy is . ” “[96-mr. darcy] Probably not ; but [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy can please where [he]96-mr. darcy chooses . [He]96-mr. darcy does not want abilities . [He]96-mr. darcy can be a conversible companion if [he]96-mr. darcy thinks it worth [his]96-mr. darcy while . Among [those who are at all [his]96-mr. darcy equals]813-those who are at all his equals in consequence , [he]96-mr. darcy is [a very different man from what [he]96-mr. darcy is to the less prosperous]814-a very different man from what he is to the less prosperous . [His]96-mr. darcy pride never deserts [him]96-mr. darcy ; but with [the rich]815-the rich [he]96-mr. darcy is liberal - minded , just , sincere , rational , honourable , and , perhaps , agreeable,--allowing something for fortune and figure . ” [The whist party]3675-the whist party soon afterwards breaking up , [the players]3676-the players gathered round the other table , and [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins took [his]134-mr. collins station between [[his]134-mr. collins cousin]3538-his cousin [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth and [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips . The usual inquiries as to [his]134-mr. collins success were made by [the latter]491-the latter . It had not been very great ; [he]134-mr. collins had lost every point ; but when [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips began to express [her]117-mrs. philips concern thereupon , [he]134-mr. collins assured [her]117-mrs. philips , with much earnest gravity , that it was not of the least importance ; that [he]134-mr. collins considered the money as a mere trifle , and begged [she]117-mrs. philips would not make [herself]117-mrs. philips uneasy . “[0-i] [I]0-i know very well , [madam]3346-madam , ” said [he]134-mr. collins , “[3346-madam] that when [persons]817-persons sit down to a card table [they]817-persons must take [their]817-persons chance of these things,--and happily [I]0-i am not in such circumstances as to make five shillings any object . There are , undoubtedly , many who could not say the same ; but , thanks to [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]93-lady catherine , [I]0-i am removed far beyond the necessity of regarding little matters . ” [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham ’s attention was caught ; and after observing [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins for a few moments , [he]134-mr. collins asked [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth in a low voice whether [[her]88-elizabeth relations]583-her relations were very intimately acquainted with [the family of [De Bourgh]138-miss de bourgh]3680-the family of de bourgh . “[93-lady catherine] [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]93-lady catherine , ” [she]88-elizabeth replied , “[93-lady catherine] has very lately given [him]0-i a living . [I]0-i hardly know how [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins was first introduced to [her]93-lady catherine notice , but [he]134-mr. collins certainly has not known [her]93-lady catherine long . ” “[134-mr. collins] [You]818-you know of course that [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]93-lady catherine and [Lady Anne Darcy]146-anne were [sisters]819-sisters ; consequently that [she]93-lady catherine is aunt to [the present Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy . ” “[96-mr. darcy] No , indeed , [I]0-i did not . [I]0-i knew nothing at all of [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine ’s connections . [I]0-i never heard of [her]93-lady catherine existence till the day before yesterday . ” “[93-lady catherine] [[Her]93-lady catherine daughter]461-her daughter , [Miss de Bourgh]138-miss de bourgh , will have a very large fortune , and it is believed that [she]93-lady catherine and [[her]93-lady catherine cousin]821-her cousin will unite [the two estates]822-the two estates . ” This information made [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth smile , as [she]88-elizabeth thought of poor [Miss Bingley]98-miss bingley . [Vain]147-vain indeed must be all [her]88-elizabeth attentions , vain and useless [her]88-elizabeth affection for [[his]134-mr. collins sister]565-his sister and [her]88-elizabeth praise of [himself]134-mr. collins , if [he]134-mr. collins were already self - destined to another . “[134-mr. collins] [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , ” said [she]88-elizabeth , “[134-mr. collins] speaks highly both of [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine and [[her]93-lady catherine daughter]461-her daughter ; but , from some particulars that [he]134-mr. collins has related of [[her]93-lady catherine Ladyship]3490-her ladyship , [I]0-i suspect [his]134-mr. collins gratitude misleads [him]134-mr. collins ; and that , in spite of [her]93-lady catherine being [[his]134-mr. collins patroness]3528-his patroness , [she]93-lady catherine is [an arrogant , conceited woman]826-an arrogant , conceited woman . ” “[93-lady catherine] [I]0-i believe [her]93-lady catherine to be both in a great degree , ” replied [Wickham]142-wickham ; “[93-lady catherine] [I]0-i have not seen [her]93-lady catherine for many years ; but [I]0-i very well remember that [I]0-i never liked [her]93-lady catherine , and that [her]93-lady catherine manners were dictatorial and insolent . [She]93-lady catherine has the reputation of being remarkably sensible and clever ; but [I]0-i rather believe [she]93-lady catherine derives part of [her]93-lady catherine abilities from [her]93-lady catherine rank and fortune , part from [her]93-lady catherine authoritative manner , and the rest from the pride of [[her]93-lady catherine nephew]827-her nephew , who chooses that [everyone connected with [him]827-her nephew]828-everyone connected with him should have an understanding of [the first class]829-the first class . ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth allowed that [he]142-wickham had given a very rational account of it , and [they]3682-they continued talking together with mutual satisfaction till supper put an end to cards , and gave [the rest of [the ladies]254-the ladies]3683-the rest of the ladies [their]3683-the rest of the ladies share of [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham ’s attentions . There could be no conversation in the noise of [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips ’s supper party , but [his]142-wickham manners recommended [him]142-wickham to [everybody]305-everybody . Whatever [he]142-wickham said , was said well ; and whatever [he]142-wickham did , done gracefully . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth went away with [her]88-elizabeth head full of [him]142-wickham . [She]88-elizabeth could think of nothing but of [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham , and of what [he]142-wickham had told [her]88-elizabeth , all the way [home]3288-home ; but there was not time for [her]88-elizabeth even to mention [his]142-wickham name as [they]3687-they went , for neither [Lydia]90-lydia nor [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins were once silent . [Lydia]90-lydia talked incessantly of lottery tickets , of the fish [she]90-lydia had lost and the fish [she]90-lydia had won ; and [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , in describing the civility of [Mr.]3688-mr. and [Mrs. Philips]117-mrs. philips , protesting that [he]134-mr. collins did not in the least regard [his]134-mr. collins losses at whist , enumerating all the dishes at supper , and repeatedly fearing that [he]134-mr. collins crowded [[his]134-mr. collins cousins]3580-his cousins , had more to say than [he]134-mr. collins could well manage before [the carriage]3286-the carriage stopped at [Longbourn House]22-longbourn house . [ Illustration : “[827-her nephew] delighted to see [[their]830-their dear friend]520-their dear friend again ” ] CHAPTER XVII . [ Illustration ] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth related to [Jane]89-jane , the next day , what had passed between [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham and [herself]89-jane . [Jane]89-jane listened with astonishment and concern : [she]89-jane knew not how to believe that [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy could be so unworthy of [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley ’s regard ; and yet it was not in [her]89-jane nature to question the veracity of [a young man of such amiable appearance]3691-a young man of such amiable appearance as [Wickham]142-wickham . The possibility of [his]96-mr. darcy having really endured such unkindness was enough to interest all [her]89-jane tender feelings ; and nothing therefore remained to be done but to think well of [them]830-their both , to defend the conduct of [each]3692-each , and throw into the account of accident or mistake whatever could not be otherwise explained . “[830-their] [They]830-their have both , ” said [she]89-jane , “[830-their] been deceived , [I]0-i dare say , in some way or other , of which [we]832-we can form no idea . [Interested people]833-interested people have perhaps misrepresented [each]3692-each to [the other]3427-the other . It is , in short , impossible for [us]832-we to conjecture the causes or circumstances which may have alienated [them]833-interested people , without actual blame on either side . ” “[89-jane] Very true , indeed ; and now , [my]0-i dear [Jane]89-jane , what have [you]89-jane got to say in behalf of [the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business]836-the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business ? Do clear [them]836-the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business , too , or [we]832-we shall be obliged to think ill of [somebody]837-somebody . ” “[837-somebody] Laugh as much as [you]89-jane choose , but [you]89-jane will not laugh [me]0-i out of [my]0-i opinion . [[My]0-i dearest]3296-my dearest [Lizzy]88-elizabeth , do but consider in what a disgraceful light it places [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , to be treating [[[his]96-mr. darcy father]339-his father ’s favourite in such a manner,--one whom [[his]96-mr. darcy father]339-his father had promised to provide for]840-his father ’s favourite in such a manner,--one whom his father had promised to provide for . It is impossible . [No man of common humanity]842-no man of common humanity , [no man who had any value for [his]96-mr. darcy character]843-no man who had any value for his character , could be capable of it . Can [[his]96-mr. darcy most intimate friends]844-his most intimate friends be so excessively deceived in [him]96-mr. darcy ? Oh no . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i can much more easily believe [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley ’s being imposed on than that [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham should invent such a history of [himself]142-wickham as [he]142-wickham gave [me]0-i last night ; names , facts , everything mentioned without ceremony . If it be not so , let [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy contradict it . Besides , there was truth in [his]96-mr. darcy looks . ” “[96-mr. darcy] It is difficult , indeed -- it is distressing . [One]3113-one does not know what to think . ” “[3113-one] [I]0-i beg [your]96-mr. darcy pardon -one knows exactly what to think . ” But [Jane]89-jane could think with certainty on only one point,--that [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley , if [he]85-mr. bingley had been imposed on , would have much to suffer when the affair became public . [The two young ladies]3693-the two young ladies were summoned from the shrubbery , where this conversation passed , by the arrival of [some of [the very persons of whom [they]3693-the two young ladies had been speaking]3695-the very persons of whom they had been speaking]3694-some of the very persons of whom they had been speaking ; [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley and [[his]85-mr. bingley sisters]284-his sisters came to give [their]3693-the two young ladies personal invitation for the long expected ball at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , which was fixed for the following Tuesday . [The two ladies]505-the two ladies were delighted to see [[their]505-the two ladies dear friend]520-their dear friend again , called it an age since [they]505-the two ladies had met , and repeatedly asked what [she]520-their dear friend had been doing with [herself]520-their dear friend since [their]505-the two ladies separation . To [the rest of [the family]414-the family]3699-the rest of the family [they]505-the two ladies paid little attention ; avoiding [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet as much as possible , saying not much to [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , and nothing at all to [the others]511-the others . [They]505-the two ladies were soon gone again , rising from [their]505-the two ladies seats with an activity which took [[their]505-the two ladies brother]338-their brother by surprise , and hurrying off as if eager to escape from [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet ’s civilities . The prospect of the [Netherfield]2-netherfield ball was extremely agreeable to [every female of [the family]414-the family]3703-every female of the family . [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet chose to consider it as given in compliment to [[her]92-mrs. bennet eldest daughter]313-her eldest daughter , and was particularly flattered by receiving the invitation from [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley [himself]85-mr. bingley , instead of a ceremonious card . [Jane]89-jane pictured to [herself]89-jane a happy evening in the society of [[her]89-jane two friends]615-her two friends , and the attentions of [[their]505-the two ladies brother]338-their brother ; and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth thought with pleasure of dancing a great deal with [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham , and of seeing a confirmation of everything in [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s look and behaviour . The happiness anticipated by [Catherine]93-lady catherine and [Lydia]90-lydia depended less on any single event , or [any particular person]3708-any particular person ; for though [they]505-the two ladies each , like [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , meant to dance half the evening with [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham , [he]142-wickham was by no means [the only partner who could satisfy [them]505-the two ladies]3709-the only partner who could satisfy them , and a ball was , at any rate , a ball . And even [Mary]94-mary could assure [[her]94-mary family]3710-her family that [she]94-mary had no disinclination for it . “[3113-one] While [I]0-i can have [my]0-i mornings to [myself]0-i , ” said [she]88-elizabeth , “[3113-one] it is enough . [I]0-i think it is no sacrifice to join occasionally in evening engagements . [Society]148-society has claims on [us]846-us all ; and [I]0-i profess [myself]0-i one of those who consider intervals of recreation and amusement as desirable for [everybody]305-everybody . ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s spirits were so high on the occasion , that though [she]88-elizabeth did not often speak unnecessarily to [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , [she]88-elizabeth could not help asking [him]134-mr. collins whether [he]134-mr. collins intended to accept [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley ’s invitation , and if [he]134-mr. collins did , whether [he]134-mr. collins would think it proper to join in the evening ’s amusement ; and [she]88-elizabeth was rather surprised to find that [he]134-mr. collins entertained no scruple whatever on that head , and was very far from dreading a rebuke , either from [the Archbishop]3711-the archbishop or [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]93-lady catherine , by venturing to dance . “[0-i] [I]0-i am by no means of opinion , [I]0-i assure [you]848-you , ” said [he]0-i , “[0-i] that a ball of this kind , given by [a young man of character]849-a young man of character , to [respectable people]850-respectable people , can have any evil tendency ; and [I]0-i am so far from objecting to dancing [myself]0-i , that [I]0-i shall hope to be honoured with the hands of all [[my]0-i fair cousins]686-my fair cousins in the course of the evening ; and [I]0-i take this opportunity of soliciting [yours]848-you , [Miss Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , for the two first dances especially ; a preference which [I]0-i trust [[my]0-i cousin]3477-my cousin [Jane]89-jane will attribute to the right cause , and not to any disrespect for [her]89-jane . ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth felt [herself]88-elizabeth completely taken in .
