[She]88-elizabeth had fully proposed being engaged by [Wickham]142-wickham for those very dances ; and to have [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins instead -her liveliness had been never worse timed . There was no help for it , however . [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham ’s happiness and [her]88-elizabeth own was perforce delayed a little longer , and [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins ’s proposal accepted with as good a grace as [she]88-elizabeth could . [She]88-elizabeth was not the better pleased with [his]134-mr. collins gallantry , from the idea it suggested of something more . It now first struck [her]88-elizabeth , that [she]88-elizabeth was selected from among [[her]88-elizabeth sisters]3096-her sisters as worthy of being [the mistress of [Hunsford Parsonage]3714-hunsford parsonage]3713-the mistress of hunsford parsonage , and of assisting to form a quadrille table at [Rosings]18-rosings , in the absence of [more eligible visitors]3715-more eligible visitors . The idea soon reached to conviction , as [she]88-elizabeth observed [his]134-mr. collins increasing civilities towards [herself]88-elizabeth , and heard [his]134-mr. collins frequent attempt at a compliment on [her]88-elizabeth wit and vivacity ; and though more astonished than gratified [herself]88-elizabeth by this effect of [her]88-elizabeth charms , it was not long before [[her]88-elizabeth mother]246-her mother gave [her]88-elizabeth to understand that the probability of [their]3717-their marriage was exceedingly agreeable to [her]88-elizabeth . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , however , did not choose to take the hint , being well aware that a serious dispute must be the consequence of any reply . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins might never make the offer , and , till [he]134-mr. collins did , it was useless to quarrel about [him]134-mr. collins . If there had not been a Netherfield ball to prepare for and talk of , [the younger Miss Bennets]105-the bennets would have been in a pitiable state at this time ; for , from the day of the invitation to the day of the ball , there was such a succession of rain as prevented [their]3717-their walking to [Meryton]9-meryton once . [No aunt]3718-no aunt , [no officers]3719-no officers , no news could be sought after ; the very shoe - roses for [Netherfield]2-netherfield were got by proxy . Even [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth might have found some trial of [her]88-elizabeth patience in weather which totally suspended the improvement of [her]88-elizabeth acquaintance with [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham ; and nothing less than a dance on Tuesday could have made such a Friday , Saturday , Sunday , and Monday endurable to [Kitty]93-lady catherine and [Lydia]90-lydia . [ Illustration ] CHAPTER XVIII . [ Illustration ] Till [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth entered [the drawing - room at [Netherfield]2-netherfield]3720-the drawing - room at netherfield , and looked in vain for [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham among the cluster of red coats there assembled , a doubt of [his]142-wickham being present had never occurred to [her]88-elizabeth . The certainty of meeting [him]142-wickham had not been checked by any of those recollections that might not unreasonably have alarmed [her]88-elizabeth . [She]88-elizabeth had dressed with more than usual care , and prepared in the highest spirits for the conquest of all that remained unsubdued of [his]142-wickham heart , trusting that it was not more than might be won in the course of the evening . But in an instant arose the dreadful suspicion of [his]142-wickham being purposely omitted , for [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s pleasure , in the Bingleys ’ invitation to [the officers]452-the officers ; and though this was not exactly the case , the absolute fact of [his]142-wickham absence was pronounced by [[his]142-wickham friend]288-his friend [Mr. Denny]141-denny , to whom [Lydia]90-lydia eagerly applied , and who told [them]452-the officers that [Wickham]142-wickham had been obliged to go to [town]268-town on business the day before , and was not yet returned ; adding , with a significant smile,-- “[0-i] [I]0-i do not imagine [his]853-his business would have called [him]853-his away just now , if [he]853-his had not wished to avoid [a certain gentleman]854-a certain gentleman [here]3067-here . ” This part of [his]142-wickham intelligence , though unheard by [Lydia]90-lydia , was caught by [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ; and , as it assured [her]88-elizabeth that [Darcy]96-mr. darcy was not less answerable for [Wickham]142-wickham ’s absence than if [her]88-elizabeth first surmise had been just , every feeling of displeasure against [the former]327-the former was so sharpened by immediate disappointment , that [she]88-elizabeth could hardly reply with tolerable civility to the polite inquiries which [he]142-wickham directly afterwards approached to make . Attention , forbearance , patience with [Darcy]96-mr. darcy , was injury to [Wickham]142-wickham . [She]88-elizabeth was resolved against any sort of conversation with [him]142-wickham , and turned away with a degree of ill - humour which [she]88-elizabeth could not wholly surmount even in speaking to [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley , whose blind partiality provoked [her]88-elizabeth . But [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was not formed for ill - humour ; and though every prospect of [her]88-elizabeth own was destroyed for the evening , it could not dwell long on [her]88-elizabeth spirits ; and , having told all [her]88-elizabeth griefs to [Charlotte Lucas]107-charlotte , whom [she]88-elizabeth had not seen for a week , [she]88-elizabeth was soon able to make a voluntary transition to the oddities of [[her]88-elizabeth cousin]821-her cousin , and to point [him]142-wickham out to [her]88-elizabeth particular notice . The two first dances , however , brought a return of distress : they were dances of mortification . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , awkward and solemn , apologizing instead of attending , and often moving wrong without being aware of it , gave [her]88-elizabeth all the shame and misery which [a disagreeable partner for a couple of dances]3726-a disagreeable partner for a couple of dances can give . The moment of [her]88-elizabeth release from [him]142-wickham was ecstasy . [She]88-elizabeth danced next with [an officer]3727-an officer , and had the refreshment of talking of [Wickham]142-wickham , and of hearing that [he]142-wickham was universally liked . When those dances were over , [she]88-elizabeth returned to [Charlotte Lucas]107-charlotte , and was in conversation with [her]107-charlotte , when [she]88-elizabeth found [herself]88-elizabeth suddenly addressed by [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , who took [her]88-elizabeth so much by surprise in [his]96-mr. darcy application for [her]88-elizabeth hand , that , without knowing what [she]88-elizabeth did , [she]88-elizabeth accepted [him]96-mr. darcy . [He]96-mr. darcy walked away again immediately , and [she]88-elizabeth was left to fret over [her]88-elizabeth own want of presence of mind : [Charlotte]107-charlotte tried to console [her]88-elizabeth . “[0-i] [I]0-i dare say [you]0-i will find [him]856-him very agreeable . ” “[0-i] Heaven forbid ! That would be the greatest misfortune of all ! To find [a man agreeable whom [one]3113-one is determined to hate]857-a man agreeable whom one is determined to hate ! Do not wish [me]0-i such an evil . ” When the dancing recommenced , however , and [Darcy]96-mr. darcy approached to claim [her]88-elizabeth hand , [Charlotte]107-charlotte could not help cautioning [her]88-elizabeth , in a whisper , not to be [a simpleton]3212-a simpleton , and allow [her]88-elizabeth fancy for [Wickham]142-wickham to make [her]88-elizabeth appear unpleasant in the eyes of [a man often times [his]856-him consequence]3729-a man often times his consequence . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth made no answer , and took [her]88-elizabeth place in the set , amazed at the dignity to which [she]88-elizabeth was arrived in being allowed to stand opposite to [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , and reading in [[her]88-elizabeth neighbours]3652-her neighbours ’ looks [their]3652-her neighbours equal amazement in beholding it . [They]3731-they stood for some time without speaking a word ; and [she]88-elizabeth began to imagine that [their]3731-they silence was to last through the two dances , and , at first , was resolved not to break it ; till suddenly fancying that it would be the greater punishment to [[her]88-elizabeth partner]3732-her partner to oblige [him]859-you to talk , [she]88-elizabeth made some slight observation on the dance . [He]859-you replied , and was again silent . After a pause of some minutes , [she]88-elizabeth addressed [him]859-you a second time , with-- “[859-you] It is [your]859-you turn to say something now , [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy . [I]0-i talked about the dance , and [you]859-you ought to make some kind of remark on the size of [the room]255-the room , or the number of [couples]861-couples . ” [He]859-you smiled , and assured [her]88-elizabeth that whatever [she]88-elizabeth wished [him]859-you to say should be said . “[859-you] Very well ; that reply will do for the present . Perhaps , by - and - by , [I]0-i may observe that private balls are much pleasanter than public ones ; but now [we]862-we may be silent . ” “[859-you] Do [you]859-you talk by rule , then , while [you]859-you are dancing ? ” “[859-you] Sometimes . [One]3113-one must speak a little , [you]859-you know . It would look odd to be entirely silent for half an hour together ; and yet , for the advantage of some , conversation ought to be so arranged as that [they]864-they may have the trouble of saying as little as possible . ” “[859-you] Are [you]859-you consulting [your]859-you own feelings in the present case , or do [you]859-you imagine that [you]859-you are gratifying [mine]0-i ? ” “[859-you] Both , ” replied [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth archly ; “[859-you] for [I]0-i have always seen a great similarity in the turn of [our]862-we minds . [We]862-we are each of an unsocial , taciturn disposition , unwilling to speak , unless [we]862-we expect to say something that will amaze [the whole room]865-the whole room , and be handed down to posterity with all the éclat of a proverb . ” “[0-i] This is no very striking resemblance of [your]0-i own character , [I]0-i am sure , ” said [he]0-i . “[0-i] How near it may be to [mine]0-i , [I]0-i can not pretend to say . [You]0-i think it a faithful portrait , undoubtedly . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i must not decide on [my]0-i own performance . ” [He]0-i made no answer ; and [they]866-they were again silent till [they]866-they had gone down the dance , when [he]0-i asked [her]3733-her if [she]3733-her and [[her]3733-her sisters]3096-her sisters did not very often walk to [Meryton]9-meryton . [She]3733-her answered in the affirmative ; and , unable to resist the temptation , added , “[0-i] When [you]0-i met [us]866-they [there]306-there the other day , [we]866-they had just been forming [a new acquaintance]868-a new acquaintance . ” The effect was immediate . A deeper shade of hauteur overspread [his]0-i features , but [he]0-i said not a word ; and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , though blaming [herself]88-elizabeth for [her]88-elizabeth own weakness , could not go on . At length [Darcy]96-mr. darcy spoke , and in a constrained manner said,-- “[868-a new acquaintance] [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham is blessed with such happy manners as may insure [his]142-wickham making friends ; whether [he]142-wickham may be equally capable of retaining [them]869-them , is less certain . ” “[142-wickham] [He]142-wickham has been so unlucky as to lose [your]0-i friendship , ” replied [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , with emphasis , “[142-wickham] and in a manner which [he]142-wickham is likely to suffer from all [his]142-wickham life . ” [Darcy]96-mr. darcy made no answer , and seemed desirous of changing the subject . At that moment [Sir William Lucas]86-sir william appeared close to [them]3735-them , meaning to pass through the set to the other side of [the room]255-the room ; but , on perceiving [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , [he]86-sir william stopped , with a bow of superior courtesy , to compliment [him]86-sir william on [his]86-sir william dancing and [[his]86-sir william partner]3737-his partner . “[0-i] [I]0-i have been most highly gratified , indeed , [[my]0-i dear [sir]3234-sir]870-my dear sir ; such very superior dancing is not often seen . It is evident that [you]3234-sir belong to [the first circles]872-the first circles . Allow [me]0-i to say , however , that [[your]3234-sir fair partner]873-your fair partner does not disgrace [you]3234-sir : and that [I]0-i must hope to have this pleasure often repeated , especially when a certain desirable event , [[my]0-i dear]3066-my dear [Miss Eliza]88-elizabeth ( glancing at [[her]88-elizabeth sister]328-her sister and [Bingley]85-mr. bingley ) , shall take place . What congratulations will then flow in ! [I]0-i appeal to [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy -but let [me]0-i not interrupt [you]3234-sir , [sir]3234-sir . [You]3234-sir will not thank [me]0-i for detaining [you]3234-sir from the bewitching converse of [that young lady , whose bright eyes]877-that young lady , whose bright eyes are also upbraiding [me]0-i . ” [ Illustration : “[877-that young lady , whose bright eyes] Such very superior dancing is not often seen . ” The latter part of this address was scarcely heard by [Darcy]96-mr. darcy ; but [Sir William]86-sir william ’s allusion to [[his]86-sir william friend]288-his friend seemed to strike [him]86-sir william forcibly , and [his]86-sir william eyes were directed , with a very serious expression , towards [Bingley]85-mr. bingley and [Jane]89-jane , who were dancing together . Recovering [himself]86-sir william , however , shortly , [he]86-sir william turned to [[his]86-sir william partner]3737-his partner , and said,-- “[86-sir william] [Sir William]86-sir william ’s interruption has made [me]0-i forget what [we]878-we were talking of . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do not think [we]878-we were speaking at all . [Sir William]86-sir william could not have interrupted [any two people in [the room]255-the room who had less to say for [themselves]879-any two people in the room who had less to say for themselves]879-any two people in the room who had less to say for themselves . [We]878-we have tried two or three subjects already without success , and what [we]878-we are to talk of next [I]0-i can not imagine . ” “[0-i] What think [you]0-i of books ? ” said [he]0-i , smiling . “[0-i] Books -- oh no -I am sure [we]878-we never read the same , or not with the same feelings . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am sorry [you]0-i think so ; but if that be the case , there can at least be no want of subject . [We]878-we may compare [our]878-we different opinions . ” “[0-i] No -- [I]0-i can not talk of books in [a ball - room]881-a ball - room ; [my]0-i head is always full of something else . ” “[0-i] The present always occupies [you]0-i in such scenes -- does it ? ” said [he]0-i , with a look of doubt . “[0-i] Yes , always , ” [she]3740-she replied , without knowing what [she]3740-she said ; for [her]3740-she thoughts had wandered far from the subject , as soon afterwards appeared by [her]3740-she suddenly exclaiming , “[0-i] [I]0-i remember hearing [you]0-i once say , [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , that [you]0-i hardly ever forgave -that [your]0-i resentment , once created , was unappeasable . [You]0-i are very cautious , [I]0-i suppose , as to its being created ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am , ” said [he]0-i , with a firm voice . “[0-i] And never allow [yourself]0-i to be blinded by prejudice ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i hope not . ” “[0-i] It is particularly incumbent on those who never change [their]882-their opinion , to be secure of judging properly at first . ” “[0-i] May [I]0-i ask to what these questions tend ? ” “[0-i] Merely to the illustration of [your]0-i character , ” said [she]3741-her , endeavouring to shake off [her]3741-her gravity . “[0-i] [I]0-i am trying to make it out . ” “[0-i] And what is [your]0-i success ? ” [She]3741-her shook [her]3741-her head . “[0-i] [I]0-i do not get on at all . [I]0-i hear such different accounts of [you]0-i as puzzle [me]0-i exceedingly . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i can readily believe , ” answered [he]0-i , gravely , “[0-i] that reports may vary greatly with respect to [me]0-i ; and [I]0-i could wish , [Miss Bennet]88-elizabeth , that [you]88-elizabeth were not to sketch [my]0-i character at the present moment , as there is reason to fear that the performance would reflect no credit on either . ” “[88-elizabeth] But if [I]0-i do not take [your]88-elizabeth likeness now , [I]0-i may never have another opportunity . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i would by no means suspend any pleasure of [yours]88-elizabeth , ” [he]0-i coldly replied . [She]3741-her said no more , and [they]3742-they went down the other dance and parted in silence ; on each side dissatisfied , though not to an equal degree ; for in [Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s breast there was a tolerably powerful feeling towards [her]3741-her , which soon procured [her]3741-her pardon , and directed all [his]0-i anger against another . [They]3742-they had not long separated when [Miss Bingley]98-miss bingley came towards [her]3741-her , and , with an expression of civil disdain , thus accosted [her,--]96-mr. darcy “[0-i] So , [Miss Eliza]88-elizabeth , [I]0-i hear [you]88-elizabeth are quite delighted with [George Wickham]149-george wickham ? [[Your]88-elizabeth sister]3211-your sister has been talking to [me]0-i about [him]149-george wickham , and asking [me]0-i a thousand questions ; and [I]0-i find that [the young man]3597-the young man forgot to tell [you]88-elizabeth , among [his]3597-the young man other communications , that [he]3597-the young man was [the son of [old Wickham]149-george wickham]885-the son of old wickham , [[the late Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s steward]886-the late mr. darcy ’s steward . Let [me]0-i recommend [you]88-elizabeth , however , as [a friend]3228-a friend , not to give implicit confidence to all [his]149-george wickham assertions ; for , as to [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s using [him]149-george wickham ill , it is perfectly false : for , on the contrary , [he]96-mr. darcy has been always remarkably kind to [him]149-george wickham , though [George Wickham]149-george wickham has treated [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy in a most infamous manner . [I]0-i do not know the particulars , but [I]0-i know very well that [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy is not in the least to blame ; that [he]96-mr. darcy can not bear to hear [George Wickham]149-george wickham mentioned ; and that though [[my]0-i brother]465-my brother thought [he]465-my brother could not well avoid including [him]96-mr. darcy in [his]465-my brother invitation to [the officers]452-the officers , [he]465-my brother was excessively glad to find that [he]96-mr. darcy had taken [himself]96-mr. darcy out of the way . [His]96-mr. darcy coming into [the country]448-the country at all is a most insolent thing , indeed , and [I]0-i wonder how [he]96-mr. darcy could presume to do it . [I]0-i pity [you]891-you , [Miss Eliza]88-elizabeth , for this discovery of [[your]891-you favourite]892-your favourite ’s guilt ; but really , considering [his]96-mr. darcy descent , one could not expect much better . ” “[96-mr. darcy] [His]96-mr. darcy guilt and [his]96-mr. darcy descent appear , by [your]891-you account , to be the same , ” said [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , angrily ; “[891-you] for [I]0-i have heard [you]891-you accuse [him]96-mr. darcy of nothing worse than of being [the son of [[Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s steward]894-mr. darcy ’s steward]893-the son of mr. darcy ’s steward , and of that , [I]0-i can assure [you]891-you , [he]96-mr. darcy informed [me]0-i [himself]96-mr. darcy . ” “[96-mr. darcy] [I]0-i beg [your]891-you pardon , ” replied [Miss Bingley]98-miss bingley , turning away with a sneer . “[96-mr. darcy] Excuse [my]0-i interference ; it was kindly meant . ” “[895-insolent girl] [Insolent girl]895-insolent girl ! ” said [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth to [herself]88-elizabeth . “[895-insolent girl] [You]891-you are much mistaken if [you]891-you expect to influence [me]0-i by such a paltry attack as this . [I]0-i see nothing in it but [your]891-you own wilful ignorance and the malice of [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy . ” [She]88-elizabeth then sought [[her]88-elizabeth eldest sister]3743-her eldest sister , who had undertaken to make inquiries on the same subject of [Bingley]98-miss bingley . [Jane]89-jane met [her]89-jane with a smile of such sweet complacency , a glow of such happy expression , as sufficiently marked how well [she]89-jane was satisfied with the occurrences of the evening . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth instantly read [her]89-jane feelings ; and , at that moment , solicitude for [Wickham]149-george wickham , resentment against [[his]149-george wickham enemies]3744-his enemies , and everything else , gave way before the hope of [Jane]89-jane ’s being in the fairest way for happiness . “[96-mr. darcy] [I]0-i want to know , ” said [she]89-jane , with a countenance no less smiling than [[her]89-jane sister]328-her sister ’s , “[0-i] what [you]891-you have learnt about [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham . But perhaps [you]891-you have been too pleasantly engaged to think of [any third person]896-any third person , in which case [you]891-you may be sure of [my]0-i pardon . ” “[891-you] No , ” replied [Jane]89-jane , “[891-you] [I]0-i have not forgotten [him]142-wickham ; but [I]0-i have nothing satisfactory to tell [you]891-you . [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley does not know the whole of [his]85-mr. bingley history , and is quite ignorant of the circumstances which have principally offended [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ; but [he]85-mr. bingley will vouch for the good conduct , the probity and honour , of [[his]85-mr. bingley friend]288-his friend , and is perfectly convinced that [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham has deserved much less attention from [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy than [he]85-mr. bingley has received ; and [I]0-i am sorry to say that by [his]85-mr. bingley account , as well as [[his]85-mr. bingley sister]565-his sister ’s , [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham is by no means [a respectable young man]899-a respectable young man . [I]0-i am afraid [he]142-wickham has been very imprudent , and has deserved to lose [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s regard . ” “[85-mr. bingley] [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley does not know [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham [himself]85-mr. bingley . ” “[85-mr. bingley] No ; [he]85-mr. bingley never saw [him]142-wickham till the other morning at [Meryton]9-meryton . ” “[85-mr. bingley] This account then is what [he]85-mr. bingley has received from [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy . [I]0-i am perfectly satisfied . But what does [he]85-mr. bingley say of [the living]900-the living ? ” “[85-mr. bingley] [He]85-mr. bingley does not exactly recollect the circumstances , though [he]85-mr. bingley has heard them from [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy more than once , but [he]85-mr. bingley believes that it was left to [him]85-mr. bingley conditionally only . ” “[85-mr. bingley] [I]0-i have not a doubt of [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley ’s sincerity , ” said [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth warmly , “[0-i] but [you]901-you must excuse [my]0-i not being convinced by assurances only . [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley ’s defence of [[his]85-mr. bingley friend]288-his friend was a very able one , [I]0-i dare say ; but since [he]85-mr. bingley is unacquainted with several parts of the story , and has learnt the rest from [that friend]903-that friend [himself]85-mr. bingley , [I]0-i shall venture still to think of [both gentlemen]904-both gentlemen as [I]0-i did before . ” [She]88-elizabeth then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each , and on which there could be no difference of sentiment . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth listened with delight to the happy though modest hopes which [Jane]89-jane entertained of [Bingley]85-mr. bingley ’s regard , and said all in [her]88-elizabeth power to heighten [her]88-elizabeth confidence in it . On [their]904-both gentlemen being joined by [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley [himself]85-mr. bingley , [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth withdrew to [Miss Lucas]99-miss lucas ; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of [[her]88-elizabeth last partner]3746-her last partner [she]88-elizabeth had scarcely replied , before [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins came up to [them]904-both gentlemen , and told [her]88-elizabeth with great exultation , that [he]0-i had just been so fortunate as to make a most important discovery . “[0-i] [I]0-i have found out , ” said [he]0-i , “[287-the gentleman] by a singular accident , that there is now in [the room]255-the room a near relation to [[my]0-i patroness]906-my patroness . [I]0-i happened to overhear [the gentleman]287-the gentleman [himself]287-the gentleman mentioning to [the young lady who does the honours of [this house]3479-this house]908-the young lady who does the honours of this house the names of [[his]287-the gentleman cousin]3538-his cousin [Miss De Bourgh]138-miss de bourgh , and of [[her]908-the young lady who does the honours of this house mother]246-her mother , [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine . How wonderfully these sort of things occur ! Who would have thought of [my]0-i meeting with -- perhaps -- [a nephew of [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]93-lady catherine in this assembly]912-a nephew of lady catherine de bourgh in this assembly ! [I]0-i am most thankful that the discovery is made in time for [me]0-i to pay [my]0-i respects to [him]287-the gentleman , which [I]0-i am now going to do , and trust [he]287-the gentleman will excuse [my]0-i not having done it before . [My]0-i total ignorance of the connection must plead [my]0-i apology . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i are not going to introduce [yourself]0-i to [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ? ” “[0-i] Indeed [I]0-i am . [I]0-i shall entreat [his]287-the gentleman pardon for not having done it earlier . [I]0-i believe [him]287-the gentleman to be [[Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine ’s nephew]913-lady catherine ’s nephew . It will be in [my]0-i power to assure [him]287-the gentleman that [[her]93-lady catherine Ladyship]3490-her ladyship was quite well yesterday se’nnight . ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth tried hard to dissuade [him]287-the gentleman from such a scheme ; assuring [him]287-the gentleman that [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy would consider [his]287-the gentleman addressing [him]287-the gentleman without introduction as an impertinent freedom , rather than a compliment to [[his]287-the gentleman aunt]3747-his aunt ; that it was not in the least necessary there should be any notice on either side , and that if it were , it must belong to [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , [the superior]3748-the superior in consequence , to begin the acquaintance . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins listened to [her]88-elizabeth with the determined air of following [his]134-mr. collins own inclination , and when [she]88-elizabeth ceased speaking , replied thus,-- “[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]3066-my dear [Miss Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , [I]0-i have the highest opinion in [the world]304-the world of [your]88-elizabeth excellent judgment in all matters within the scope of [your]88-elizabeth understanding , but permit [me]0-i to say that there must be a wide difference between the established forms of ceremony amongst [the laity]917-the laity and those which regulate [the clergy]918-the clergy ; for , give [me]0-i leave to observe that [I]0-i consider the clerical office as equal in point of dignity with the highest rank in [the kingdom]919-the kingdom -- provided that a proper humility of behaviour is at the same time maintained . [You]88-elizabeth must , therefore , allow [me]0-i to follow the dictates of [my]0-i conscience on this occasion , which lead [me]0-i to perform what [I]0-i look on as a point of duty . Pardon [me]0-i for neglecting to profit by [your]88-elizabeth advice , which on every other subject shall be [my]0-i constant guide , though in the case before [us]920-us [I]0-i consider [myself]0-i more fitted by education and habitual study to decide on what is right than [a young lady like [yourself]88-elizabeth]921-a young lady like yourself ; ” and with a low bow [he]0-i left [her]88-elizabeth to attack [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , whose reception of [his]0-i advances [she]88-elizabeth eagerly watched , and whose astonishment at being so addressed was very evident . [[Her]88-elizabeth cousin]821-her cousin prefaced [his]821-her cousin speech with a solemn bow , and though [she]88-elizabeth could not hear a word of it , [she]88-elizabeth felt as if hearing it all , and saw in the motion of [his]821-her cousin lips the words “[88-elizabeth] apology , ” “[15-hunsford] [Hunsford]15-hunsford , ” and “[15-hunsford] [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]93-lady catherine . ” It vexed [her]88-elizabeth to see [him]821-her cousin expose [himself]821-her cousin to [such a man]230-such a man . [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy was eyeing [him]821-her cousin with unrestrained wonder ; and when at last [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins allowed [him]821-her cousin to speak , replied with an air of distant civility . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , however , was not discouraged from speaking again , and [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s contempt seemed abundantly increasing with the length of [his]821-her cousin second speech ; and at the end of it [he]821-her cousin only made [him]96-mr. darcy a slight bow , and moved another way : [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins then returned to [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth . “[0-i] [I]0-i have no reason , [I]0-i assure [you]922-you , ” said [he]0-i , “[0-i] to be dissatisfied with [my]0-i reception . [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy seemed much pleased with the attention . [He]96-mr. darcy answered [me]0-i with the utmost civility , and even paid [me]0-i the compliment of saying , that [he]96-mr. darcy was so well convinced of [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine ’s discernment as to be certain [she]93-lady catherine could never bestow a favour unworthily . It was really a very handsome thought . Upon the whole , [I]0-i am much pleased with [him]96-mr. darcy . ” As [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth had no longer any interest of [her]88-elizabeth own to pursue , [she]88-elizabeth turned [her]88-elizabeth attention almost entirely on [[her]88-elizabeth sister]328-her sister and [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley ; and the train of agreeable reflections which [her]88-elizabeth observations gave birth to made [her]88-elizabeth perhaps almost as happy as [Jane]89-jane . [She]88-elizabeth saw [her]89-jane in idea settled in [that very house]3752-that very house , in all the felicity which a marriage of true affection could bestow ; and [she]88-elizabeth felt capable , under such circumstances , of endeavouring even to like [[Bingley]85-mr. bingley ’s two sisters]3753-bingley ’s two sisters . [[Her]88-elizabeth mother]246-her mother ’s thoughts [she]88-elizabeth plainly saw were bent the same way , and [she]88-elizabeth determined not to venture near [her]246-her mother , lest [she]88-elizabeth might hear too much . When [they]3753-bingley ’s two sisters sat down to supper , therefore , [she]88-elizabeth considered it a most unlucky perverseness which placed [them]3753-bingley ’s two sisters within one of [each other]3216-each other ; and deeply was [she]88-elizabeth vexed to find that [[her]88-elizabeth mother]246-her mother was talking to [that one person]3757-that one person ( [Lady Lucas]87-lady lucas ) freely , openly , and of nothing else but of [her]246-her mother expectation that [Jane]89-jane would be soon married to [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley . It was an animating subject , and [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet seemed incapable of fatigue while enumerating the advantages of the match . [His]85-mr. bingley being such [a charming young man]3758-a charming young man , and so rich , and living but three miles from [them]3753-bingley ’s two sisters , were the first points of self - gratulation ; and then it was such a comfort to think how fond [the two sisters]3759-the two sisters were of [Jane]89-jane , and to be certain that [they]3759-the two sisters must desire the connection as much as [she]88-elizabeth could do . It was , moreover , such a promising thing for [[her]246-her mother younger daughters]727-her younger daughters , as [Jane]89-jane ’s marrying so greatly must throw [them]727-her younger daughters in the way of [other rich men]3761-other rich men ; and , lastly , it was so pleasant at [her]246-her mother time of life to be able to consign [[her]246-her mother single daughters]3762-her single daughters to the care of [[their]3762-her single daughters sister]3763-their sister , that [she]246-her mother might not be obliged to go into company more than [she]246-her mother liked . It was necessary to make this circumstance a matter of pleasure , because on such occasions it is the etiquette ; but [no one]3336-no one was less likely than [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet to find comfort in staying at [home]3288-home at any period of [her]246-her mother life . [She]246-her mother concluded with many good wishes that [Lady Lucas]87-lady lucas might soon be equally fortunate , though evidently and triumphantly believing there was no chance of it . In vain did [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth endeavour to check the rapidity of [[her]88-elizabeth mother]246-her mother ’s words , or persuade [her]246-her mother to describe [her]246-her mother felicity in a less audible whisper ; for to [her]88-elizabeth inexpressible vexation [she]88-elizabeth could perceive that [the chief of it]3767-the chief of it was overheard by [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , who sat opposite to [them]923-them . [[Her]88-elizabeth mother]246-her mother only scolded [her]88-elizabeth for being nonsensical . “[0-i] What is [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy to [me]0-i , pray , that [I]0-i should be afraid of [him]96-mr. darcy ? [I]0-i am sure [we]923-them owe [him]96-mr. darcy no such particular civility as to be obliged to say nothing [he]96-mr. darcy may not like to hear . ” “[0-i] For heaven ’s sake , [madam]3346-madam , speak lower . What advantage can it be to [you]3346-madam to offend [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ? [You]3346-madam will never recommend [yourself]3346-madam to [[his]96-mr. darcy friend]288-his friend by so doing . ” Nothing that [she]88-elizabeth could say , however , had any influence . [[Her]88-elizabeth mother]246-her mother would talk of [her]246-her mother views in the same intelligible tone . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth blushed and blushed again with shame and vexation . [She]88-elizabeth could not help frequently glancing [her]88-elizabeth eye at [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , though every glance convinced [her]88-elizabeth of what [she]88-elizabeth dreaded ; for though [he]96-mr. darcy was not always looking at [[her]88-elizabeth mother]246-her mother , [she]88-elizabeth was convinced that [his]96-mr. darcy attention was invariably fixed by [her]88-elizabeth . The expression of [his]96-mr. darcy face changed gradually from indignant contempt to a composed and steady gravity . At length , however , [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet had no more to say ; and [Lady Lucas]87-lady lucas , who had been long yawning at the repetition of delights which [she]87-lady lucas saw no likelihood of sharing , was left to the comforts of cold ham and chicken . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth now began to revive . But not long was the interval of tranquillity ; for when supper was over , singing was talked of , and [she]88-elizabeth had the mortification of seeing [Mary]94-mary , after very little entreaty , preparing to oblige [the company]3771-the company . By many significant looks and silent entreaties did [she]88-elizabeth endeavour to prevent such a proof of complaisance,--but in vain ; [Mary]94-mary would not understand [them]3772-them ; such an opportunity of exhibiting was delightful to [her]88-elizabeth , and [she]88-elizabeth began [her]88-elizabeth song . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s eyes were fixed on [her]88-elizabeth , with most painful sensations ; and [she]88-elizabeth watched [her]88-elizabeth progress through the several stanzas with an impatience which was very ill rewarded at [their]3772-them close ; for [Mary]94-mary , on receiving amongst the thanks of the table the hint of a hope that [she]94-mary might be prevailed on to favour [them]3772-them again , after the pause of half a minute began another . [Mary]94-mary ’s powers were by no means fitted for such a display ; [her]94-mary voice was weak , and [her]94-mary manner affected . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was in agonies . [She]88-elizabeth looked at [Jane]89-jane to see how [she]88-elizabeth bore it ; but [Jane]89-jane was very composedly talking to [Bingley]85-mr. bingley . [She]88-elizabeth looked at [[his]85-mr. bingley two sisters]281-his two sisters , and saw [them]281-his two sisters making signs of derision at [each other]3216-each other , and at [Darcy]96-mr. darcy , who continued , however , impenetrably grave . [She]88-elizabeth looked at [[her]88-elizabeth father]249-her father to entreat [his]249-her father interference , lest [Mary]94-mary should be singing all night . [He]249-her father took the hint , and , when [Mary]94-mary had finished [her]94-mary second song , said aloud,-- “[3346-madam] That will do extremely well , [child]926-child . [You]926-child have delighted [us]927-us long enough . Let [the other young ladies]928-the other young ladies have time to exhibit . ” [Mary]94-mary , though pretending not to hear , was somewhat disconcerted ; and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , sorry for [her]94-mary , and sorry for [[her]88-elizabeth father]249-her father ’s speech , was afraid [her]88-elizabeth anxiety had done no good . [Others of the party]3777-others of the party were now applied to . “[928-the other young ladies] If [I]0-i , ” said [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , “[928-the other young ladies] were so fortunate as to be able to sing , [I]0-i should have great pleasure , [I]0-i am sure , in obliging [the company]3771-the company with an air ; for [I]0-i consider music as a very innocent diversion , and perfectly compatible with the profession of [a clergyman]3492-a clergyman . [I]0-i do not mean , however , to assert that [we]927-us can be justified in devoting too much of [our]927-us time to music , for there are certainly other things to be attended to . [The rector of [a parish]932-a parish]931-the rector of a parish has much to do . In the first place , [he]931-the rector of a parish must make such an agreement for tithes as may be beneficial to [himself]931-the rector of a parish and not offensive to [[his]931-the rector of a parish patron]933-his patron . [He]931-the rector of a parish must write [his]931-the rector of a parish own sermons ; and the time that remains will not be too much for [his]931-the rector of a parish parish duties , and the care and improvement of [[his]931-the rector of a parish dwelling]934-his dwelling , which [he]931-the rector of a parish can not be excused from making as comfortable as possible . And [I]0-i do not think it of light importance that [he]931-the rector of a parish should have attentive and conciliatory manners towards [everybody]305-everybody , especially towards those to whom [he]931-the rector of a parish owes [his]931-the rector of a parish preferment . [I]0-i can not acquit [him]931-the rector of a parish of that duty ; nor could [I]0-i think well of [the man who should omit an occasion of]936-the man who should omit an occasion of testifying [his]931-the rector of a parish respect towards anybody connected with [the family]414-the family . ” And with a bow to [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , [he]931-the rector of a parish concluded [his]931-the rector of a parish speech , which had been spoken so loud as to be heard by half [the room]255-the room . [Many]3779-many stared -- [many]3779-many smiled ; but [no one]3336-no one looked more amused than [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet [himself]81-mr. bennet , while [[his]81-mr. bennet wife]236-his wife seriously commended [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins for having spoken so sensibly , and observed , in a half - whisper to [Lady Lucas]87-lady lucas , that [he]931-the rector of a parish was [a remarkably clever , good kind of young man]3783-a remarkably clever , good kind of young man . To [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth it appeared , that had [[her]88-elizabeth family]3710-her family made an agreement to expose [themselves]3710-her family as much as [they]3710-her family could during the evening , it would have been impossible for [them]3710-her family to play [their]3710-her family parts with more spirit , or finer success ; and happy did [she]88-elizabeth think it for [Bingley]85-mr. bingley and [[her]88-elizabeth sister]328-her sister that some of the exhibition had escaped [his]81-mr. bennet notice , and that [his]81-mr. bennet feelings were not of a sort to be much distressed by the folly which [he]81-mr. bennet must have witnessed . That [[his]81-mr. bennet two sisters]281-his two sisters and [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , however , should have such an opportunity of ridiculing [her]88-elizabeth relations was bad enough ; and [she]88-elizabeth could not determine whether the silent contempt of [the gentleman]287-the gentleman , or the insolent smiles of [the ladies]254-the ladies , were more intolerable . The rest of the evening brought [her]88-elizabeth little amusement . [She]88-elizabeth was teased by [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , who continued most perseveringly by [her]88-elizabeth side ; and though [he]134-mr. collins could not prevail with [her]88-elizabeth to dance with [him]134-mr. collins again , put it out of [her]88-elizabeth power to dance with [others]3175-others . In vain did [she]88-elizabeth entreat [him]134-mr. collins to stand up with [somebody else]3116-somebody else , and offered to introduce [him]134-mr. collins to [any young lady in [the room]255-the room]3791-any young lady in the room . [He]134-mr. collins assured [her]88-elizabeth that , as to dancing , [he]134-mr. collins was perfectly indifferent to it ; that [his]134-mr. collins chief object was , by delicate attentions , to recommend [himself]134-mr. collins to [her]88-elizabeth ; and that [he]134-mr. collins should therefore make a point of remaining close to [her]88-elizabeth the whole evening . There was no arguing upon such a project . [She]88-elizabeth owed [her]88-elizabeth greatest relief to [[her]88-elizabeth friend]400-her friend [Miss Lucas]99-miss lucas , who often joined [them]3794-their , and good - naturedly engaged [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins ’s conversation to [herself]88-elizabeth . [She]88-elizabeth was at least free from the offence of [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s further notice : though often standing within a very short distance of [her]88-elizabeth , quite disengaged , [he]96-mr. darcy never came near enough to speak . [She]88-elizabeth felt it to be the probable consequence of [her]88-elizabeth allusions to [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham , and rejoiced in it . [The Longbourn party]3795-the longbourn party were the last of all [the company]3771-the company to depart ; and by a manœuvre of [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet had to wait for [[their]3794-their carriage]3797-their carriage a quarter of an hour after [everybody else]3798-everybody else was gone , which gave [them]3794-their time to see how heartily [they]3794-their were wished away by [some of [the family]414-the family]3799-some of the family . [Mrs. Hurst]97-mrs. hurst and [[her]97-mrs. hurst sister]328-her sister scarcely opened [their]3794-their mouths except to complain of fatigue , and were evidently impatient to have [the house]3075-the house to [themselves]3794-their . [They]3794-their repulsed every attempt of [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet at conversation , and , by so doing , threw a languor over the whole party , which was very little relieved by the long speeches of [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , who was complimenting [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley and [[his]134-mr. collins sisters]284-his sisters on the elegance of [their]3794-their entertainment , and the hospitality and politeness which had marked [their]3794-their behaviour to [[their]3794-their guests]3804-their guests . [Darcy]96-mr. darcy said nothing at all . [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet , in equal silence , was enjoying the scene . [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley and [Jane]89-jane were standing together a little detached from the rest , and talked only to [each other]3216-each other . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth preserved as steady a silence as either [Mrs. Hurst]97-mrs. hurst or [Miss Bingley]98-miss bingley ; and even [Lydia]90-lydia was too much fatigued to utter more than the occasional exclamation of “[931-the rector of a parish] [Lord]938-lord , how tired [I]0-i am ! ” accompanied by a violent yawn . When at length [they]3794-their arose to take leave , [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet was most pressingly civil in [her]92-mrs. bennet hope of seeing [the whole family]312-the whole family soon at [Longbourn]7-longbourn ; and addressed [herself]92-mrs. bennet particularly to [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley , to assure [him]85-mr. bingley how happy [he]85-mr. bingley would make [them]3794-their , by eating a family dinner with [them]3794-their at any time , without the ceremony of a formal invitation . [Bingley]85-mr. bingley was all grateful pleasure ; and [he]85-mr. bingley readily engaged for taking the earliest opportunity of waiting on [her]92-mrs. bennet after [his]85-mr. bingley return from [London]5-london , whither [he]85-mr. bingley was obliged to go the next day for a short time . [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet was perfectly satisfied ; and quitted [the house]3075-the house under the delightful persuasion that , allowing for the necessary preparations of settlements , new carriages , and wedding clothes , [she]92-mrs. bennet should undoubtedly see [[her]92-mrs. bennet daughter]461-her daughter settled at [Netherfield]2-netherfield in the course of three or four months . Of having [another daughter]3809-another daughter married to [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins [she]92-mrs. bennet thought with equal certainty , and with considerable , though not equal , pleasure . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was [the least dear to [her]92-mrs. bennet of all [[her]92-mrs. bennet children]3811-her children]3810-the least dear to her of all her children ; and though [the man]3163-the man and the match were quite good enough for [her]88-elizabeth , the worth of each was eclipsed by [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley and [Netherfield]2-netherfield . [ Illustration : “[931-the rector of a parish] to assure [you]939-you in the most animated language ” ] CHAPTER XIX . [ Illustration ] The next day opened a new scene at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins made [his]134-mr. collins declaration in form . Having resolved to do it without loss of time , as [his]134-mr. collins leave of absence extended only to the following Saturday , and having no feelings of diffidence to make it distressing to [himself]134-mr. collins even at the moment , [he]134-mr. collins set about it in a very orderly manner , with all the observances which [he]134-mr. collins supposed a regular part of the business . On finding [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet , [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , and [one of [the younger girls]3435-the younger girls]3813-one of the younger girls together , soon after breakfast , [he]134-mr. collins addressed [the mother]393-the mother in these words,-- “[931-the rector of a parish] May [I]0-i hope , [madam]3346-madam , for [your]3346-madam interest with [[your]3346-madam fair daughter]941-your fair daughter [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , when [I]0-i solicit for the honour of a private audience with [her]88-elizabeth in the course of this morning ? ” Before [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth had time for anything but a blush of surprise , [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet instantly answered,-- “[0-i] Oh dear ! Yes , certainly . [I]0-i am sure [Lizzy]88-elizabeth will be very happy -- [I]0-i am sure [she]88-elizabeth can have no objection . Come , [Kitty]93-lady catherine , [I]0-i want [you]93-lady catherine [upstairs]3537-upstairs . ” And gathering [her]88-elizabeth work together , [she]88-elizabeth was hastening away , when [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth called out,-- “[93-lady catherine] [Dear ma’am]151-dear ma’am , do not go . [I]0-i beg [you]151-dear ma’am will not go . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins must excuse [me]0-i . [He]134-mr. collins can have nothing to say to [me]0-i that [anybody]3171-anybody need not hear . [I]0-i am going away [myself]0-i . ” “[0-i] No , no , nonsense , [Lizzy]88-elizabeth . [I]0-i desire [you]88-elizabeth will stay where [you]88-elizabeth are . ” And upon [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s seeming really , with vexed and embarrassed looks , about to escape , [she]88-elizabeth added , “[88-elizabeth] [Lizzy]88-elizabeth , [I]0-i insist upon [your]88-elizabeth staying and hearing [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins . ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth would not oppose such an injunction ; and a moment ’s consideration making [her]88-elizabeth also sensible that it would be wisest to get it over as soon and as quietly as possible , [she]88-elizabeth sat down again , and tried to conceal , by incessant employment , the feelings which were divided between distress and diversion . [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet and [Kitty]93-lady catherine walked off , and as soon as [they]3816-they were gone , [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins began,-- “[0-i] Believe [me]0-i , [[my]0-i dear]3066-my dear [Miss Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , that [your]88-elizabeth modesty , so far from doing [you]88-elizabeth any disservice , rather adds to [your]88-elizabeth other perfections . [You]88-elizabeth would have been less amiable in [my]0-i eyes had there not been this little unwillingness ; but allow [me]0-i to assure [you]88-elizabeth that [I]0-i have [[your]88-elizabeth respected mother]945-your respected mother ’s permission for this address . [You]88-elizabeth can hardly doubt the purport of [my]0-i discourse , however [your]88-elizabeth natural delicacy may lead [you]88-elizabeth to dissemble ; [my]0-i attentions have been too marked to be mistaken . Almost as soon as [I]0-i entered [the house]3075-the house [I]0-i singled [you]88-elizabeth out as the companion of [my]0-i future life . But before [I]0-i am run away with by [my]0-i feelings on this subject , perhaps it will be advisable for [me]0-i to state [my]0-i reasons for marrying -- and , moreover , for coming into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire with the design of selecting [a wife]229-a wife , as [I]0-i certainly did . ” The idea of [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , with all [his]134-mr. collins solemn composure , being run away with by [his]134-mr. collins feelings , made [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth so near laughing that [she]88-elizabeth could not use the short pause [he]134-mr. collins allowed in any attempt to stop [him]134-mr. collins farther , and [he]134-mr. collins continued,-- “[0-i] [My]0-i reasons for marrying are , first , that [I]0-i think it a right thing for [every clergyman in easy circumstances ( like [myself]0-i ) to set the example of matrimony in [[his]948-every clergyman in easy circumstances ( like myself ) to set the example of matrimony in his parish parish]3534-his parish]948-every clergyman in easy circumstances ( like myself ) to set the example of matrimony in his parish ; secondly , that [I]0-i am convinced it will add very greatly to [my]0-i happiness ; and , thirdly , which perhaps [I]0-i ought to have mentioned earlier , that it is the particular advice and recommendation of [the very noble lady whom [I]0-i have the honour of calling [patroness]951-patroness]950-the very noble lady whom i have the honour of calling patroness . Twice has [she]950-the very noble lady whom i have the honour of calling patroness condescended to give [me]0-i [her]950-the very noble lady whom i have the honour of calling patroness opinion ( unasked too ! ) on this subject ; and it was but the very Saturday night before [I]0-i left Hunsford,--between [[our]952-our pools]953-our pools at [quadrille]24-quadrille , while [Mrs. Jenkinson]152-mrs. jenkinson was arranging [Miss De Bourgh]138-miss de bourgh ’s footstool,--that [she]152-mrs. jenkinson said , ‘ [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , [you]134-mr. collins must marry . [A clergyman like [you]134-mr. collins]954-a clergyman like you must marry . Choose properly , choose [a gentlewoman]955-a gentlewoman for [my]0-i sake , and for [your]134-mr. collins own ; let [her]955-a gentlewoman be [an active , useful sort of person]956-an active , useful sort of person , not brought up high , but able to make a small income go a good way . This is [my]0-i advice . Find such [a woman]3084-a woman as soon as [you]134-mr. collins can , bring [her]3084-a woman to [Hunsford]15-hunsford , and [I]0-i will visit [her]3084-a woman . ’ Allow [me]0-i , by the way , to observe , [[my]0-i fair cousin]958-my fair cousin , that [I]0-i do not reckon the notice and kindness of [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]93-lady catherine as among the least of the advantages in [my]0-i power to offer . [You]134-mr. collins will find [her]3084-a woman manners beyond anything [I]0-i can describe ; and [your]134-mr. collins wit and vivacity , [I]0-i think , must be acceptable to [her]3084-a woman , especially when tempered with the silence and respect which [her]3084-a woman rank will inevitably excite . Thus much for [my]0-i general intention in favour of matrimony ; it remains to be told why [my]0-i views were directed to [Longbourn]7-longbourn instead of [[my]0-i own neighbourhood]959-my own neighbourhood , where [I]0-i assure [you]134-mr. collins there are [many amiable young women]960-many amiable young women . But the fact is , that being , as [I]0-i am , to inherit [this estate]681-this estate after the death of [[your]134-mr. collins honoured father]962-your honoured father ( who , however , may live many years longer ) , [I]0-i could not satisfy [myself]0-i without resolving to choose [a wife]229-a wife from among [[his]962-your honoured father daughters]430-his daughters , that the loss to [them]430-his daughters might be as little as possible when the melancholy event takes place -- which , however , as [I]0-i have already said , may not be for several years . This has been [my]0-i motive , [[my]0-i fair cousin]958-my fair cousin , and [I]0-i flatter [myself]0-i it will not sink [me]0-i in [your]134-mr. collins esteem . And now nothing remains for [me]0-i but to assure [you]134-mr. collins in the most animated language of the violence of [my]0-i affection . To fortune [I]0-i am perfectly indifferent , and shall make no demand of that nature on [[your]134-mr. collins father]3292-your father , since [I]0-i am well aware that it could not be complied with ; and that one thousand pounds in the 4 per cents . , which will not be [yours]134-mr. collins till after [[your]134-mr. collins mother]967-your mother ’s decease , is all that [you]134-mr. collins may ever be entitled to . On that head , therefore , [I]0-i shall be uniformly silent : and [you]134-mr. collins may assure [yourself]134-mr. collins that no ungenerous reproach shall ever pass [my]0-i lips when [we]968-we are married . ” It was absolutely necessary to interrupt [him]3292-your father now . “[3292-your father] [You]3292-your father are too hasty , [sir]3234-sir , ” [she]967-your mother cried . “[3292-your father] [You]3292-your father forget that [I]0-i have made no answer . Let [me]0-i do it without further loss of time . Accept [my]0-i thanks for the compliment [you]3292-your father are paying [me]0-i . [I]0-i am very sensible of the honour of [your]3292-your father proposals , but it is impossible for [me]0-i to do otherwise than decline them . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am not now to learn , ” replied [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , with a formal wave of the hand , “[0-i] that it is usual with [young ladies]3329-young ladies to reject the addresses of [the man whom [they]3329-young ladies secretly mean to accept , when [he]971-the man whom they secretly mean to accept , when he first applies for their favour first applies for [their]3329-young ladies favour]971-the man whom they secretly mean to accept , when he first applies for their favour ; and that sometimes the refusal is repeated a second or even a third time . [I]0-i am , therefore , by no means discouraged by what [you]3292-your father have just said , and shall hope to lead [you]3292-your father to the altar ere long . ” “[0-i] Upon [my]0-i word , [sir]3234-sir , ” cried [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , “[0-i] [your]3234-sir hope is rather an extraordinary one after [my]0-i declaration . [I]0-i do assure [you]3234-sir that [I]0-i am not one of [those young ladies ( if [such young ladies there]974-such young ladies there are ) who are so daring as to risk [their]973-those young ladies ( if such young ladies there are ) who are so daring as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second time happiness on the chance of being asked a second time]973-those young ladies ( if such young ladies there are ) who are so daring as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second time . [I]0-i am perfectly serious in [my]0-i refusal . [You]3292-your father could not make [me]0-i happy , and [I]0-i am convinced that [I]0-i am [the last woman in [the world]304-the world]975-the last woman in the world who would make [you]3292-your father so . Nay , were [[your]3292-your father friend]3112-your friend [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine to know [me]0-i , [I]0-i am persuaded [she]93-lady catherine would find [me]0-i in every respect ill qualified for the situation . ” “[93-lady catherine] Were it certain that [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine would think so , ” said [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , very gravely--“but[93-lady catherine] [I]0-i can not imagine that [[her]93-lady catherine Ladyship]3490-her ladyship would at all disapprove of [you]3292-your father . And [you]3292-your father may be certain that when [I]0-i have the honour of seeing [her]93-lady catherine again [I]0-i shall speak in the highest terms of [your]3292-your father modesty , economy , and other amiable qualifications . ” “[0-i] Indeed , [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , all praise of [me]0-i will be unnecessary . [You]134-mr. collins must give [me]0-i leave to judge for [myself]0-i , and pay [me]0-i the compliment of believing what [I]0-i say . [I]0-i wish [you]3292-your father very happy and very rich , and by refusing [your]3292-your father hand , do all in [my]0-i power to prevent [your]3292-your father being otherwise . In making [me]0-i the offer , [you]3292-your father must have satisfied the delicacy of [your]3292-your father feelings with regard to [[my]0-i family]979-my family , and may take possession of [Longbourn estate]3494-longbourn estate whenever it falls , without any self - reproach . This matter may be considered , therefore , as finally settled . ” And rising as [she]3292-your father thus spoke , [she]3292-your father would have quitted [the room]255-the room , had not [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins thus addressed [her,--]3292-your father “[3292-your father] When [I]0-i do [myself]0-i the honour of speaking to [you]3292-your father next on the subject , [I]0-i shall hope to receive a more favourable answer than [you]3292-your father have now given [me]0-i ; though [I]0-i am far from accusing [you]3292-your father of cruelty at present , because [I]0-i know it to be the established custom of [your]3292-your father sex to reject [a man]3114-a man on the first application , and , perhaps , [you]3292-your father have even now said as much to encourage [my]0-i suit as would be consistent with the true delicacy of [the female character]982-the female character . ” “[3292-your father] Really , [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , ” cried [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , with some warmth , “[134-mr. collins] [you]134-mr. collins puzzle [me]0-i exceedingly . If what [I]0-i have hitherto said can appear to [you]134-mr. collins in the form of encouragement , [I]0-i know not how to express [my]0-i refusal in such a way as may convince [you]134-mr. collins of its being one . ” “[3292-your father] [You]3292-your father must give [me]0-i leave to flatter [myself]0-i , [[my]0-i dear cousin]983-my dear cousin , that [your]3292-your father refusal of [my]0-i addresses are merely words of course . [My]0-i reasons for believing it are briefly these -It does not appear to [me]0-i that [my]0-i hand is unworthy [your]3292-your father acceptance , or that the establishment [I]0-i can offer would be any other than highly desirable . [My]0-i situation in life , [my]0-i connections with [the family of [De Bourgh]138-miss de bourgh]3680-the family of de bourgh , and [my]0-i relationship to [your]3292-your father own , are circumstances highly in [my]0-i favour ; and [you]3292-your father should take it into further consideration that , in spite of [your]3292-your father manifold attractions , it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made [you]3292-your father . [Your]3292-your father portion is unhappily so small , that it will in all likelihood undo the effects of [your]3292-your father loveliness and amiable qualifications . As [I]0-i must , therefore , conclude that [you]3292-your father are not serious in [your]3292-your father rejection of [me]0-i , [I]0-i shall choose to attribute it to [your]3292-your father wish of increasing [my]0-i love by suspense , according to the usual practice of [elegant females]985-elegant females . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do assure [you]3292-your father , [sir]3234-sir , that [I]0-i have no pretensions whatever to that kind of elegance which consists in tormenting [a respectable man]987-a respectable man . [I]0-i would rather be paid the compliment of being believed sincere . [I]0-i thank [you]3292-your father again and again for the honour [you]3292-your father have done [me]0-i in [your]3292-your father proposals , but to accept them is absolutely impossible . [My]0-i feelings in every respect forbid it . Can [I]0-i speak plainer ? Do not consider [me]0-i now as [an elegant female]988-an elegant female intending to plague [you]3292-your father , but as a rational creature speaking the truth from [her]988-an elegant female heart . ” “[988-an elegant female] [You]0-i are uniformly charming ! ” cried [he]0-i , with an air of awkward gallantry ; “[0-i] and [I]0-i am persuaded that , when sanctioned by the express authority of both [[your]0-i excellent parents]989-your excellent parents , [my]0-i proposals will not fail of being acceptable . ” To such perseverance in wilful self - deception [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth would make no reply , and immediately and in silence withdrew ; determined , that if [he]0-i persisted in considering [her]88-elizabeth repeated refusals as flattering encouragement , to apply to [[her]88-elizabeth father]249-her father , whose negative might be uttered in such a manner as must be decisive , and whose behaviour at least could not be mistaken for the affectation and coquetry of [an elegant female]988-an elegant female . [ Illustration ] CHAPTER XX . [ Illustration ] [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins was not left long to the silent contemplation of [his]134-mr. collins successful love ; for [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet , having dawdled about in [the vestibule]3820-the vestibule to watch for the end of the conference , no sooner saw [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth open the door and with quick step pass [her]88-elizabeth towards the staircase , than [she]92-mrs. bennet entered [the breakfast - room]3821-the breakfast - room , and congratulated both [him]0-i and [herself]92-mrs. bennet in warm terms on the happy prospect of [their]989-your excellent parents nearer connection . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins received and returned these felicitations with equal pleasure , and then proceeded to relate the particulars of [their]989-your excellent parents interview , with the result of which [he]134-mr. collins trusted [he]134-mr. collins had every reason to be satisfied , since the refusal which [[his]134-mr. collins cousin]3538-his cousin had steadfastly given [him]134-mr. collins would naturally flow from [her]3538-his cousin bashful modesty and the genuine delicacy of [her]3538-his cousin character . This information , however , startled [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet : [she]92-mrs. bennet would have been glad to be equally satisfied that [[her]92-mrs. bennet daughter]461-her daughter had meant to encourage [him]134-mr. collins by protesting against [his]134-mr. collins proposals , but [she]92-mrs. bennet dared not believe it , and could not help saying so . “[134-mr. collins] But depend upon it , [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , ” [she]92-mrs. bennet added , “[134-mr. collins] that [Lizzy]88-elizabeth shall be brought to reason . [I]0-i will speak to [her]88-elizabeth about it [myself]0-i directly . [She]88-elizabeth is [a very headstrong , foolish girl]990-a very headstrong , foolish girl , and does not know [her]88-elizabeth own interest ; but [I]0-i will make [her]88-elizabeth know it . ” “[0-i] Pardon [me]0-i for interrupting [you]0-i , [madam]3346-madam , ” cried [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins ; “[0-i] but if [she]88-elizabeth is really headstrong and foolish , [I]0-i know not whether [she]88-elizabeth would altogether be [a very desirable wife to [a man in [my]0-i situation , who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state]993-a man in my situation , who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state]992-a very desirable wife to a man in my situation , who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state . If , therefore , [she]88-elizabeth actually persists in rejecting [my]0-i suit , perhaps it were better not to force [her]88-elizabeth into accepting [me]0-i , because , if liable to such defects of temper , [she]88-elizabeth could not contribute much to [my]0-i felicity . ” “[3234-sir] [Sir]3234-sir , [you]3234-sir quite misunderstand [me]0-i , ” said [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet , alarmed . “[3234-sir] [Lizzy]88-elizabeth is only headstrong in such matters as these . In everything else [she]88-elizabeth is as good - natured [a girl as ever lived]995-a girl as ever lived . [I]0-i will go directly to [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet , and [we]996-we shall very soon settle it with [her]88-elizabeth , [I]0-i am sure . ” [She]92-mrs. bennet would not give [him]81-mr. bennet time to reply , but hurrying instantly to [[her]92-mrs. bennet husband]260-her husband , called out , as [she]92-mrs. bennet entered the library,-- “[0-i] Oh , [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet , [you]81-mr. bennet are wanted immediately ; [we]996-we are all in an uproar . [You]81-mr. bennet must come and make [Lizzy]88-elizabeth marry [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , for [she]88-elizabeth vows [she]88-elizabeth will not have [him]134-mr. collins ; and if [you]81-mr. bennet do not make haste [he]134-mr. collins will change [his]134-mr. collins mind and not have [her]88-elizabeth . ” [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet raised [his]81-mr. bennet eyes from [his]81-mr. bennet book as [she]88-elizabeth entered , and fixed them on [her]88-elizabeth face with a calm unconcern , which was not in the least altered by [her]88-elizabeth communication . “[0-i] [I]0-i have not the pleasure of understanding [you]81-mr. bennet , ” said [he]81-mr. bennet , when [she]88-elizabeth had finished [her]88-elizabeth speech . “[0-i] Of what are [you]81-mr. bennet talking ? ” “[81-mr. bennet] Of [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins and [Lizzy]88-elizabeth . [Lizzy]88-elizabeth declares [she]88-elizabeth will not have [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , and [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins begins to say that [he]134-mr. collins will not have [Lizzy]88-elizabeth . ” “[134-mr. collins] And what am [I]0-i to do on the occasion ? It seems a hopeless business . ” “[0-i] Speak to [Lizzy]88-elizabeth about it [yourself]0-i . Tell [her]88-elizabeth that [you]0-i insist upon [her]88-elizabeth marrying [him]134-mr. collins . ” “[0-i] Let [her]88-elizabeth be called down . [She]88-elizabeth shall hear [my]0-i opinion . ” [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet rang the bell , and [Miss Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was summoned to [the library]3825-the library . “[88-elizabeth] Come here , [child]926-child , ” cried [[her]88-elizabeth father]249-her father as [she]88-elizabeth appeared . “[926-child] [I]0-i have sent for [you]926-child on an affair of importance . [I]0-i understand that [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins has made [you]926-child an offer of marriage . Is it true ? ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth replied that it was . “[134-mr. collins] Very well -- and this offer of marriage [you]0-i have refused ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i have , [sir]3234-sir . ” “[0-i] Very well . [We]999-we now come to the point . [[Your]926-child mother]967-your mother insists upon [your]926-child accepting it . Is it not so , [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet ? ” “[92-mrs. bennet] Yes , or [I]0-i will never see [her]967-your mother again . ” “[92-mrs. bennet] An unhappy alternative is before [you]926-child , [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth . From this day [you]926-child must be [a stranger to one of [[your]926-child parents]1002-your parents]1001-a stranger to one of your parents . [[Your]926-child mother]967-your mother will never see [you]926-child again if [you]926-child do not marry [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , and [I]0-i will never see [you]926-child again if [you]926-child do . ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth could not but smile at such a conclusion of such a beginning ; but [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet , who had persuaded [herself]92-mrs. bennet that [[her]92-mrs. bennet husband]260-her husband regarded the affair as [she]92-mrs. bennet wished , was excessively disappointed . “[0-i] What do [you]0-i mean , [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet , by talking in this way ? [You]0-i promised [me]0-i to insist upon [her]967-your mother marrying [him]134-mr. collins . ” “[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]3066-my dear , ” replied [[her]92-mrs. bennet husband]260-her husband , “[0-i] [I]0-i have two small favours to request . First , that [you]0-i will allow [me]0-i the free use of [my]0-i understanding on the present occasion ; and , secondly , of [[my]0-i room]1005-my room . [I]0-i shall be glad to have [the library]3825-the library to [myself]0-i as soon as may be . ” Not yet , however , in spite of [her]92-mrs. bennet disappointment in [[her]92-mrs. bennet husband]260-her husband , did [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet give up the point . [She]92-mrs. bennet talked to [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth again and again ; coaxed and threatened [her]88-elizabeth by turns . [She]92-mrs. bennet endeavoured to secure [Jane]89-jane in [her]92-mrs. bennet interest , but [Jane]89-jane , with all possible mildness , declined interfering ; and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , sometimes with real earnestness , and sometimes with playful gaiety , replied to [her]92-mrs. bennet attacks . Though [her]92-mrs. bennet manner varied , however , [her]92-mrs. bennet determination never did . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , meanwhile , was meditating in solitude on what had passed . [He]134-mr. collins thought too well of [himself]134-mr. collins to comprehend on what motive [[his]134-mr. collins cousin]3538-his cousin could refuse [him]134-mr. collins ; and though [his]134-mr. collins pride was hurt , [he]134-mr. collins suffered in no other way . [His]134-mr. collins regard for [her]92-mrs. bennet was quite imaginary ; and the possibility of [her]92-mrs. bennet deserving [[her]92-mrs. bennet mother]246-her mother ’s reproach prevented [his]134-mr. collins feeling any regret . While [the family]414-the family were in this confusion , [Charlotte Lucas]107-charlotte came to spend the day with [them]414-the family . [She]107-charlotte was met in [the vestibule]3820-the vestibule by [Lydia]90-lydia , who , flying to [her]107-charlotte , cried in a half whisper , “[0-i] [I]0-i am glad [you]1007-you are come , for there is such fun here ! What do [you]1007-you think has happened this morning ? [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins has made an offer to [Lizzy]88-elizabeth , and [she]88-elizabeth will not have [him]134-mr. collins . ” [ Illustration : “[1008-they] [they]1008-they entered [the breakfast room]1009-the breakfast room ” ] [Charlotte]107-charlotte had hardly time to answer before [they]1008-they were joined by [Kitty]93-lady catherine , who came to tell the same news ; and no sooner had [they]1008-they entered [the breakfast - room]3821-the breakfast - room , where [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet was alone , than [she]107-charlotte likewise began on the subject , calling on [Miss Lucas]99-miss lucas for [her]99-miss lucas compassion , and entreating [her]99-miss lucas to persuade [[her]99-miss lucas friend]400-her friend [Lizzy]88-elizabeth to comply with the wishes of [[her]99-miss lucas family]3710-her family . “[1008-they] Pray do , [[my]0-i dear]3066-my dear [Miss Lucas]99-miss lucas , ” [she]107-charlotte added , in a melancholy tone ; “[99-miss lucas] for [nobody]3152-nobody is on [my]0-i side , [nobody]3152-nobody takes part with [me]0-i ; [I]0-i am cruelly used , [nobody]3152-nobody feels for [my]0-i poor nerves . ” [Charlotte]107-charlotte ’s reply was spared by the entrance of [Jane]89-jane and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth . “[1014-she] Ay , there [she]1014-she comes , ” continued [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet , “[1014-she] looking as unconcerned as may be , and caring no more for [us]1015-us than if [we]1015-us were at [York]25-york , provided [she]1014-she can have [her]1014-she own way . But [I]0-i tell [you]99-miss lucas what , [Miss Lizzy]88-elizabeth , if [you]99-miss lucas take it into [your]99-miss lucas head to go on refusing every offer of marriage in this way , [you]99-miss lucas will never get [a husband]1016-a husband at all -- and [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i do not know who is to maintain [you]99-miss lucas when [[your]99-miss lucas father]3292-your father is dead . [I]0-i shall not be able to keep [you]99-miss lucas -- and so [I]0-i warn [you]99-miss lucas . [I]0-i have done with [you]99-miss lucas from this very day . [I]0-i told [you]99-miss lucas in [the library]3825-the library , [you]99-miss lucas know , that [I]0-i should never speak to [you]99-miss lucas again , and [you]99-miss lucas will find [me]0-i as good as [my]0-i word . [I]0-i have no pleasure in talking to [undutiful children]1019-undutiful children . Not that [I]0-i have much pleasure , indeed , in talking to [anybody]3171-anybody . People who suffer as [I]0-i do from nervous complaints can have no great inclination for talking . [Nobody]3152-nobody can tell what [I]0-i suffer ! But it is always so . [Those who do not complain]1022-those who do not complain are never pitied . ” [[Her]3837-her daughters]242-her daughters listened in silence to this effusion , sensible that any attempt to reason with or soothe [her]3837-her would only increase the irritation . [She]3837-her talked on , therefore , without interruption from [any of [them]242-her daughters]3839-any of them till [they]242-her daughters were joined by [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , who entered with an air more stately than usual , and on perceiving whom , [she]3837-her said to the girls,-- “[0-i] Now , [I]0-i do insist upon it , that [you]1023-you , all of [you]1023-you , hold [your]1023-you tongues , and let [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins and [me]0-i have a little conversation together . ” [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth passed quietly out of [the room]255-the room , [Jane]89-jane and [Kitty]93-lady catherine followed , but [Lydia]90-lydia stood [her]90-lydia ground , determined to hear all [she]90-lydia could ; and [Charlotte]107-charlotte , detained first by the civility of [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins , whose inquiries after [herself]107-charlotte and all [[her]107-charlotte family]3710-her family were very minute , and then by a little curiosity , satisfied [herself]107-charlotte with walking to the window and pretending not to hear . In a doleful voice [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet thus began the projected conversation - “[134-mr. collins] Oh , [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins ! ” “[134-mr. collins] [[My]0-i dear madam]1024-my dear madam , ” replied [he]0-i , “[134-mr. collins] let [us]1025-us be for ever silent on this point . Far be it from [me]0-i , ” [he]0-i presently continued , in a voice that marked [his]0-i displeasure , “[0-i] to resent the behaviour of [[your]1024-my dear madam daughter]3298-your daughter . Resignation to inevitable evils is the duty of [us]1025-us all : the peculiar duty of [a young man who has been so fortunate as [I]0-i have been , in early preferment]1027-a young man who has been so fortunate as i have been , in early preferment ; and , [I]0-i trust , [I]0-i am resigned . Perhaps not the less so from feeling a doubt of [my]0-i positive happiness had [[my]0-i fair cousin]958-my fair cousin honoured [me]0-i with [her]958-my fair cousin hand ; for [I]0-i have often observed , that resignation is never so perfect as when the blessing denied begins to lose somewhat of its value in [our]1025-us estimation . [You]1024-my dear madam will not , [I]0-i hope , consider [me]0-i as showing any disrespect to [[your]1024-my dear madam family]3498-your family , [[my]0-i dear madam]1024-my dear madam , by thus withdrawing [my]0-i pretensions to [[your]1024-my dear madam daughter]3298-your daughter ’s favour , without having paid [yourself]1024-my dear madam and [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet the compliment of requesting [you]1024-my dear madam to interpose [your]1024-my dear madam authority in [my]0-i behalf . [My]0-i conduct may , [I]0-i fear , be objectionable in having accepted [my]0-i dismission from [[your]1024-my dear madam daughter]3298-your daughter ’s lips instead of [your]1024-my dear madam own ; but [we]1033-we are all liable to error . [I]0-i have certainly meant well through the whole affair . [My]0-i object has been to secure an amiable companion for [myself]0-i , with due consideration for the advantage of all [[your]1024-my dear madam family]3498-your family ; and if [my]0-i manner has been at all reprehensible , [I]0-i here beg leave to apologize . ” [ Illustration ] CHAPTER XXI . [ Illustration ] The discussion of [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins ’s offer was now nearly at an end , and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth had only to suffer from the uncomfortable feelings necessarily attending it , and occasionally from some peevish allusion of [[her]88-elizabeth mother]246-her mother . As for [the gentleman]287-the gentleman [himself]287-the gentleman , [his]287-the gentleman feelings were chiefly expressed , not by embarrassment or dejection , or by trying to avoid [her]88-elizabeth , but by stiffness of manner and resentful silence . [He]287-the gentleman scarcely ever spoke to [her]88-elizabeth ; and the assiduous attentions which [he]287-the gentleman had been so sensible of [himself]287-the gentleman were transferred for the rest of the day to [Miss Lucas]99-miss lucas , whose civility in listening to [him]287-the gentleman was a seasonable relief to [them]3844-them all , and especially to [[her]99-miss lucas friend]400-her friend . The morrow produced no abatement of [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet ’s ill humour or ill health . [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins was also in the same state of angry pride . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth had hoped that [his]134-mr. collins resentment might shorten [his]134-mr. collins visit , but [his]134-mr. collins plan did not appear in the least affected by it . [He]134-mr. collins was always to have gone on Saturday , and to Saturday [he]134-mr. collins still meant to stay . After breakfast , [the girls]3082-the girls walked to [Meryton]9-meryton , to inquire if [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham were returned , and to lament over [his]134-mr. collins absence from the [Netherfield]2-netherfield ball .
