[Elizabeth]88-elizabeth saw what [he]172-colonel fitzwilliam was doing , and at the first convenient pause turned to [him]172-colonel fitzwilliam with an arch smile , and said,-- “ [You]172-colonel fitzwilliam mean to frighten [me]88-elizabeth , [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , by coming in all this state to hear [me]88-elizabeth . But [I]88-elizabeth will not be alarmed , though [[your]96-mr. darcy sister]3211-your sister does play so well . There is a stubbornness about [me]88-elizabeth that never can bear to be frightened at the will of [others]3175-others . [My]88-elizabeth courage always rises with every attempt to intimidate [me]88-elizabeth . ”[88-elizabeth] “ [I]172-colonel fitzwilliam shall not say that [you]88-elizabeth are mistaken , ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] [he]172-colonel fitzwilliam replied , “ because [you]88-elizabeth could not really believe [me]172-colonel fitzwilliam to entertain any design of alarming [you]88-elizabeth ; and [I]172-colonel fitzwilliam have had the pleasure of [your]88-elizabeth acquaintance long enough to know , that [you]88-elizabeth find great enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which , in fact , are not [your]88-elizabeth own . ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture of [herself]88-elizabeth , and said to [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam , “ [[Your]172-colonel fitzwilliam cousin]4182-your cousin will give [you]172-colonel fitzwilliam a very pretty notion of [me]88-elizabeth , and teach [you]172-colonel fitzwilliam not to believe a word [I]88-elizabeth say . [I]88-elizabeth am particularly unlucky in meeting with [a person so well able to expose [my]88-elizabeth real character , in [a part of [the world]304-the world where [I]88-elizabeth had hoped to pass [myself]88-elizabeth off with some degree of credit]4184-a part of the world where i had hoped to pass myself off with some degree of credit]4183-a person so well able to expose my real character , in a part of the world where i had hoped to pass myself off with some degree of credit . Indeed , [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , it is very ungenerous in [you]96-mr. darcy to mention all that [you]96-mr. darcy knew to [my]88-elizabeth disadvantage in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire -- and , give [me]88-elizabeth leave to say , very impolitic too -- for it is provoking [me]88-elizabeth to retaliate , and such things may come out as will shock [[your]96-mr. darcy relations]4186-your relations to hear . ”[88-elizabeth] “ [I]1496-you am not afraid of [you]1496-you , ”[1496-you] said [he]1496-you , smilingly . “ Pray let [me]172-colonel fitzwilliam hear what [you]1496-you have to accuse [him]1496-you of , ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] cried [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam . “ [I]172-colonel fitzwilliam should like to know how [he]1496-you behaves among [strangers]4187-strangers . ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] “ [You]1496-you shall hear , then -- but prepare for something very dreadful . The first time of [my]88-elizabeth ever seeing [him]1496-you in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , [you]1496-you must know , was at a ball -- and at this ball , what do [you]1496-you think [he]1496-you did ? [He]1496-you danced only four dances ! [I]88-elizabeth am sorry to pain [you]1496-you , but so it was . [He]1496-you danced only four dances , though [gentlemen]309-gentlemen were scarce ; and , to [my]88-elizabeth certain knowledge , more than [one young lady]4189-one young lady was sitting down in want of [a partner]3251-a partner . [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , [you]96-mr. darcy can not deny the fact . ”[88-elizabeth] “ [I]172-colonel fitzwilliam had not at that time the honour of knowing [any lady in the assembly]4191-any lady in the assembly beyond [my]172-colonel fitzwilliam own party . ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] “ True ; and [nobody]3152-nobody can ever be introduced in a ball - room . Well , [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam , what do [I]88-elizabeth play next ? [My]88-elizabeth fingers wait [your]172-colonel fitzwilliam orders . ”[88-elizabeth] “ Perhaps , ”[96-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]96-mr. darcy , “ [I]96-mr. darcy should have judged better had [I]96-mr. darcy sought an introduction , but [I]96-mr. darcy am ill - qualified to recommend [myself]96-mr. darcy to [strangers]4187-strangers . ”[96-mr. darcy] “ Shall [we]4194-we ask [[your]172-colonel fitzwilliam cousin]4182-your cousin the reason of this ? ”[88-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , still addressing [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam . “ Shall [we]4194-we ask [him]4182-your cousin why [a man of sense and education]4196-a man of sense and education , and who has lived in [the world]304-the world , is ill - qualified to recommend [himself]4182-your cousin to [strangers]4187-strangers ? ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] “ [I]172-colonel fitzwilliam can answer [your]172-colonel fitzwilliam question , ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] said [Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam , “ without applying to [him]4182-your cousin . It is because [he]4182-your cousin will not give [himself]4182-your cousin the trouble . ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] “ [I]96-mr. darcy certainly have not the talent which [some people]4199-some people possess , ”[96-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]96-mr. darcy , “ of conversing easily with those [I]96-mr. darcy have never seen before . [I]96-mr. darcy can not catch [their]4199-some people tone of conversation , or appear interested in [their]4199-some people concerns , as [I]96-mr. darcy often see done . ”[96-mr. darcy] “ [My]88-elizabeth fingers , ”[88-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , “ do not move over this instrument in the masterly manner which [I]88-elizabeth see [so many women]4200-so many women ’s do . [They]4199-some people have not the same force or rapidity , and do not produce the same expression . But then [I]88-elizabeth have always supposed it to be [my]88-elizabeth own fault -- because [I]88-elizabeth would not take the trouble of practising . It is not that [I]88-elizabeth do not believe [my]88-elizabeth fingers as capable as [any other woman]4201-any other woman ’s of superior execution . ”[88-elizabeth] [Darcy]96-mr. darcy smiled and said , “ [You]88-elizabeth are perfectly right . [You]88-elizabeth have employed [your]88-elizabeth time much better . [No one]3336-no one admitted to the privilege of hearing [you]88-elizabeth can think anything wanting . [We]1497-they neither of [us]1497-they perform to [strangers]4187-strangers . ”[96-mr. darcy] Here [they]1497-they were interrupted by [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine , who called out to know what [they]1497-they were talking of . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth immediately began playing again . [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine approached , and , after listening for a few minutes , said to [Darcy,--]173-darcy,-- “ [Miss Bennet]88-elizabeth would not play at all amiss if [she]88-elizabeth practised more , and could have the advantage of [a London master]4204-a london master . [She]88-elizabeth has a very good notion of fingering , though [her]88-elizabeth taste is not equal to [Anne]146-anne ’s . [Anne]146-anne would have been [a delightful performer]4205-a delightful performer , had [her]146-anne health allowed [her]146-anne to learn . ”[93-lady catherine] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth looked at [Darcy]146-anne , to see how cordially [he]1498-his assented to [[his]1498-his cousin]3538-his cousin ’s praise : but neither at that moment nor at any other could [she]88-elizabeth discern any symptom of love ; and from the whole of [his]1498-his behaviour to [Miss De Bourgh]138-miss de bourgh [she]88-elizabeth derived this comfort for [Miss Bingley]98-miss bingley , that [he]1498-his might have been just as likely to marry [her]98-miss bingley , had [she]98-miss bingley been [[his]1498-his relation]1500-his relation . [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine continued [her]93-lady catherine remarks on [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s performance , mixing with [them]1501-them many instructions on execution and taste . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth received them with all the forbearance of civility ; and at the request of [the gentlemen]292-the gentlemen remained at the instrument till [[her]88-elizabeth Ladyship]3490-her ladyship ’s carriage was ready to take [them]292-the gentlemen all [home]3288-home . [ Illustration ] CHAPTER XXXII . [ Illustration ] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was sitting by [herself]88-elizabeth the next morning , and writing to [Jane]89-jane , while [Mrs. Collins]166-mrs. collins and [Maria]101-maria were gone on business into [the village]320-the village , when [she]88-elizabeth was startled by a ring at the door , the certain signal of [a visitor]1506-a visitor . As [she]88-elizabeth had heard [no carriage]1507-no carriage , [she]88-elizabeth thought it not unlikely to be [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine ; and under that apprehension was putting away [her]88-elizabeth half - finished letter , that [she]88-elizabeth might escape all impertinent questions , when the door opened , and to [her]88-elizabeth very great surprise [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , and [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy only , entered [the room]255-the room . [He]96-mr. darcy seemed astonished too on finding [her]88-elizabeth alone , and apologized for [his]96-mr. darcy intrusion , by letting [her]88-elizabeth know that [he]96-mr. darcy had understood all [the ladies]254-the ladies to be within . [They]1510-they then sat down , and when [her]88-elizabeth inquiries after Rosings were made , seemed in danger of sinking into total silence . It was absolutely necessary , therefore , to think of something ; and in this emergency recollecting when [she]88-elizabeth had seen [him]96-mr. darcy last in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , and feeling curious to know what [he]96-mr. darcy would say on the subject of [their]1510-they hasty departure , [she]88-elizabeth observed,-- “ How very suddenly [you]96-mr. darcy all quitted [Netherfield]2-netherfield last November , [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ! It must have been a most agreeable surprise to [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley to see [you]96-mr. darcy all after [him]85-mr. bingley so soon ; for , if [I]88-elizabeth recollect right , [he]85-mr. bingley went but the day before . [He]85-mr. bingley and [[his]85-mr. bingley sisters]284-his sisters were well , [I]88-elizabeth hope , when [you]96-mr. darcy left [London]5-london ? ”[88-elizabeth] “ Perfectly so , [I]88-elizabeth thank [you]96-mr. darcy . ”[88-elizabeth] [She]88-elizabeth found that [she]88-elizabeth was to receive no other answer ; and , after a short pause , added,-- “ [I]88-elizabeth think [I]88-elizabeth have understood that [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley has not much idea of ever returning to [Netherfield]2-netherfield again ? ”[88-elizabeth] “ [I]88-elizabeth have never heard [him]85-mr. bingley say so ; but it is probable that [he]85-mr. bingley may spend very little of [his]85-mr. bingley time [there]306-there in future . [He]85-mr. bingley has [many friends]4208-many friends , and [he]85-mr. bingley is at a time of life when [friends]1046-friends and engagements are continually increasing . ”[88-elizabeth] “ If [he]85-mr. bingley means to be but little at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , it would be better for [the neighbourhood]3088-the neighbourhood that [he]85-mr. bingley should give up [the place]3068-the place entirely , for then [we]4212-we might possibly get [a settled family]4213-a settled family [there]306-there . But , perhaps , [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley did not take [the house]3075-the house so much for the convenience of [the neighbourhood]3088-the neighbourhood as for [his]85-mr. bingley own , and [we]4212-we must expect [him]85-mr. bingley to keep or quit [it]3075-the house on the same principle . ”[88-elizabeth] “ [I]96-mr. darcy should not be surprised , ”[96-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]96-mr. darcy , “ if [he]85-mr. bingley were to give it up as soon as any eligible purchase offers . ”[96-mr. darcy] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth made no answer . [She]88-elizabeth was afraid of talking longer of [[his]96-mr. darcy friend]288-his friend ; and , having nothing else to say , was now determined to leave the trouble of finding a subject to [him]96-mr. darcy . [He]96-mr. darcy took the hint and soon began with , “ This seems [a very comfortable house]4217-a very comfortable house . [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine , [I]96-mr. darcy believe , did a great deal to it when [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins first came to [Hunsford]15-hunsford . ”[96-mr. darcy] “ [I]96-mr. darcy believe [she]93-lady catherine did -- and [I]96-mr. darcy am sure [she]93-lady catherine could not have bestowed [her]93-lady catherine kindness on a more grateful object . ”[96-mr. darcy] “ [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins appears very fortunate in [his]134-mr. collins choice of [a wife]229-a wife . ”[96-mr. darcy] “ Yes , indeed ; [[his]134-mr. collins friends]405-his friends may well rejoice in [his]134-mr. collins having met with one of [the very few sensible women who would have accepted [him]134-mr. collins , or have made [him]134-mr. collins happy if [they]405-his friends had]4220-the very few sensible women who would have accepted him , or have made him happy if they had . [[My]96-mr. darcy friend]3416-my friend has an excellent understanding -- though [I]96-mr. darcy am not certain that [I]96-mr. darcy consider [her]3416-my friend marrying [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins as the wisest thing [she]3416-my friend ever did . [She]3416-my friend seems perfectly happy , however ; and , in a prudential light , it is certainly a very good match for [her]3416-my friend . ”[96-mr. darcy] “ It must be very agreeable to [her]3416-my friend to be settled within so easy a distance of [[her]3416-my friend own family]4222-her own family and [friends]1046-friends . ”[96-mr. darcy] “ An easy distance do [you]96-mr. darcy call it ? [It]4224-it is nearly fifty miles . ”[96-mr. darcy] “ And what is fifty miles of [good road]4225-good road ? Little more than half a day ’s journey . Yes , [I]96-mr. darcy call it a very easy distance . ”[96-mr. darcy] “ [I]88-elizabeth should never have considered the distance as one of the advantages of the match , ”[88-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth . “ [I]88-elizabeth should never have said [Mrs. Collins]166-mrs. collins was settled near [[her]166-mrs. collins family]3710-her family . ”[88-elizabeth] “ It is a proof of [your]88-elizabeth own attachment to [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire . Anything beyond [the very neighbourhood of [Longbourn]7-longbourn]4227-the very neighbourhood of longbourn , [I]1512-he suppose , would appear far . ”[1512-he] As [he]1512-he spoke there was a sort of smile , which [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth fancied [she]88-elizabeth understood ; [he]1512-he must be supposing [her]88-elizabeth to be thinking of [Jane]89-jane and [Netherfield]2-netherfield , and [she]88-elizabeth blushed as [she]88-elizabeth answered,-- “ [I]96-mr. darcy do not mean to say that [a woman]3084-a woman may not be settled too near [[her]3084-a woman family]3710-her family . [The far and the near]4230-the far and the near must be relative , and depend on many varying circumstances . Where there is fortune to make the expense of travelling unimportant , distance becomes no evil . But that is not the case here . [Mr.]4231-mr. and [Mrs. Collins]166-mrs. collins have a comfortable income , but not such a one as will allow of frequent journeys -- and [I]96-mr. darcy am persuaded [[my]96-mr. darcy friend]3416-my friend would not call [herself]3416-my friend near [[her]3416-my friend family]3710-her family under less than half the present distance . ”[96-mr. darcy] [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy drew [his]96-mr. darcy chair a little towards [her]88-elizabeth , and said , “ [You]88-elizabeth can not have a right to such very strong local attachment . [You]88-elizabeth can not have been always at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . ”[96-mr. darcy] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth looked surprised . [The gentleman]287-the gentleman experienced some change of feeling ; [he]287-the gentleman drew back [his]287-the gentleman chair , took a newspaper from the table , and , glancing over it , said , in a colder voice,-- “ Are [you]88-elizabeth pleased with [Kent]17-kent ? ”[287-the gentleman] A short dialogue on the subject of [the country]448-the country ensued , on either side calm and concise -- and soon put an end to by the entrance of [Charlotte]107-charlotte and [[her]107-charlotte sister]328-her sister , just returned from [their]1516-their walk . The tête - à - tête surprised [them]1516-their . [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy related the mistake which had occasioned [his]96-mr. darcy intruding on [Miss Bennet]88-elizabeth , and , after sitting a few minutes longer , without saying much to [anybody]3171-anybody , went away . [ Illustration : “ Accompanied by [[their]1516-their aunt]442-their aunt ”[96-mr. darcy] “ What can be the meaning of this ? ”[107-charlotte] said [Charlotte]107-charlotte , as soon as [he]96-mr. darcy was gone . “ [[My]107-charlotte dear]3066-my dear [Eliza]88-elizabeth , [he]96-mr. darcy must be in love with [you]88-elizabeth , or [he]96-mr. darcy would never have called on [us]1521-the two cousins in this familiar way . ”[107-charlotte] But when [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth told of [his]96-mr. darcy silence , it did not seem very likely , even to [Charlotte]107-charlotte ’s wishes , to be the case ; and , after various conjectures , [they]1516-their could at last only suppose [his]96-mr. darcy visit to proceed from the difficulty of finding anything to do , which was the more probable from the time of year . All field sports were over . Within doors there was [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine , books , and a billiard table , but [gentlemen]309-gentlemen can not be always within doors ; and in the nearness of [the Parsonage]1288-the parsonage , or the pleasantness of the walk to it , or of [the people who lived in it]1520-the people who lived in it , [the two cousins]1521-the two cousins found a temptation from this period of walking thither almost every day . [They]1521-the two cousins called at various times of the morning , sometimes separately , sometimes together , and now and then accompanied by [[their]1521-the two cousins aunt]442-their aunt . It was plain to [them]1521-the two cousins all that [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam came because [he]172-colonel fitzwilliam had pleasure in [their]1521-the two cousins society , a persuasion which of course recommended [him]172-colonel fitzwilliam still more ; and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was reminded by [her]88-elizabeth own satisfaction in being with [him]172-colonel fitzwilliam , as well as by [his]172-colonel fitzwilliam evident admiration , of [[her]88-elizabeth former favourite]1523-her former favourite , [George Wickham]149-george wickham ; and though , in comparing [them]1521-the two cousins , [she]88-elizabeth saw there was less captivating softness in [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam ’s manners , [she]88-elizabeth believed [he]172-colonel fitzwilliam might have the best informed mind . But why [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy came so often to [the Parsonage]33-the parsonage it was more difficult to understand . It could not be for [society]1524-society , as [he]96-mr. darcy frequently sat there ten minutes together without opening [his]96-mr. darcy lips ; and when [he]96-mr. darcy did speak , it seemed the effect of necessity rather than of choice -- a sacrifice to propriety , not a pleasure to [himself]96-mr. darcy . [He]96-mr. darcy seldom appeared really animated . [Mrs. Collins]166-mrs. collins knew not what to make of [him]96-mr. darcy . [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam ’s occasionally laughing at [his]96-mr. darcy stupidity proved that [he]96-mr. darcy was generally different , which [her]166-mrs. collins own knowledge of [him]96-mr. darcy could not have told [her]166-mrs. collins ; and as [she]166-mrs. collins would have liked to believe this change the effect of love , and the object of that love [[her]166-mrs. collins friend]400-her friend [Eliza]88-elizabeth , [she]166-mrs. collins set [herself]166-mrs. collins seriously to work to find it out : [she]166-mrs. collins watched [him]96-mr. darcy whenever [they]1526-they were at [Rosings]18-rosings , and whenever [he]96-mr. darcy came to [Hunsford]15-hunsford ; but without much success . [He]96-mr. darcy certainly looked at [[her]166-mrs. collins friend]400-her friend a great deal , but the expression of that look was disputable . It was an earnest , steadfast gaze , but [she]166-mrs. collins often doubted whether there were much admiration in it , and sometimes it seemed nothing but absence of mind . [She]166-mrs. collins had once or twice suggested to [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth the possibility of [his]96-mr. darcy being partial to [her]88-elizabeth , but [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth always laughed at the idea ; and [Mrs. Collins]166-mrs. collins did not think it right to press the subject , from the danger of raising expectations which might only end in disappointment ; for in [her]166-mrs. collins opinion it admitted not of a doubt , that all [[her]166-mrs. collins friend]400-her friend ’s dislike would vanish , if [she]166-mrs. collins could suppose [him]96-mr. darcy to be in [her]166-mrs. collins power . In [her]166-mrs. collins kind schemes for [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , [she]166-mrs. collins sometimes planned [her]88-elizabeth marrying [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam . [He]96-mr. darcy was , beyond comparison , [the pleasantest man]1529-the pleasantest man : [he]96-mr. darcy certainly admired [her]88-elizabeth , and [his]96-mr. darcy situation in life was most eligible ; but , to counterbalance these advantages , [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy had considerable patronage in [the church]761-the church , and [[his]96-mr. darcy cousin]3538-his cousin could have none at all . [ Illustration : “ On looking up ”[96-mr. darcy] ] CHAPTER XXXIII . [ Illustration ] More than once did [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , in [her]88-elizabeth ramble within [the park]1317-the park , unexpectedly meet [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy . [She]88-elizabeth felt all the perverseness of the mischance that should bring [him]96-mr. darcy where [no one else]1130-no one else was brought ; and , to prevent its ever happening again , took care to inform [him]96-mr. darcy , at first , that it was a favourite haunt of [hers]88-elizabeth . How it could occur a second time , therefore , was very odd ! Yet it did , and even the third . It seemed like wilful ill - nature , or a voluntary penance ; for on these occasions it was not merely a few formal inquiries and an awkward pause and then away , but [he]96-mr. darcy actually thought it necessary to turn back and walk with [her]88-elizabeth . [He]96-mr. darcy never said a great deal , nor did [she]88-elizabeth give [herself]88-elizabeth the trouble of talking or of listening much ; but it struck [her]88-elizabeth in the course of [their]1534-their third rencounter that [he]96-mr. darcy was asking some odd unconnected questions -- about [her]88-elizabeth pleasure in being at [Hunsford]15-hunsford , [her]88-elizabeth love of solitary walks , and [her]88-elizabeth opinion of [Mr.]1535-mr. and [Mrs. Collins]166-mrs. collins ’s happiness ; and that in speaking of Rosings , and [her]88-elizabeth not perfectly understanding [the house]3075-the house , [he]96-mr. darcy seemed to expect that whenever [she]88-elizabeth came into [Kent]17-kent again [she]88-elizabeth would be staying [there]306-there too . [His]96-mr. darcy words seemed to imply it . Could [he]96-mr. darcy have [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam in [his]96-mr. darcy thoughts ? [She]88-elizabeth supposed , if [he]96-mr. darcy meant anything , [he]96-mr. darcy must mean an allusion to what might arise in that quarter . It distressed [her]88-elizabeth a little , and [she]88-elizabeth was quite glad to find [herself]88-elizabeth at the gate in [the pales opposite [the Parsonage]1288-the parsonage]1538-the pales opposite the parsonage . [She]88-elizabeth was engaged one day , as [she]88-elizabeth walked , in re - perusing [Jane]89-jane ’s last letter , and dwelling on some passages which proved that [Jane]89-jane had not written in spirits , when , instead of being again surprised by [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , [she]88-elizabeth saw , on looking up , that [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam was meeting [her]88-elizabeth . Putting away the letter immediately , and forcing a smile , [she]88-elizabeth said,-- “ [I]88-elizabeth did not know before that [you]96-mr. darcy ever walked this way . ”[88-elizabeth] “ [I]96-mr. darcy have been making the tour of [the park]1317-the park , ”[96-mr. darcy] [he]96-mr. darcy replied , “ as [I]96-mr. darcy generally do every year , and intended to close it with a call at [the Parsonage]1288-the parsonage . Are [you]96-mr. darcy going much farther ? ”[96-mr. darcy] “ No , [I]88-elizabeth should have turned in a moment . ”[88-elizabeth] And accordingly [she]88-elizabeth did turn , and [they]1540-they walked towards [the Parsonage]1288-the parsonage together . “ Do [you]96-mr. darcy certainly leave [Kent]17-kent on Saturday ? ”[88-elizabeth] said [she]88-elizabeth . “ Yes -- if [Darcy]96-mr. darcy does not put it off again . But [I]88-elizabeth am at [his]96-mr. darcy disposal . [He]96-mr. darcy arranges the business just as [he]96-mr. darcy pleases . ”[88-elizabeth] “ And if not able to please [himself]96-mr. darcy in the arrangement , [he]96-mr. darcy has at least great pleasure in the power of choice . [I]88-elizabeth do not know anybody who seems more to enjoy the power of doing what [he]96-mr. darcy likes than [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy . ”[88-elizabeth] “ [He]96-mr. darcy likes to have [his]96-mr. darcy own way very well , ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] replied [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam . “ But so [we]1540-they all do . It is only that [he]96-mr. darcy has better means of having it than [many others]4238-many others , because [he]96-mr. darcy is rich , and [many others]4238-many others are poor . [I]172-colonel fitzwilliam speak feelingly . [A younger son]4240-a younger son , [you]88-elizabeth know , must be inured to self - denial and dependence . ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] “ In [my]88-elizabeth opinion , [the younger son of an earl]4241-the younger son of an earl can know very little of either . Now , seriously , what have [you]88-elizabeth ever known of self - denial and dependence ? When have [you]88-elizabeth been prevented by want of money from going wherever [you]88-elizabeth chose or procuring anything [you]88-elizabeth had a fancy for ? ”[88-elizabeth] “ These are [home]3288-home questions -- and perhaps [I]88-elizabeth can not say that [I]88-elizabeth have experienced many hardships of that nature . But in matters of greater weight , [I]88-elizabeth may suffer from the want of money . [Younger sons]4243-younger sons can not marry where [they]4243-younger sons like . ”[88-elizabeth] “ Unless where [they]4243-younger sons like [women of fortune]4244-women of fortune , which [I]172-colonel fitzwilliam think [they]4243-younger sons very often do . ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] “ [Our]4245-our habits of expense make [us]4245-our too dependent , and there are not many in [my]88-elizabeth [rank of life who can afford to marry without some attention to money]4246-rank of life who can afford to marry without some attention to money . ”[88-elizabeth] “ Is this , ”[88-elizabeth] thought [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , “ meant for [me]88-elizabeth ? ”[88-elizabeth] and [she]88-elizabeth coloured at the idea ; but , recovering [herself]88-elizabeth , said in a lively tone , “ And pray , what is the usual price of [[an earl]4247-an earl ’s younger son]4248-an earl ’s younger son ? Unless [the elder brother]4249-the elder brother is very sickly , [I]88-elizabeth suppose [you]1542-you would not ask above fifty thousand pounds . ”[88-elizabeth] [He]1542-you answered [her]88-elizabeth in the same style , and the subject dropped . To interrupt a silence which might make [him]1542-you fancy [her]88-elizabeth affected with what had passed , [she]88-elizabeth soon afterwards said,-- “ [I]88-elizabeth imagine [[your]1542-you cousin]4182-your cousin brought [you]1542-you down with [him]4182-your cousin chiefly for the sake of having [somebody]837-somebody at [his]4182-your cousin disposal . [I]88-elizabeth wonder [he]4182-your cousin does not marry , to secure a lasting convenience of that kind . But , perhaps , [[his]4182-your cousin sister]565-his sister does as well for the present ; and , as [she]565-his sister is under [his]4182-your cousin sole care , [he]4182-your cousin may do what [he]4182-your cousin likes with [her]565-his sister . ”[88-elizabeth] “ No , ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] said [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam , “ that is an advantage which [he]4182-your cousin must divide with [me]172-colonel fitzwilliam . [I]172-colonel fitzwilliam am joined with [him]4182-your cousin in the guardianship of [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy . ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] “ Are [you]1542-you , indeed ? And pray what sort of [a guardian]4253-a guardian do [you]1542-you make ? Does [your]1542-you charge give [you]1542-you much trouble ? [Young ladies of [her]128-miss darcy age]4254-young ladies of her age are sometimes a little difficult to manage ; and if [she]128-miss darcy has the true Darcy spirit , [she]128-miss darcy may like to have [her]128-miss darcy own way . ”[1544-you] As [she]1543-i spoke , [she]1543-i observed [him]1544-you looking at [her]1543-i earnestly ; and the manner in which [he]1544-you immediately asked [her]1543-i why [she]1543-i supposed [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy likely to give [them]1545-them any uneasiness , convinced [her]1543-i that [she]1543-i had somehow or other got pretty near the truth . [She]1543-i directly replied,-- “ [You]1544-you need not be frightened . [I]1543-i never heard any harm of [her]128-miss darcy ; and [I]1543-i dare say [she]128-miss darcy is one of the most tractable creatures in [the world]304-the world . [She]128-miss darcy is a very great favourite with [some ladies of [my]1543-i acquaintance]4256-some ladies of my acquaintance , [Mrs. Hurst]97-mrs. hurst and [Miss Bingley]98-miss bingley . [I]1543-i think [I]1543-i have heard [you]1544-you say that [you]1544-you know [them]4256-some ladies of my acquaintance . ”[1543-i] “ [I]1543-i know [them]4256-some ladies of my acquaintance a little . [[Their]4256-some ladies of my acquaintance brother]338-their brother is [a pleasant , gentlemanlike man]4258-a pleasant , gentlemanlike man -- [he]338-their brother is [a great friend of [Darcy]128-miss darcy ’s]4259-a great friend of darcy ’s . ”[1543-i] “ Oh yes , ”[88-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth drily--“Mr . [Darcy]128-miss darcy is uncommonly kind to [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley , and takes a prodigious deal of care of [him]85-mr. bingley . ”[1543-i] “ Care of [him]85-mr. bingley ! Yes , [I]1543-i really believe [Darcy]128-miss darcy does take care of [him]85-mr. bingley in those points where [he]85-mr. bingley most wants care . From something that [he]85-mr. bingley told [me]1543-i in [our]4260-our journey hither , [I]1543-i have reason to think [Bingley]85-mr. bingley very much indebted to [him]85-mr. bingley . But [I]1543-i ought to beg [his]85-mr. bingley pardon , for [I]1543-i have no right to suppose that [Bingley]85-mr. bingley was [the person]4261-the person meant . It was all conjecture . ”[1543-i] “ What is it [you]1543-i mean ? ”[1543-i] “ It is a circumstance which [Darcy]128-miss darcy of course could not wish to be generally known , because if it were to get round to [[the lady]590-the lady ’s family]4263-the lady ’s family it would be an unpleasant thing . ”[1543-i] “ [You]1543-i may depend upon [my]1543-i not mentioning it . ”[1543-i] “ And remember that [I]1543-i have not much reason for supposing it to be [Bingley]85-mr. bingley . What [he]85-mr. bingley told [me]1543-i was merely this : that [he]85-mr. bingley congratulated [himself]85-mr. bingley on having lately saved [a friend]3228-a friend from the inconveniences of a most imprudent marriage , but without mentioning names or any other particulars ; and [I]1543-i only suspected it to be [Bingley]85-mr. bingley from believing [him]85-mr. bingley [the kind of young man to get into a scrape of that sort]4265-the kind of young man to get into a scrape of that sort , and from knowing [them]4266-them to have been together the whole of last summer . ”[1543-i] “ Did [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy give [you]1543-i [his]96-mr. darcy reasons for this interference ? ”[1543-i] “ [I]1543-i understood that there were some very strong objections against [the lady]590-the lady . ”[1543-i] “ And what arts did [he]96-mr. darcy use to separate [them]4266-them ? ”[1543-i] “ [He]96-mr. darcy did not talk to [me]96-mr. darcy of [his]96-mr. darcy own arts , ”[96-mr. darcy] said [Fitzwilliam]96-mr. darcy , smiling . “ [He]96-mr. darcy only told [me]96-mr. darcy what [I]96-mr. darcy have now told [you]88-elizabeth . ”[96-mr. darcy] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth made no answer , and walked on , [her]88-elizabeth heart swelling with indignation . After watching [her]88-elizabeth a little , [Fitzwilliam]96-mr. darcy asked [her]88-elizabeth why [she]88-elizabeth was so thoughtful . “ [I]88-elizabeth am thinking of what [you]96-mr. darcy have been telling [me]88-elizabeth , ”[88-elizabeth] said [she]88-elizabeth . “ [[Your]96-mr. darcy cousin]4182-your cousin ’s conduct does not suit [my]88-elizabeth feelings . Why was [he]4182-your cousin to be [the judge]3442-the judge ? ”[88-elizabeth] “ [You]96-mr. darcy are rather disposed to call [his]4182-your cousin interference officious ? ”[96-mr. darcy] “ [I]88-elizabeth do not see what right [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy had to decide on the propriety of [[his]96-mr. darcy friend]288-his friend ’s inclination ; or why , upon [his]96-mr. darcy own judgment alone , [he]96-mr. darcy was to determine and direct in what manner [that friend]903-that friend was to be happy . But , ”[88-elizabeth] [she]88-elizabeth continued , recollecting [herself]88-elizabeth , “ as [we]1546-them know none of the particulars , it is not fair to condemn [him]4182-your cousin . It is not to be supposed that there was much affection in the case . ”[88-elizabeth] “ That is not an unnatural surmise , ”[96-mr. darcy] said [Fitzwilliam]96-mr. darcy ; “ but it is lessening the honour of [[my]96-mr. darcy cousin]3477-my cousin ’s triumph very sadly . ”[96-mr. darcy] This was spoken jestingly , but it appeared to [her]88-elizabeth so just a picture of [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , that [she]88-elizabeth would not trust [herself]88-elizabeth with an answer ; and , therefore , abruptly changing the conversation , talked on indifferent matters till [they]1546-them reached [the Parsonage]1288-the parsonage . There , shut into [[her]88-elizabeth own room]1548-her own room , as soon as [[their]1546-them visitor]1549-their visitor left [them]1546-them , [she]88-elizabeth could think without interruption of all that [she]88-elizabeth had heard . It was not to be supposed that [any other people]1550-any other people could be meant than those with whom [she]88-elizabeth was connected . There could not exist in [the world]304-the world [two men over whom [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy]1552-two men over whom mr. darcy could have such boundless influence . That [he]96-mr. darcy had been concerned in the measures taken to separate [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley and [Jane]89-jane , [she]88-elizabeth had never doubted ; but [she]88-elizabeth had always attributed to [Miss Bingley]98-miss bingley the principal design and arrangement of [them]1546-them . If [his]96-mr. darcy own vanity , however , did not mislead [him]96-mr. darcy , [he]96-mr. darcy was the cause -- [his]96-mr. darcy pride and caprice were the cause -- of all that [Jane]89-jane had suffered , and still continued to suffer . [He]96-mr. darcy had ruined for a while every hope of happiness for the most affectionate , generous heart in [the world]304-the world ; and [no one]3336-no one could say how lasting an evil [he]96-mr. darcy might have inflicted . “ There were some very strong objections against [the lady]590-the lady , ”[172-colonel fitzwilliam] were [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam ’s words ; and these strong objections probably were , [her]88-elizabeth having [one uncle who was [a country attorney]1556-a country attorney , and another who was in business in [London]5-london]1555-one uncle who was a country attorney , and another who was in business in london . “ To [Jane]89-jane [herself]89-jane , ”[88-elizabeth] [she]88-elizabeth exclaimed , “ there could be no possibility of objection,--all loveliness and goodness as [she]89-jane is ! [Her]89-jane understanding excellent , [her]89-jane mind improved , and [her]89-jane manners captivating . Neither could anything be urged against [[my]88-elizabeth father]3323-my father , who , though with some peculiarities , has abilities which [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy [himself]96-mr. darcy need not disdain , and respectability which [he]96-mr. darcy will probably never reach . ”[88-elizabeth] When [she]88-elizabeth thought of [[her]88-elizabeth mother]246-her mother , indeed , [her]88-elizabeth confidence gave way a little ; but [she]88-elizabeth would not allow that any objections there had material weight with [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , whose pride , [she]88-elizabeth was convinced , would receive a deeper wound from the want of importance in [[his]96-mr. darcy friend]288-his friend ’s connections than from [their]1559-their want of sense ; and [she]88-elizabeth was quite decided , at last , that [he]96-mr. darcy had been partly governed by this worst kind of pride , and partly by the wish of retaining [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley for [[his]96-mr. darcy sister]565-his sister . The agitation and tears which [the subject]1561-the subject occasioned brought on a headache ; and it grew so much worse towards the evening that , added to [her]88-elizabeth unwillingness to see [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , it determined [her]88-elizabeth not to attend [[her]88-elizabeth cousins]1562-her cousins to [Rosings]19-rosings , where [they]1562-her cousins were engaged to drink tea . [Mrs. Collins]166-mrs. collins , seeing that [she]166-mrs. collins was really unwell , did not press [her]166-mrs. collins to go , and as much as possible prevented [[her]166-mrs. collins husband]260-her husband from pressing [her]166-mrs. collins ; but [Mr. Collins]134-mr. collins could not conceal [his]134-mr. collins apprehension of [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine ’s being rather displeased by [her]93-lady catherine staying at [home]3288-home . [ Illustration ] CHAPTER XXXIV . [ Illustration ] When [they]1565-they were gone , [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , as if intending to exasperate [herself]88-elizabeth as much as possible against [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , chose for [her]88-elizabeth employment the examination of all the letters which [Jane]89-jane had written to [her]88-elizabeth since [her]89-jane being in [Kent]17-kent . They contained no actual complaint , nor was there any revival of past occurrences , or any communication of present suffering . But in all , and in almost every line of each , there was a want of that cheerfulness which had been used to characterize [her]88-elizabeth style , and which , proceeding from the serenity of a mind at ease with itself , and kindly disposed towards [everyone]3873-everyone , had been scarcely ever clouded . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth noticed every sentence conveying the idea of uneasiness , with an attention which it had hardly received on the first perusal . [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s shameful boast of what misery [he]96-mr. darcy had been able to inflict gave [her]88-elizabeth a keener sense of [[her]88-elizabeth sister]328-her sister ’s sufferings . It was some consolation to think that [his]96-mr. darcy visit to [Rosings]19-rosings was to end on the day after the next , and a still greater that in less than a fortnight [she]88-elizabeth should [herself]88-elizabeth be with [Jane]89-jane again , and enabled to contribute to the recovery of [her]88-elizabeth spirits , by all that affection could do . [She]88-elizabeth could not think of [Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s leaving [Kent]17-kent without remembering that [[his]96-mr. darcy cousin]3538-his cousin was to go with [him]96-mr. darcy ; but [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam had made it clear that [he]96-mr. darcy had no intentions at all , and , agreeable as [he]96-mr. darcy was , [she]88-elizabeth did not mean to be unhappy about [him]96-mr. darcy . While settling this point , [she]88-elizabeth was suddenly roused by the sound of the door - bell ; and [her]88-elizabeth spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its being [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam [himself]96-mr. darcy , who had once before called late in the evening , and might now come to inquire particularly after [her]88-elizabeth . But this idea was soon banished , and [her]88-elizabeth spirits were very differently affected , when , to [her]88-elizabeth utter amazement , [she]88-elizabeth saw [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy walk into [the room]255-the room . In a hurried manner [he]96-mr. darcy immediately began an inquiry after [her]88-elizabeth health , imputing [his]96-mr. darcy visit to a wish of hearing that [she]88-elizabeth were better . [She]88-elizabeth answered [him]96-mr. darcy with cold civility . [He]96-mr. darcy sat down for a few moments , and then getting up walked about [the room]255-the room . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was surprised , but said not a word . After a silence of several minutes , [he]96-mr. darcy came towards [her]88-elizabeth in an agitated manner , and thus began - “ In vain have [I]96-mr. darcy struggled . It will not do . [My]96-mr. darcy feelings will not be repressed . [You]88-elizabeth must allow [me]96-mr. darcy to tell [you]88-elizabeth how ardently [I]96-mr. darcy admire and love [you]88-elizabeth . ”[96-mr. darcy] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s astonishment was beyond expression . [She]88-elizabeth stared , coloured , doubted , and was silent . This [he]96-mr. darcy considered sufficient encouragement , and the avowal of all that [he]96-mr. darcy felt and had long felt for [her]88-elizabeth immediately followed . [He]96-mr. darcy spoke well ; but there were feelings besides those of the heart to be detailed , and [he]96-mr. darcy was not more eloquent on the subject of tenderness than of pride . [His]96-mr. darcy sense of [her]88-elizabeth inferiority , of its being a degradation , of the family obstacles which judgment had always opposed to inclination , were dwelt on with a warmth which seemed due to the consequence [he]96-mr. darcy was wounding , but was very unlikely to recommend [his]96-mr. darcy suit . In spite of [her]88-elizabeth deeply - rooted dislike , [she]88-elizabeth could not be insensible to the compliment of [such a man]230-such a man ’s affection , and though [her]88-elizabeth intentions did not vary for an instant , [she]88-elizabeth was at first sorry for the pain [he]96-mr. darcy was to receive ; till roused to resentment by [his]96-mr. darcy subsequent language , [she]88-elizabeth lost all compassion in anger . [She]88-elizabeth tried , however , to compose [herself]88-elizabeth to answer [him]96-mr. darcy with patience , when [he]96-mr. darcy should have done . [He]96-mr. darcy concluded with representing to [her]88-elizabeth the strength of that attachment which in spite of all [his]96-mr. darcy endeavours [he]96-mr. darcy had found impossible to conquer ; and with expressing [his]96-mr. darcy hope that it would now be rewarded by [her]88-elizabeth acceptance of [his]96-mr. darcy hand . As [he]96-mr. darcy said this [she]88-elizabeth could easily see that [he]96-mr. darcy had no doubt of a favourable answer . [He]96-mr. darcy spoke of apprehension and anxiety , but [his]96-mr. darcy countenance expressed real security . Such a circumstance could only exasperate farther ; and when [he]96-mr. darcy ceased the colour rose into [her]88-elizabeth cheeks and [she]88-elizabeth said,-- “ In such cases as this , it is , [I]88-elizabeth believe , the established mode to express a sense of obligation for the sentiments avowed , however unequally they may be returned . It is natural that obligation should be felt , and if [I]88-elizabeth could feel gratitude , [I]88-elizabeth would now thank [you]96-mr. darcy . But [I]88-elizabeth cannot -- [I]88-elizabeth have never desired [your]96-mr. darcy good opinion , and [you]96-mr. darcy have certainly bestowed it most unwillingly . [I]88-elizabeth am sorry to have occasioned pain to [anyone]3174-anyone . It has been most unconsciously done , however , and [I]88-elizabeth hope will be of short duration . The feelings which [you]96-mr. darcy tell [me]88-elizabeth have long prevented the acknowledgment of [your]96-mr. darcy regard can have little difficulty in overcoming it after this explanation . ”[88-elizabeth] [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , who was leaning against the mantel - piece with [his]96-mr. darcy eyes fixed on [her]88-elizabeth face , seemed to catch [her]88-elizabeth words with no less resentment than surprise . [His]96-mr. darcy complexion became pale with anger , and the disturbance of [his]96-mr. darcy mind was visible in every feature . [He]96-mr. darcy was struggling for the appearance of composure , and would not open [his]96-mr. darcy lips till [he]96-mr. darcy believed [himself]96-mr. darcy to have attained it . The pause was to [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s feelings dreadful . At length , in a voice of forced calmness , [he]96-mr. darcy said,-- “ And this is all the reply which [I]96-mr. darcy am to have the honour of expecting ! [I]96-mr. darcy might , perhaps , wish to be informed why , with so little endeavour at civility , [I]96-mr. darcy am thus rejected . But it is of small importance . ”[96-mr. darcy] “ [I]88-elizabeth might as well inquire , ”[88-elizabeth] replied [she]88-elizabeth , “ why , with so evident a design of offending and insulting [me]88-elizabeth , [you]96-mr. darcy chose to tell [me]88-elizabeth that [you]96-mr. darcy liked [me]88-elizabeth against [your]96-mr. darcy will , against [your]96-mr. darcy reason , and even against [your]96-mr. darcy character ? Was not this some excuse for incivility , if [I]88-elizabeth was uncivil ? But [I]88-elizabeth have other provocations . [You]96-mr. darcy know [I]88-elizabeth have . Had not [my]88-elizabeth own feelings decided against [you]96-mr. darcy , had [they]4276-they been indifferent , or had they even been favourable , do [you]96-mr. darcy think that any consideration would tempt [me]88-elizabeth to accept [the man who has been the means of ruining , perhaps for ever , the happiness of [a most beloved sister]4278-a most beloved sister]4277-the man who has been the means of ruining , perhaps for ever , the happiness of a most beloved sister ? ”[88-elizabeth] As [she]88-elizabeth pronounced these words , [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy changed colour ; but the emotion was short , and [he]96-mr. darcy listened without attempting to interrupt [her]88-elizabeth while [she]88-elizabeth continued,-- “ [I]88-elizabeth have every reason in [the world]304-the world to think ill of [you]96-mr. darcy . No motive can excuse the unjust and ungenerous part [you]96-mr. darcy acted there . [You]96-mr. darcy dare not , [you]96-mr. darcy can not deny that [you]96-mr. darcy have been [the principal]4280-the principal , if not the only means of dividing [them]4281-them from each other , of exposing one to the censure of [the world]304-the world for caprice and instability , [the other]3427-the other to its derision for disappointed hopes , and involving [them]4281-them both in misery of the acutest kind . ”[88-elizabeth] [She]88-elizabeth paused , and saw with no slight indignation that [he]96-mr. darcy was listening with an air which proved [him]96-mr. darcy wholly unmoved by any feeling of remorse . [He]96-mr. darcy even looked at [her]88-elizabeth with a smile of affected incredulity . “ Can [you]96-mr. darcy deny that [you]96-mr. darcy have done it ? ”[88-elizabeth] [she]88-elizabeth repeated . With assumed tranquillity [he]96-mr. darcy then replied , “ [I]96-mr. darcy have no wish of denying that [I]96-mr. darcy did everything in [my]96-mr. darcy power to separate [[my]96-mr. darcy friend]3416-my friend from [[your]88-elizabeth sister]3211-your sister , or that [I]96-mr. darcy rejoice in [my]96-mr. darcy success . Towards [him]3416-my friend [I]96-mr. darcy have been kinder than towards [myself]96-mr. darcy . ”[96-mr. darcy] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth disdained the appearance of noticing this civil reflection , but its meaning did not escape , nor was it likely to conciliate [her]88-elizabeth . “ But it is not merely this affair , ”[88-elizabeth] [she]88-elizabeth continued , “ on which [my]88-elizabeth dislike is founded . Long before it had taken place , [my]88-elizabeth opinion of [you]88-elizabeth was decided . [Your]88-elizabeth character was unfolded in the recital which [I]88-elizabeth received many months ago from [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham . On this subject , what can [you]88-elizabeth have to say ? In what imaginary act of friendship can [you]88-elizabeth here defend [yourself]88-elizabeth ? or under what misrepresentation can [you]88-elizabeth here impose upon [others]3175-others ? ”[88-elizabeth] “ [You]88-elizabeth take an eager interest in [that gentleman]3371-that gentleman ’s concerns , ”[96-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]96-mr. darcy , in a less tranquil tone , and with a heightened colour . “ Who that knows what [his]3371-that gentleman misfortunes have been can help feeling an interest in [him]3371-that gentleman ? ”[96-mr. darcy] “ [His]3371-that gentleman misfortunes ! ”[96-mr. darcy] repeated [Darcy]96-mr. darcy , contemptuously,--“yes , [his]3371-that gentleman misfortunes have been great indeed . ”[96-mr. darcy] “ And of [your]96-mr. darcy infliction , ”[88-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , with energy ; “ [You]96-mr. darcy have reduced [him]3371-that gentleman to [his]3371-that gentleman present state of poverty -- comparative poverty . [You]96-mr. darcy have withheld the advantages which [you]96-mr. darcy must know to have been designed for [him]3371-that gentleman . [You]96-mr. darcy have deprived the best years of [his]3371-that gentleman life of that independence which was no less [his]3371-that gentleman due than [his]3371-that gentleman desert . [You]96-mr. darcy have done all this ! and yet [you]96-mr. darcy can treat the mention of [his]3371-that gentleman misfortunes with contempt and ridicule . ”[88-elizabeth] “ And this , ”[96-mr. darcy] cried [Darcy]96-mr. darcy , as [he]96-mr. darcy walked with quick steps across [the room]255-the room , “ is [your]1573-you opinion of [me]96-mr. darcy ! This is the estimation in which [you]1573-you hold [me]96-mr. darcy ! [I]96-mr. darcy thank [you]1573-you for explaining it so fully . [My]96-mr. darcy faults , according to this calculation , are heavy indeed ! But , perhaps , ”[96-mr. darcy] added [he]96-mr. darcy , stopping in [his]96-mr. darcy walk , and turning towards [her]1573-you , “ these offences might have been overlooked , had not [your]1573-you pride been hurt by [my]96-mr. darcy honest confession of the scruples that had long prevented [my]96-mr. darcy forming any serious design . These bitter accusations might have been suppressed , had [I]96-mr. darcy , with greater policy , concealed [my]96-mr. darcy struggles , and flattered [you]1573-you into the belief of [my]96-mr. darcy being impelled by unqualified , unalloyed inclination ; by reason , by reflection , by everything . But disguise of every sort is [my]96-mr. darcy abhorrence . Nor am [I]96-mr. darcy ashamed of the feelings [I]96-mr. darcy related . They were natural and just . Could [you]1573-you expect [me]96-mr. darcy to rejoice in the inferiority of [your]1573-you connections -to congratulate [myself]96-mr. darcy on the hope of relations whose condition in life is so decidedly beneath [my]96-mr. darcy own ? ”[96-mr. darcy] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth felt [herself]88-elizabeth growing more angry every moment ; yet [she]88-elizabeth tried to the utmost to speak with composure when [she]88-elizabeth said,-- “ [You]1574-you are mistaken , [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , if [you]1574-you suppose that the mode of [your]1574-you declaration affected [me]88-elizabeth in any other way than as it spared [me]88-elizabeth the concern which [I]88-elizabeth might have felt in refusing [you]1574-you , had [you]1574-you behaved in a more gentlemanlike manner . ”[88-elizabeth] [She]88-elizabeth saw [him]1574-you start at this ; but [he]1574-you said nothing , and [she]88-elizabeth continued,-- “ [You]1574-you could not have made [me]88-elizabeth the offer of [your]1574-you hand in any possible way that would have tempted [me]88-elizabeth to accept it . ”[88-elizabeth] Again [his]1574-you astonishment was obvious ; and [he]1574-you looked at [her]88-elizabeth with an expression of mingled incredulity and mortification . [She]88-elizabeth went on,-- “ From the very beginning , from the first moment , [I]88-elizabeth may almost say , of [my]88-elizabeth acquaintance with [you]1574-you , [your]1574-you manners impressing [me]88-elizabeth with the fullest belief of [your]1574-you arrogance , [your]1574-you conceit , and [your]1574-you selfish disdain of the feelings of [others]3175-others , were such as to form that groundwork of disapprobation , on which succeeding events have built so immovable a dislike ; and [I]88-elizabeth had not known [you]1574-you a month before [I]88-elizabeth felt that [you]1574-you were [the last man in [the world]304-the world whom [I]88-elizabeth could ever be prevailed on to marry]4289-the last man in the world whom i could ever be prevailed on to marry . ”[88-elizabeth] “ [You]1574-you have said quite enough , [madam]3346-madam . [I]1575-his perfectly comprehend [your]3346-madam feelings , and have now only to be ashamed of what [my]1575-his own have been . Forgive [me]1575-his for having taken up so much of [your]3346-madam time , and accept [my]1575-his best wishes for [your]3346-madam health and happiness . ”[1575-his] And with these words [he]1575-his hastily left [the room]255-the room , and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth heard [him]1575-his the next moment open the front door and quit [the house]3075-the house . The tumult of [her]88-elizabeth mind was now painfully great . [She]88-elizabeth knew not how to support [herself]88-elizabeth , and , from actual weakness , sat down and cried for half an hour . [Her]88-elizabeth astonishment , as [she]88-elizabeth reflected on what had passed , was increased by every review of it . That [she]88-elizabeth should receive an offer of marriage from [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ! that [he]1575-his should have been in love with [her]88-elizabeth for so many months ! so much in love as to wish to marry [her]88-elizabeth in spite of all the objections which had made [him]1575-his prevent [[his]1575-his friend]288-his friend ’s marrying [[her]88-elizabeth sister]328-her sister , and which must appear at least with equal force in [his]1575-his own case , was almost incredible ! it was gratifying to have inspired unconsciously so strong an affection . But [his]1575-his pride , [his]1575-his abominable pride , [his]1575-his shameless avowal of what [he]1575-his had done with respect to [Jane]89-jane , [his]1575-his unpardonable assurance in acknowledging , though [he]1575-his could not justify it , and the unfeeling manner which [he]1575-his had mentioned [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham , [his]1575-his cruelty towards whom [he]1575-his had not attempted to deny , soon overcame the pity which the consideration of [his]1575-his attachment had for a moment excited . [She]88-elizabeth continued in very agitating reflections till the sound of [Lady Catherine]93-lady catherine ’s carriage made [her]88-elizabeth feel how unequal [she]88-elizabeth was to encounter [Charlotte]107-charlotte ’s observation , and hurried [her]88-elizabeth away to [[her]88-elizabeth room]493-her room . [ Illustration : “ Hearing [herself]88-elizabeth called ”[93-lady catherine] ] CHAPTER XXXV . [ Illustration ] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth awoke the next morning to the same thoughts and meditations which had at length closed [her]88-elizabeth eyes . [She]88-elizabeth could not yet recover from the surprise of what had happened : it was impossible to think of anything else ; and , totally indisposed for employment , [she]88-elizabeth resolved soon after breakfast to indulge [herself]88-elizabeth in air and exercise . [She]88-elizabeth was proceeding directly to [her]88-elizabeth favourite walk , when the recollection of [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s sometimes coming [there]306-there stopped [her]88-elizabeth , and instead of entering [the park]1317-the park , [she]88-elizabeth turned up [the lane]3884-the lane which led [her]88-elizabeth farther from [the turnpike road]1584-the turnpike road . [The park paling]1585-the park paling was still the boundary on one side , and [she]88-elizabeth soon passed one of the gates into the ground . After walking two or three times along that part of [the lane]3884-the lane , [she]88-elizabeth was tempted , by the pleasantness of the morning , to stop at the gates and look into [the park]1317-the park . The five weeks which [she]88-elizabeth had now passed in [Kent]17-kent had made a great difference in [the country]448-the country , and every day was adding to the verdure of the early trees . [She]88-elizabeth was on the point of continuing [her]88-elizabeth walk , when [she]88-elizabeth caught a glimpse of [a gentleman within [the sort of grove which edged [the park]1317-the park]1590-the sort of grove which edged the park]1589-a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park : [he]1589-a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park was moving that way ; and fearful of its being [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , [she]88-elizabeth was directly retreating . But [the person who advanced]1592-the person who advanced was now near enough to see [her]88-elizabeth , and stepping forward with eagerness , pronounced [her]88-elizabeth name . [She]88-elizabeth had turned away ; but on hearing [herself]88-elizabeth called , though in a voice which proved it to be [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , [she]88-elizabeth moved again towards the gate . [He]96-mr. darcy had by that time reached [it]1593-it also ; and , holding out a letter , which [she]88-elizabeth instinctively took , said , with a look of haughty composure , “ [I]88-elizabeth have been walking in [the grove]4292-the grove some time , in the hope of meeting [you]88-elizabeth . Will [you]88-elizabeth do [me]88-elizabeth the honour of reading that letter ? ”[88-elizabeth] and then , with a slight bow , turned again into [the plantation]1594-the plantation , and was soon out of sight . With no expectation of pleasure , but with the strongest curiosity , [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth opened the letter , and to [her]88-elizabeth still increasing wonder , perceived an envelope containing two sheets of letter paper , written quite through , in a very close hand . The envelope itself was likewise full . Pursuing [her]88-elizabeth way along [the lane]3884-the lane , [she]88-elizabeth then began it . It was dated from Rosings , at eight o’clock in the morning , and was as follows - “ Be not alarmed , [madam]3346-madam , on receiving this letter , by the apprehension of its containing any repetition of those sentiments , or renewal of those offers , which were last night so disgusting to [you]3346-madam . [I]88-elizabeth write without any intention of paining [you]3346-madam , or humbling [myself]88-elizabeth , by dwelling on wishes , which , for the happiness of both , can not be too soon forgotten ; and the effort which the formation and the perusal of this letter must occasion , should have been spared , had not [my]88-elizabeth character required it to be written and read . [You]1596-your must , therefore , pardon the freedom with which [I]88-elizabeth demand [your]1596-your attention ; [your]1596-your feelings , [I]88-elizabeth know , will bestow it unwillingly , but [I]88-elizabeth demand it of [your]1596-your justice . “[88-elizabeth] Two offences of a very different nature , and by no means of equal magnitude , [you]1596-your last night laid to [my]0-i charge . The first mentioned was , that , regardless of the sentiments of either , [I]0-i had detached [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley from [your]1596-your sister,--and the other , that [I]0-i had , in defiance of various claims , in defiance of honour and humanity , ruined the immediate prosperity and blasted the prospects of [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham . Wilfully and wantonly to have thrown off the companion of [my]0-i youth , [the acknowledged favourite of [[my]0-i father]3323-my father , [a young man who had scarcely any other dependence than on [our]1600-our patronage , and who had been brought up to expect its exertion]1599-a young man who had scarcely any other dependence than on our patronage , and who had been brought up to expect its exertion , would be a depravity , to which the separation of [two young persons whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks]1601-two young persons whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks , could bear no comparison . But from the severity of that blame which was last night so liberally bestowed , respecting each circumstance , [I]0-i shall hope to be in future secured , when the following account of [my]0-i actions and their motives has been read]1597-the acknowledged favourite of my father , a young man who had scarcely any other dependence than on our patronage , and who had been brought up to expect its exertion , would be a depravity , to which the separation of two young persons whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks , could bear no comparison . but from the severity of that blame which was last night so liberally bestowed , respecting each circumstance , i shall hope to be in future secured , when the following account of my actions and their motives has been read . If , in the explanation of them which is due to [myself]0-i , [I]0-i am under the necessity of relating feelings which may be offensive to [yours]1596-your , [I]0-i can only say that [I]0-i am sorry . The necessity must be obeyed , and further apology would be absurd . [I]0-i had not been long in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire before [I]0-i saw , in common with [others]3175-others , that [Bingley]85-mr. bingley preferred [[your]1596-your elder sister]1603-your elder sister to [any other young woman in [the country]448-the country]1604-any other young woman in the country . But it was not till the evening of the dance at [Netherfield]2-netherfield that [I]0-i had any apprehension of [his]85-mr. bingley feeling a serious attachment . [I]0-i had often seen [him]85-mr. bingley in love before . At that ball , while [I]0-i had the honour of dancing with [you]1596-your , [I]0-i was first made acquainted , by [Sir William Lucas]86-sir william ’s accidental information , that [Bingley]85-mr. bingley ’s attentions to [[your]1596-your sister]3211-your sister had given rise to a general expectation of [their]1607-their marriage . [He]85-mr. bingley spoke of it as a certain event , of which the time alone could be undecided . From that moment [I]0-i observed [[my]0-i friend]3416-my friend ’s behaviour attentively ; and [I]0-i could then perceive that [his]85-mr. bingley partiality for [Miss Bennet]88-elizabeth was beyond what [I]0-i had ever witnessed in [him]85-mr. bingley . [[Your]1596-your sister]3211-your sister [I]0-i also watched . [Her]3211-your sister look and manners were open , cheerful , and engaging as ever , but without any symptom of peculiar regard ; and [I]0-i remained convinced , from the evening ’s scrutiny , that though [she]3211-your sister received [his]85-mr. bingley attentions with pleasure , [she]3211-your sister did not invite [them]1610-them by any participation of sentiment . If [you]1596-your have not been mistaken here , [I]0-i must have been in an error . [Your]1596-your superior knowledge of [[your]1596-your sister]3211-your sister must make the latter probable . If it be so , if [I]0-i have been misled by such error to inflict pain on [her]3211-your sister , [your]1596-your resentment has not been unreasonable . But [I]0-i shall not scruple to assert , that the serenity of [[your]1596-your sister]3211-your sister ’s countenance and air was such as might have given [the most acute observer]1613-the most acute observer a conviction that , however amiable [her]3211-your sister temper , [her]3211-your sister heart was not likely to be easily touched . That [I]0-i was desirous of believing [her]3211-your sister indifferent is certain ; but [I]0-i will venture to say that [my]0-i investigations and decisions are not usually influenced by [my]0-i hopes or fears . [I]0-i did not believe [her]3211-your sister to be indifferent because [I]0-i wished it ; [I]0-i believed it on impartial conviction , as truly as [I]0-i wished it in reason . [My]0-i objections to the marriage were not merely those which [I]0-i last night acknowledged to have required the utmost force of passion to put aside in [my]0-i own case ; the want of connection could not be so great an evil to [[my]0-i friend]3416-my friend as to [me]0-i . But there were other causes of repugnance ; causes which , though still existing , and existing to an equal degree in both instances , [I]0-i had [myself]0-i endeavoured to forget , because they were not immediately before [me]0-i . These causes must be stated , though briefly . The situation of [[[your]1615-your mother]967-your mother ’s family]1617-your mother ’s family , though objectionable , was nothing in comparison of that total want of propriety so frequently , so almost uniformly betrayed by [herself]967-your mother , by [[your]1615-your three younger sisters]1618-your three younger sisters , and occasionally even by [[your]1615-your father]3292-your father -pardon me,--it pains [me]0-i to offend [you]1615-your . But amidst [your]1615-your concern for the defects of [[your]1615-your nearest relations]1620-your nearest relations , and [your]1615-your displeasure at this representation of [them]1620-your nearest relations , let it give [you]1615-your consolation to consider that to have conducted [yourselves]1615-your so as to avoid any share of the like censure is praise no less generally bestowed on [you]1615-your and [[your]1615-your eldest sister]1621-your eldest sister than it is honourable to the sense and disposition of both . [I]0-i will only say , farther , that from what passed that evening [my]0-i opinion of [all parties]1622-all parties was confirmed , and every inducement heightened , which could have led [me]0-i before to preserve [[my]0-i friend]3416-my friend from what [I]0-i esteemed a most unhappy connection . [He]3416-my friend left [Netherfield]2-netherfield for [London]5-london on the day following , as [you]1615-your , [I]0-i am certain , remember , with the design of soon returning . The part which [I]0-i acted is now to be explained . [[His]3416-my friend sisters]284-his sisters ’ uneasiness had been equally excited with [my]0-i own : [our]1625-we coincidence of feeling was soon discovered ; and , alike sensible that no time was to be lost in detaching [[their]284-his sisters brother]338-their brother , [we]1625-we shortly resolved on joining [him]338-their brother directly in [London]5-london . [We]1625-we accordingly went -- and there [I]0-i readily engaged in the office of pointing out to [[my]0-i friend]3416-my friend the certain evils of such a choice . [I]0-i described and enforced [them]1628-them earnestly . But however this remonstrance might have staggered or delayed [his]338-their brother determination , [I]0-i do not suppose that it would ultimately have prevented the marriage , had it not been seconded by the assurance , which [I]0-i hesitated not in giving , of [[your]1629-your sister]3211-your sister ’s indifference . [He]338-their brother had before believed [her]3211-your sister to return [his]338-their brother affection with sincere , if not with equal , regard . But [Bingley]85-mr. bingley has great natural modesty , with a stronger dependence on [my]0-i judgment than on [his]85-mr. bingley own . To convince [him]85-mr. bingley , therefore , that [he]85-mr. bingley had deceived [himself]85-mr. bingley was no very difficult point . To persuade [him]85-mr. bingley against returning into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , when that conviction had been given , was scarcely the work of a moment . [I]0-i can not blame [myself]0-i for having done thus much . There is but one part of [my]0-i conduct , in the whole affair , on which [I]0-i do not reflect with satisfaction ; it is that [I]0-i condescended to adopt the measures of art so far as to conceal from [him]85-mr. bingley [[your]1629-your sister]3211-your sister ’s being in [town]268-town . [I]0-i knew it [myself]0-i , as it was known to [Miss Bingley]98-miss bingley ; but [[her]3211-your sister brother]3181-her brother is even yet ignorant of it . That [they]1634-they might have met without ill consequence is , perhaps , probable ; but [his]85-mr. bingley regard did not appear to [me]0-i enough extinguished for [him]85-mr. bingley to see [her]3211-your sister without some danger . Perhaps this concealment , this disguise , was beneath [me]0-i . It is done , however , and it was done for the best . On this subject [I]0-i have nothing more to say , no other apology to offer . If [I]0-i have wounded [[your]1629-your sister]3211-your sister ’s feelings , it was unknowingly done ; and though the motives which governed [me]0-i may to [you]1629-your very naturally appear insufficient , [I]0-i have not yet learnt to condemn [them]1636-them -With respect to that other , more weighty accusation , of having injured [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham , [I]0-i can only refute it by laying before [you]1629-your the whole of [his]85-mr. bingley connection with [[my]0-i family]979-my family . Of what [he]85-mr. bingley has particularly accused [me]0-i [I]0-i am ignorant ; but of the truth of what [I]0-i shall relate [I]0-i can summon more than one witness of undoubted veracity . [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham is [the son of [a very respectable man]1639-a very respectable man , who had for many years the management of all [the Pemberley estates]1640-the pemberley estates , and whose good conduct in the discharge of [his]85-mr. bingley trust naturally inclined [[my]0-i father]3323-my father to be of service to [him]85-mr. bingley ; and on [George Wickham]149-george wickham , who was [[his]142-wickham godson]1642-his godson , [his]142-wickham kindness was therefore liberally bestowed . [[My]0-i father]3323-my father supported [him]142-wickham at [school]1644-school , and afterwards at [Cambridge]34-cambridge ; most important assistance , as [[his]142-wickham own father]1645-his own father , always poor from the extravagance of [[his]3323-my father wife]236-his wife]1638-the son of a very respectable man , who had for many years the management of all the pemberley estates , and whose good conduct in the discharge of his trust naturally inclined my father to be of service to him ; and on george wickham , who was his godson , his kindness was therefore liberally bestowed . my father supported him at school , and afterwards at cambridge ; most important assistance , as his own father , always poor from the extravagance of his wife , would have been unable to give [him]142-wickham [a gentleman]3470-a gentleman ’s education . [[My]0-i father]3323-my father was not only fond of [this young man]1191-this young man ’s society , whose manners were always engaging , [he]3323-my father had also the highest opinion of [him]1191-this young man , and hoping [the church]761-the church would be [his]3323-my father profession , intended to provide for [him]3323-my father in it . As for [myself]0-i , it is many , many years since [I]0-i first began to think of [him]1191-this young man in a very different manner . The vicious propensities , the want of principle , which [he]1191-this young man was careful to guard from the knowledge of [[his]1191-this young man best friend]792-his best friend , could not escape the observation of [a young man of nearly the same age]1652-a young man of nearly the same age with [himself]1191-this young man , and who had opportunities of seeing [him]1191-this young man in unguarded moments , which [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy could not have . Here again [I]0-i shall give [you]1653-you pain -- to what degree [you]1653-you only can tell . But whatever may be the sentiments which [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham has created , a suspicion of [their]1654-their nature shall not prevent [me]0-i from unfolding [his]142-wickham real character . It adds even another motive . [[My]0-i excellent father]1655-my excellent father died about five years ago ; and [his]142-wickham attachment to [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham was to the last so steady , that in [his]142-wickham will [he]142-wickham particularly recommended it to [me]0-i to promote [his]142-wickham advancement in the best manner that [his]142-wickham profession might allow , and if [he]142-wickham took orders , desired that [a valuable family]1656-a valuable family living might be [his]142-wickham as soon as it became vacant . There was also a legacy of one thousand pounds . [[His]142-wickham own father]1645-his own father did not long survive [mine]0-i ; and within half a year from these events [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham wrote to inform [me]0-i that , having finally resolved against taking orders , [he]142-wickham hoped [I]0-i should not think it unreasonable for [him]142-wickham to expect some more immediate pecuniary advantage , in lieu of the preferment , by which [he]142-wickham could not be benefited . [He]142-wickham had some intention , [he]142-wickham added , of studying the law , and [I]0-i must be aware that the interest of one thousand pounds would be a very insufficient support therein . [I]0-i rather wished than believed [him]142-wickham to be sincere ; but , at any rate , was perfectly ready to accede to [his]142-wickham proposal . [I]0-i knew that [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham ought not to be [a clergyman]3492-a clergyman . The business was therefore soon settled . [He]142-wickham resigned all claim to assistance in [the church]761-the church , were it possible that [he]142-wickham could ever be in a situation to receive it , and accepted in return three thousand pounds . All connection between [us]1660-us seemed now dissolved . [I]0-i thought too ill of [him]142-wickham to invite [him]142-wickham to [Pemberley]12-pemberley , or admit [[his]142-wickham society in [town]268-town]1661-his society in town . In [town]268-town , [I]0-i believe , [he]142-wickham chiefly lived , but [his]142-wickham studying the law was a mere pretence ; and being now free from all restraint , [his]142-wickham life was a life of idleness and dissipation . For about three years [I]0-i heard little of [him]142-wickham ; but on the decease of [the incumbent of the living]1664-the incumbent of the living which had been designed for [him]142-wickham , [he]142-wickham applied to [me]0-i again by letter for the presentation . [His]142-wickham circumstances , [he]142-wickham assured [me]0-i , and [I]0-i had no difficulty in believing it , were exceedingly bad . [He]142-wickham had found the law a most unprofitable study , and was now absolutely resolved on being ordained , if [I]0-i would present [him]142-wickham to [the living in question]1665-the living in question -- of which [he]142-wickham trusted there could be little doubt , as [he]142-wickham was well assured that [I]0-i had [no other person]1666-no other person to provide for , and [I]0-i could not have forgotten [[my]0-i revered father]1667-my revered father ’s intentions . [You]1668-you will hardly blame [me]0-i for refusing to comply with this entreaty , or for resisting every repetition of it . [His]142-wickham resentment was in proportion to the distress of [his]142-wickham circumstances -- and [he]142-wickham was doubtless as violent in [his]142-wickham abuse of [me]0-i to [others]3175-others as in [his]142-wickham reproaches to [myself]0-i . After this period , every appearance of acquaintance was dropped . How [he]142-wickham lived , [I]0-i know not . But last summer [he]142-wickham was again most painfully obtruded on [my]0-i notice . [I]0-i must now mention a circumstance which [I]0-i would wish to forget [myself]0-i , and which no obligation less than the present should induce [me]0-i to unfold to [any human being]1670-any human being . Having said thus much , [I]0-i feel no doubt of [your]1668-you secrecy . [[My]0-i sister , who is more than ten years [my]0-i junior]1671-my sister , who is more than ten years my junior , was left to the guardianship of [[my]0-i mother ’s nephew]1672-my mother ’s nephew , [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam , and [myself]0-i . About a year ago , [she]1671-my sister , who is more than ten years my junior was taken from [school]1644-school , and [an establishment formed for [her]1671-my sister , who is more than ten years my junior in [London]5-london]1674-an establishment formed for her in london ; and last summer [she]1671-my sister , who is more than ten years my junior went with [the lady who presided over it to [Ramsgate]35-ramsgate]1675-the lady who presided over it to ramsgate ; and thither also went [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham , undoubtedly by design ; for there proved to have been a prior acquaintance between [him]142-wickham and [Mrs. Younge]128-miss darcy , in whose character [we]1676-we were most unhappily deceived ; and by [her]128-miss darcy connivance and aid [he]142-wickham so far recommended [himself]142-wickham to [Georgiana]153-georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of [his]142-wickham kindness to [her]153-georgiana as [a child]804-a child , that [she]153-georgiana was persuaded to believe [herself]153-georgiana in love and to consent to an elopement . [She]153-georgiana was then but fifteen , which must be [her]153-georgiana excuse ; and after stating [her]153-georgiana imprudence , [I]0-i am happy to add , that [I]0-i owed the knowledge of it to [herself]153-georgiana . [I]0-i joined [them]1678-them unexpectedly a day or two before the intended elopement ; and then [Georgiana]153-georgiana , unable to support the idea of grieving and offending [a brother whom [she]153-georgiana almost looked up to as [a father]3312-a father]1679-a brother whom she almost looked up to as a father , acknowledged the whole to [me]0-i . [You]1681-you may imagine what [I]0-i felt and how [I]0-i acted . Regard for [[my]0-i sister]3345-my sister ’s credit and feelings prevented any public exposure ; but [I]0-i wrote to [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham , who left [the place]3068-the place immediately , and [Mrs. Younge]128-miss darcy was of course removed from [her]128-miss darcy charge . [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham ’s chief object was unquestionably [[my]0-i sister]3345-my sister ’s fortune , which is thirty thousand pounds ; but [I]0-i can not help supposing that the hope of revenging [himself]142-wickham on [me]0-i was a strong inducement . [His]142-wickham revenge would have been complete indeed .
