Let [us]4444-us hope , therefore , that [her]90-lydia being [there]306-there may teach [her]90-lydia [her]90-lydia own insignificance . At any rate , [she]90-lydia can not grow many degrees worse , without authorizing [us]4444-us to lock [her]90-lydia up for the rest of [her]90-lydia life . ”[81-mr. bennet] With this answer [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was forced to be content ; but [her]88-elizabeth own opinion continued the same , and [she]88-elizabeth left [him]1857-him disappointed and sorry . It was not in [her]88-elizabeth nature , however , to increase [her]88-elizabeth vexations by dwelling on them . [She]88-elizabeth was confident of having performed [her]88-elizabeth duty ; and to fret over unavoidable evils , or augment them by anxiety , was no part of [her]88-elizabeth disposition . Had [Lydia]90-lydia and [[her]90-lydia mother]246-her mother known the substance of [her]90-lydia conference with [[her]90-lydia father]249-her father , [their]1860-their indignation would hardly have found expression in [their]1860-their united volubility . In [Lydia]90-lydia ’s imagination , a visit to [Brighton]36-brighton comprised every possibility of earthly happiness . [She]90-lydia saw , with the creative eye of fancy , [the streets of [that gay bathing - place covered with [officers]456-officers]1862-that gay bathing - place covered with officers]1861-the streets of that gay bathing - place covered with officers . [She]90-lydia saw [herself]90-lydia the object of attention to [tens]1864-tens and to scores of [them]1864-tens at present unknown . [She]90-lydia saw all the glories of [the camp]1865-the camp : [its]1865-the camp tents stretched forth in beauteous uniformity of lines , crowded with [the young]1866-the young and [the gay , and dazzling with scarlet]1867-the gay , and dazzling with scarlet ; and , to complete the view , [she]90-lydia saw [herself]90-lydia seated beneath [a tent]1868-a tent , tenderly flirting with [at least six officers]1869-at least six officers at once . [ Illustration : “ Tenderly flirting ”[90-lydia] Had [she]90-lydia known that [[her]90-lydia sister]328-her sister sought to tear [her]90-lydia from such prospects and such realities as these , what would have been [her]90-lydia sensations ? They could have been understood only by [[her]90-lydia mother]246-her mother , who might have felt nearly the same . [Lydia]90-lydia ’s going to [Brighton]36-brighton was all that consoled [her]90-lydia for the melancholy conviction of [[her]90-lydia husband]260-her husband ’s never intending to go [there]306-there [himself]260-her husband . But [they]1874-their were entirely ignorant of what had passed ; and [their]1874-their raptures continued , with little intermission , to the very day of [Lydia]90-lydia ’s leaving [home]3288-home . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was now to see [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham for the last time . Having been frequently in company with [him]142-wickham since [her]88-elizabeth return , agitation was pretty well over ; the agitations of former partiality entirely so . [She]88-elizabeth had even learnt to detect , in the very gentleness which had first delighted [her]88-elizabeth , an affectation and a sameness to disgust and weary . In [his]142-wickham present behaviour to [herself]88-elizabeth , moreover , [she]88-elizabeth had a fresh source of displeasure ; for the inclination [he]142-wickham soon testified of renewing those attentions which had marked the early part of [their]1874-their acquaintance could only serve , after what had since passed , to provoke [her]88-elizabeth . [She]88-elizabeth lost all concern for [him]142-wickham in finding [herself]88-elizabeth thus selected as the object of such idle and frivolous gallantry ; and while [she]88-elizabeth steadily repressed it , could not but feel the reproof contained in [his]142-wickham believing , that however long , and for whatever cause , [his]142-wickham attentions had been withdrawn , [her]88-elizabeth vanity would be gratified , and [her]88-elizabeth preference secured , at any time , by [their]1874-their renewal . On the very last day of [the regiment]654-the regiment ’s remaining in [Meryton]9-meryton , [he]142-wickham dined , with [others of [the officers]452-the officers]1877-others of the officers , at [Longbourn]7-longbourn ; and so little was [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth disposed to part from [him]142-wickham in good - humour , that , on [his]142-wickham making some inquiry as to the manner in which [her]88-elizabeth time had passed at [Hunsford]15-hunsford , [she]88-elizabeth mentioned [Colonel Fitzwilliam]172-colonel fitzwilliam ’s and [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s having both spent three weeks at [Rosings]19-rosings , and asked [him]142-wickham if [he]142-wickham were acquainted with [the former]327-the former . [He]142-wickham looked surprised , displeased , alarmed ; but , with a moment ’s recollection , and a returning smile , replied , that [he]142-wickham had formerly seen [him]142-wickham often ; and , after observing that [he]142-wickham was [a very gentlemanlike man]1880-a very gentlemanlike man , asked [her]88-elizabeth how [she]88-elizabeth had liked [him]142-wickham . [Her]88-elizabeth answer was warmly in [his]142-wickham favour . With an air of indifference , [he]142-wickham soon afterwards added , “ How long did [you]88-elizabeth say that [he]142-wickham was at [Rosings]19-rosings ? ”[142-wickham] “ Nearly three weeks . ”[142-wickham] “ And [you]88-elizabeth saw [him]142-wickham frequently ? ”[142-wickham] “ Yes , almost every day . ”[142-wickham] “ [His]142-wickham manners are very different from [[his]142-wickham cousin]3538-his cousin ’s . ”[142-wickham] “ Yes , very different ; but [I]142-wickham think [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy improves on acquaintance . ”[142-wickham] “ Indeed ! ”[142-wickham] cried [Wickham]142-wickham , with a look which did not escape [her]88-elizabeth . “ And pray may [I]142-wickham ask-- ”[142-wickham] but checking [himself]142-wickham , [he]142-wickham added , in a gayer tone , “ Is it in address that [he]142-wickham improves ? Has [he]142-wickham deigned to add aught of civility to [his]142-wickham ordinary style ? for [I]142-wickham dare not hope , ”[142-wickham] [he]142-wickham continued , in a lower and more serious tone , “ that [he]142-wickham is improved in essentials . ”[142-wickham] “ Oh , no ! ”[88-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth . “ In essentials , [I]88-elizabeth believe , [he]142-wickham is very much what [he]142-wickham ever was . ”[88-elizabeth] While [she]88-elizabeth spoke , [Wickham]142-wickham looked as if scarcely knowing whether to rejoice over [her]88-elizabeth words or to distrust their meaning . There was a something in [her]88-elizabeth countenance which made [him]142-wickham listen with an apprehensive and anxious attention , while [she]88-elizabeth added,-- “ When [I]88-elizabeth said that [he]142-wickham improved on acquaintance , [I]88-elizabeth did not mean that either [his]142-wickham mind or manners were in a state of improvement ; but that , from knowing [him]142-wickham better , [his]142-wickham disposition was better understood . ”[88-elizabeth] [Wickham]142-wickham ’s alarm now appeared in a heightened complexion and agitated look ; for a few minutes [he]142-wickham was silent ; till , shaking off [his]142-wickham embarrassment , [he]142-wickham turned to [her]88-elizabeth again , and said in the gentlest of accents,-- “ [You]88-elizabeth , who so well know [my]142-wickham feelings towards [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , will readily comprehend how sincerely [I]142-wickham must rejoice that [he]142-wickham is wise enough to assume even the appearance of what is right . [His]142-wickham pride , in that direction , may be of service , if not to [himself]142-wickham , to [many others]4238-many others , for it must deter [him]142-wickham from such foul misconduct as [I]142-wickham have suffered by . [I]142-wickham only fear that the sort of cautiousness to which [you]88-elizabeth , [I]142-wickham imagine , have been alluding , is merely adopted on [his]142-wickham visits to [[his]142-wickham aunt]3747-his aunt , of whose good opinion and judgment [he]142-wickham stands much in awe . [His]142-wickham fear of [her]3747-his aunt has always operated , [I]142-wickham know , when [they]4455-they were together ; and a good deal is to be imputed to [his]142-wickham wish of forwarding the match with [Miss de Bourgh]138-miss de bourgh , which [I]142-wickham am certain [he]142-wickham has very much at heart . ”[142-wickham] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth could not repress a smile at this , but [she]88-elizabeth answered only by a slight inclination of the head . [She]88-elizabeth saw that [he]1881-his wanted to engage [her]88-elizabeth on the old subject of [his]1881-his grievances , and [she]88-elizabeth was in no humour to indulge [him]1881-his . The rest of the evening passed with the appearance , on [his]1881-his side , of usual cheerfulness , but with no further attempt to distinguish [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ; and [they]1882-they parted at last with mutual civility , and possibly a mutual desire of never meeting again . When the party broke up , [Lydia]90-lydia returned with [Mrs. Forster]182-mrs. forster to [Meryton]9-meryton , from whence [they]1882-they were to set out early the next morning . The separation between [her]90-lydia and [[her]90-lydia family]3710-her family was rather noisy than pathetic . [Kitty]93-lady catherine was [the only one who shed tears]1884-the only one who shed tears ; but [she]93-lady catherine did weep from vexation and envy . [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet was diffuse in [her]92-mrs. bennet good wishes for the felicity of [[her]92-mrs. bennet daughter]461-her daughter , and impressive in [her]92-mrs. bennet injunctions that [she]92-mrs. bennet would not miss the opportunity of enjoying [herself]92-mrs. bennet as much as possible,--advice which there was every reason to believe would be attended to ; and , in the clamorous happiness of [Lydia]90-lydia [herself]90-lydia in bidding farewell , [the more gentle adieus of [[her]90-lydia sisters]3096-her sisters]1886-the more gentle adieus of her sisters were uttered without being heard . [ Illustration : The arrival of [the Gardiners]159-the gardiners ] CHAPTER XLII . [ Illustration ] Had [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s opinion been all drawn from [[her]88-elizabeth own family]4222-her own family , [she]88-elizabeth could not have formed a very pleasing picture of conjugal felicity or domestic comfort . [[Her]88-elizabeth father]249-her father , captivated by youth and beauty , and that appearance of good - humour which youth and beauty generally give , had married [a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in [their]1891-their marriage]1890-a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in their marriage put an end to all real affection for [her]1890-a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in their marriage . Respect , esteem , and confidence had vanished for ever ; and all [his]249-her father views of domestic happiness were overthrown . But [Mr. Bennet]81-mr. bennet was not of a disposition to seek comfort for the disappointment which [his]81-mr. bennet own imprudence had brought on in any of those pleasures which too often console [the unfortunate]1892-the unfortunate for [their]1892-the unfortunate folly or [their]1892-the unfortunate vice . [He]81-mr. bennet was fond of [the country]448-the country and of books ; and from these tastes had arisen [his]81-mr. bennet principal enjoyments . To [[his]81-mr. bennet wife]236-his wife [he]81-mr. bennet was very little otherwise indebted than as [her]236-his wife ignorance and folly had contributed to [his]81-mr. bennet amusement . This is not the sort of happiness which [a man]3114-a man would in general wish to owe to [[his]81-mr. bennet wife]236-his wife ; but where other powers of entertainment are wanting , [the true philosopher]1897-the true philosopher will derive benefit from such as are given . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , however , had never been blind to the impropriety of [[her]88-elizabeth father]249-her father ’s behaviour as [a husband]1016-a husband . [She]88-elizabeth had always seen it with pain ; but respecting [his]81-mr. bennet abilities , and grateful for [his]81-mr. bennet affectionate treatment of [herself]88-elizabeth , [she]88-elizabeth endeavoured to forget what [she]88-elizabeth could not overlook , and to banish from [her]88-elizabeth thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation and decorum which , in exposing [[his]81-mr. bennet wife]236-his wife to the contempt of [[her]88-elizabeth own children]1901-her own children , was so highly reprehensible . But [she]88-elizabeth had never felt so strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend [the children of so unsuitable a marriage]1902-the children of so unsuitable a marriage , nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising from so ill - judged a direction of talents -- talents which , rightly used , might at least have preserved the respectability of [[his]81-mr. bennet daughters]430-his daughters , even if incapable of enlarging the mind of [[his]81-mr. bennet wife]236-his wife . When [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth had rejoiced over [Wickham]142-wickham ’s departure , [she]88-elizabeth found little other cause for satisfaction in the loss of [the regiment]654-the regiment . [Their]1906-their parties abroad were less varied than before ; and at [home]3288-home [she]88-elizabeth had [a mother]1255-a mother and [sister , whose constant repinings at the dulness of everything around them]1909-sister , whose constant repinings at the dulness of everything around them threw a real gloom over [their]1906-their domestic circle ; and , though [Kitty]93-lady catherine might in time regain [her]93-lady catherine natural degree of sense , since the disturbers of [her]93-lady catherine brain were removed , [[her]88-elizabeth other sister]1910-her other sister , from whose disposition greater evil might be apprehended , was likely to be hardened in all [her]1910-her other sister folly and assurance , by a situation of such double danger as [a watering - place]1911-a watering - place and [a camp]1912-a camp . Upon the whole , therefore , [she]88-elizabeth found , what has been sometimes found before , that an event to which [she]88-elizabeth had looked forward with impatient desire , did not , in taking place , bring all the satisfaction [she]88-elizabeth had promised [herself]88-elizabeth . It was consequently necessary to name some other period for the commencement of actual felicity ; to have some other point on which [her]88-elizabeth wishes and hopes might be fixed , and by again enjoying the pleasure of anticipation , console [herself]88-elizabeth for the present , and prepare for another disappointment . [Her]88-elizabeth tour to [the Lakes]4087-the lakes was now the object of [her]88-elizabeth happiest thoughts : it was [her]88-elizabeth best consolation for all the uncomfortable hours which the discontentedness of [[her]88-elizabeth mother]246-her mother and [Kitty]93-lady catherine made inevitable ; and could [she]88-elizabeth have included [Jane]89-jane in the scheme , every part of it would have been perfect . “ But it is fortunate , ”[88-elizabeth] thought [she]88-elizabeth , “ that [I]88-elizabeth have something to wish for . Were the whole arrangement complete , [my]88-elizabeth disappointment would be certain . But here , by carrying with [me]88-elizabeth one ceaseless source of regret in [[my]88-elizabeth sister]3345-my sister ’s absence , [I]88-elizabeth may reasonably hope to have all [my]88-elizabeth expectations of pleasure realized . A scheme of which every part promises delight can never be successful ; and general disappointment is only warded off by the defence of some little peculiar vexation . ”[88-elizabeth] When [Lydia]90-lydia went away [she]90-lydia promised to write very often and very minutely to [[her]90-lydia mother]246-her mother and [Kitty]93-lady catherine ; but [her]90-lydia letters were always long expected , and always very short . Those to [[her]90-lydia mother]246-her mother contained little else than that [they]1917-they were just returned from [the library]3825-the library , where [such and such officers]1919-such and such officers had attended [them]1917-they , and where [she]90-lydia had seen such beautiful ornaments as made [her]90-lydia quite wild ; that [she]90-lydia had a new gown , or a new parasol , which [she]90-lydia would have described more fully , but was obliged to leave off in a violent hurry , as [Mrs. Forster]182-mrs. forster called [her]90-lydia , and [they]1920-they were going to [the camp]1865-the camp ; and from [her]90-lydia correspondence with [[her]90-lydia sister]328-her sister there was still less to be learnt , for [her]90-lydia letters to [Kitty]93-lady catherine , though rather longer , were much too full of lines under the words to be made public . After the first fortnight or three weeks of [her]90-lydia absence , health , good - humour , and cheerfulness began to reappear at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . Everything wore a happier aspect . [The families who had been in [town]268-town for the winter]1923-the families who had been in town for the winter came back again , and summer finery and summer engagements arose . [Mrs. Bennet]92-mrs. bennet was restored to [her]92-mrs. bennet usual querulous serenity ; and by the middle of June [Kitty]93-lady catherine was so much recovered as to be able to enter [Meryton]9-meryton without tears,--an event of such happy promise as to make [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth hope , that by the following Christmas [she]88-elizabeth might be so tolerably reasonable as not to mention [an officer]3727-an officer above once a day , unless , by some cruel and malicious arrangement at [the War Office]1926-the war office , [another regiment]1927-another regiment should be quartered in [Meryton]9-meryton . The time fixed for the beginning of [their]1928-they northern tour was now fast approaching ; and a fortnight only was wanting of it , when a letter arrived from [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner , which at once delayed its commencement and curtailed its extent . [Mr. Gardiner]157-mr. gardiner would be prevented by business from setting out till a fortnight later in July , and must be in [London]5-london again within a month ; and as that left too short a period for [them]1928-they to go so far , and see so much as [they]1928-they had proposed , or at least to see it with the leisure and comfort [they]1928-they had built on , [they]1928-they were obliged to give up [the Lakes]4087-the lakes , and substitute a more contracted tour ; and , according to the present plan , were to go no farther northward than [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire . In [that county]1930-that county there was enough to be seen to occupy the chief of [their]1928-they three weeks ; and to [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner it had a peculiarly strong attraction . [The town where [she]129-mrs. gardiner had formerly passed some years of [her]129-mrs. gardiner life , and where [they]1928-they were now to spend a few days]1931-the town where she had formerly passed some years of her life , and where they were now to spend a few days , was probably as great an object of [her]129-mrs. gardiner curiosity as [all the celebrated beauties of [Matlock]40-matlock , [Chatsworth]41-chatsworth , [Dovedale]42-dovedale]1932-all the celebrated beauties of matlock , chatsworth , dovedale , or [the Peak]43-the peak . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was excessively disappointed : [she]88-elizabeth had set [her]88-elizabeth heart on seeing [the Lakes]4087-the lakes ; and still thought there might have been time enough . But it was [her]88-elizabeth business to be satisfied -- and certainly [her]88-elizabeth temper to be happy ; and all was soon right again . With the mention of [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire , there were many ideas connected . It was impossible for [her]88-elizabeth to see the word without thinking of [Pemberley]12-pemberley and [its owner]1934-its owner . “ But surely , ”[88-elizabeth] said [she]88-elizabeth , “ [I]88-elizabeth may enter [[his]1934-its owner county]341-his county with impunity , and rob [it]341-his county of a few petrified spars , without [his]1934-its owner perceiving [me]88-elizabeth . ”[88-elizabeth] The period of expectation was now doubled . Four weeks were to pass away before [[her]88-elizabeth uncle]579-her uncle and [aunt]1241-aunt ’s arrival . But [they]1937-they did pass away , and [Mr.]1938-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner , with [[their]1939-their four children]1940-their four children , did at length appear at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . [The children]1941-the children , [two girls of six and eight years old]1942-two girls of six and eight years old , and [two younger boys]1943-two younger boys , were to be left under the particular care of [[their]1939-their cousin]3506-their cousin [Jane]89-jane , who was [the general favourite]1945-the general favourite , and whose steady sense and sweetness of temper exactly adapted [her]89-jane for attending to [them]1941-the children in every way -- teaching [them]1941-the children , playing with [them]1941-the children , and loving [them]1941-the children . [The Gardiners]159-the gardiners stayed only one night at [Longbourn]7-longbourn , and set off the next morning with [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth in pursuit of novelty and amusement . One enjoyment was certain -- that of suitableness as [companions]1946-companions ; a suitableness which comprehended health and temper to bear inconveniences -- cheerfulness to enhance every pleasure -- and affection and intelligence , which might supply it among [themselves]159-the gardiners if there were disappointments abroad . It is not the object of this work to give a description of [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire , nor of any of [the remarkable places through which [their]1939-their route thither]1947-the remarkable places through which their route thither lay -- [Oxford]44-oxford , [Blenheim]45-blenheim , [Warwick]46-warwick , [Kenilworth]47-kenilworth , [Birmingham]48-birmingham , etc . , are sufficiently known . [A small part of [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire]1948-a small part of derbyshire is all the present concern . To [the little town of]1949-the little town of [Lambton]49-lambton , [the scene of [[Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner ’s former residence]1951-mrs. gardiner ’s former residence]1950-the scene of mrs. gardiner ’s former residence , and where [she]129-mrs. gardiner had lately learned that [some acquaintance]1952-some acquaintance still remained , [they]1939-their bent [their]1939-their steps , after having seen all the principal wonders of [the country]448-the country ; and within five miles of [Lambton]49-lambton , [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth found , from [[her]88-elizabeth aunt]4017-her aunt , that [Pemberley]12-pemberley was situated . [It]12-pemberley was not in [[their]1939-their direct road]1955-their direct road ; nor more than a mile or two out of [it]12-pemberley . In talking over [their]1939-their route the evening before , [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner expressed an inclination to see [the place]3068-the place again . [Mr. Gardiner]157-mr. gardiner declared [his]157-mr. gardiner willingness , and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was applied to for [her]88-elizabeth approbation . “ [[My]4017-her aunt love]3127-my love , should not [you]3127-my love like to see [a place of which [you]3127-my love have heard so much]4459-a place of which you have heard so much ? ”[4017-her aunt] said [[her]88-elizabeth aunt]4017-her aunt . “ [A place , too , with which so many of [your]3127-my love acquaintance]4460-a place , too , with which so many of your acquaintance are connected . [Wickham]142-wickham passed all [his]142-wickham youth [there]306-there , [you]3127-my love know . ”[4017-her aunt] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was distressed . [She]88-elizabeth felt that [she]88-elizabeth had no business at [Pemberley]12-pemberley , and was obliged to assume a disinclination for seeing [it]12-pemberley . [She]88-elizabeth must own that [she]88-elizabeth was tired of [great houses]1958-great houses : after going over so many , [she]88-elizabeth really had no pleasure in fine carpets or satin curtains . [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner abused [her]129-mrs. gardiner stupidity . “ If [it]12-pemberley were merely [a fine house richly furnished]4462-a fine house richly furnished , ”[129-mrs. gardiner] said [she]129-mrs. gardiner , “ [I]129-mrs. gardiner should not care about [it]12-pemberley [myself]129-mrs. gardiner ; but [the grounds]4463-the grounds are delightful . They have some of [the finest woods in [the country]448-the country]4464-the finest woods in the country . ”[129-mrs. gardiner] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth said no more ; but [her]88-elizabeth mind could not acquiesce . The possibility of meeting [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , while viewing [the place]3068-the place , instantly occurred . It would be dreadful ! [She]88-elizabeth blushed at the very idea ; and thought it would be better to speak openly to [[her]88-elizabeth aunt]4017-her aunt , than to run such a risk . But against this there were objections ; and [she]88-elizabeth finally resolved that it could be the last resource , if [her]88-elizabeth private inquiries as to the absence of [the family]414-the family were unfavourably answered . Accordingly , when [she]88-elizabeth retired at night , [she]88-elizabeth asked [the chambermaid]1962-the chambermaid whether [Pemberley]12-pemberley were not [a very fine place]1963-a very fine place , what was the name of [[its]12-pemberley proprietor]3645-its proprietor , and , with no little alarm , whether [the family]414-the family were down for the summer ? A most welcome negative followed the last question ; and [her]88-elizabeth alarms being now removed , [she]88-elizabeth was at leisure to feel a great deal of curiosity to see [the house]3075-the house [herself]88-elizabeth ; and when the subject was revived the next morning , and [she]88-elizabeth was again applied to , could readily answer , and with a proper air of indifference , that [she]88-elizabeth had not really any dislike to the scheme . To [Pemberley]12-pemberley , therefore , [they]1967-they were to go . [ Illustration : “ Conjecturing as to the date ”[88-elizabeth] ] CHAPTER XLIII . [ Illustration ] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , as [they]1967-they drove along , watched for the first appearance of [Pemberley Woods]50-pemberley woods with some perturbation ; and when at length [they]1967-they turned in at [the lodge]1968-the lodge , [her]88-elizabeth spirits were in a high flutter . [The park]1317-the park was very large , and contained great variety of ground . [They]1967-they entered [it]1317-the park in one of [its]1317-the park lowest points , and drove for some time through a beautiful wood stretching over a wide extent . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s mind was too full for conversation , but [she]88-elizabeth saw and admired every remarkable spot and point of view . [They]1967-they gradually ascended for half a mile , and then found [themselves]1967-they at the top of [a considerable eminence]1970-a considerable eminence , where [the wood]1971-the wood ceased , and the eye was instantly caught by [Pemberley House]21-pemberley house , situated on [the opposite side of [the valley]1973-the valley]1972-the opposite side of the valley , into which [the road]1292-the road with some abruptness wound . [It]21-pemberley house was [a large , handsome stone building , standing well on rising ground , and backed by [a ridge of high woody hills]1976-a ridge of high woody hills]1975-a large , handsome stone building , standing well on rising ground , and backed by a ridge of high woody hills ; and in front a stream of some natural importance was swelled into greater , but without any artificial appearance . [Its]21-pemberley house banks were neither formal nor falsely adorned . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was delighted . [She]88-elizabeth had never seen a place for which nature had done more , or where natural beauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste . [They]1967-they were all of [them]1967-they warm in [their]1967-they admiration ; and at that moment [she]88-elizabeth felt that to be [mistress of [Pemberley]12-pemberley]1977-mistress of pemberley might be something ! [They]1967-they descended [the hill]1978-the hill , crossed [the bridge]1979-the bridge , and drove to the door ; and , while examining the nearer aspect of [the house]3075-the house , all [her]88-elizabeth apprehension of meeting [[its]3075-the house owner]1934-its owner returned . [She]88-elizabeth dreaded lest [the chambermaid]1962-the chambermaid had been mistaken . On applying to see [the place]3068-the place , [they]1967-they were admitted into [the hall]3519-the hall ; and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , as [they]1967-they waited for [the housekeeper]3647-the housekeeper , had leisure to wonder at [her]3647-the housekeeper being where [she]3647-the housekeeper was . [The housekeeper]3647-the housekeeper came ; [a respectable looking elderly woman]1987-a respectable looking elderly woman , much less fine , and more civil , than [she]88-elizabeth had any notion of finding [her]3647-the housekeeper . [They]1967-they followed [her]3647-the housekeeper into [the dining - parlour]522-the dining - parlour . It was [a large , well - proportioned room , handsomely fitted up]1989-a large , well - proportioned room , handsomely fitted up . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , after slightly surveying [it]1989-a large , well - proportioned room , handsomely fitted up , went to a window to enjoy [its]1989-a large , well - proportioned room , handsomely fitted up prospect . [The hill]1978-the hill , crowned with wood , from which [they]1967-they had descended , receiving increased abruptness from the distance , was a beautiful object . Every disposition of [the ground]1991-the ground was good ; and [she]88-elizabeth looked on the whole scene , [the river]1992-the river , the trees scattered on [its]1992-the river banks , and [the winding of [the valley]1973-the valley]1993-the winding of the valley , as far as [she]88-elizabeth could trace it , with delight . As [they]1967-they passed into [other rooms]1995-other rooms , these objects were taking different positions ; but from every window there were beauties to be seen . [The rooms]1996-the rooms were lofty and handsome , and [their]1996-the rooms furniture suitable to the fortune of [[their]1996-the rooms proprietor]1997-their proprietor ; but [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth saw , with admiration of [his]1997-their proprietor taste , that it was neither gaudy nor uselessly fine,--with less of splendour , and more real elegance , than the furniture of Rosings . “ And of [this place]4466-this place , ”[88-elizabeth] thought [she]88-elizabeth , “ [I]88-elizabeth might have been [mistress]4467-mistress ! With [these rooms]4468-these rooms [I]88-elizabeth might have now been familiarly acquainted ! Instead of viewing [them]4468-these rooms as [a stranger]3471-a stranger , [I]88-elizabeth might have rejoiced in [them]4468-these rooms as [my]88-elizabeth own , and welcomed to [them]4468-these rooms as [visitors]3943-visitors [[my]88-elizabeth uncle]721-my uncle and [aunt]1241-aunt . But , no , ”[88-elizabeth] recollecting [herself]88-elizabeth , “ that could never be ; [[my]88-elizabeth uncle]721-my uncle and [aunt]1241-aunt would have been lost to [me]88-elizabeth ; [I]88-elizabeth should not have been allowed to invite [them]4475-them . ”[88-elizabeth] This was a lucky recollection -- it saved [her]88-elizabeth from something like regret . [She]88-elizabeth longed to inquire of [the housekeeper]3647-the housekeeper whether [[her]88-elizabeth master]1999-her master were really absent , but had not courage for it . At length , however , the question was asked by [[her]88-elizabeth uncle]579-her uncle ; and [she]88-elizabeth turned away with alarm , while [Mrs. Reynolds]192-mrs. reynolds replied , that [he]579-her uncle was ; adding , “ But [we]2001-we expect [him]579-her uncle to - morrow , with [a large party of [friends]1046-friends]4476-a large party of friends . ”[192-mrs. reynolds] How rejoiced was [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth that [their]2001-we own journey had not by any circumstance been delayed a day ! [[Her]88-elizabeth aunt]4017-her aunt now called [her]88-elizabeth to look at a picture . [She]88-elizabeth approached , and saw the likeness of [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham , suspended , amongst several other miniatures , over the mantel - piece . [[Her]88-elizabeth aunt]4017-her aunt asked [her]88-elizabeth , smilingly , how [she]88-elizabeth liked it . [The housekeeper]3647-the housekeeper came forward , and told [them]2001-we it was the picture of [a young gentleman]2005-a young gentleman , [the son of [[her]88-elizabeth late master ’s steward]2007-her late master ’s steward , who had been brought up by [him]142-wickham at [his]142-wickham own expense]2006-the son of her late master ’s steward , who had been brought up by him at his own expense . “ [He]2005-a young gentleman is now gone into [the army]4478-the army , ”[3647-the housekeeper] [she]3647-the housekeeper added ; “ but [I]3647-the housekeeper am afraid [he]2005-a young gentleman has turned out very wild . ”[3647-the housekeeper] [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner looked at [[her]129-mrs. gardiner niece]1279-her niece with a smile , but [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth could not return it . “ And that , ”[192-mrs. reynolds] said [Mrs. Reynolds]192-mrs. reynolds , pointing to another of the miniatures , “ is [[my]192-mrs. reynolds master]4479-my master -- and very like [him]2005-a young gentleman . It was drawn at the same time as the other -- about eight years ago . ”[192-mrs. reynolds] “ [I]129-mrs. gardiner have heard much of [[[your]88-elizabeth master]4480-your master ’s fine person]4481-your master ’s fine person , ”[129-mrs. gardiner] said [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner , looking at the picture ; “ it is a handsome face . But , [Lizzy]88-elizabeth , [you]88-elizabeth can tell [us]4482-us whether it is like or not . ”[129-mrs. gardiner] [Mrs. Reynolds]192-mrs. reynolds ’ respect for [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth seemed to increase on this intimation of [her]88-elizabeth knowing [[her]88-elizabeth master]1999-her master . “ Does [that young lady]4483-that young lady know [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ? ”[88-elizabeth] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth coloured , and said , “ A little . ”[88-elizabeth] “ And do not [you]88-elizabeth think [him]96-mr. darcy [a very handsome gentleman]4484-a very handsome gentleman , [ma’am]3191-ma’am ? ”[88-elizabeth] “ Yes , very handsome . ”[88-elizabeth] “ [I]88-elizabeth am sure [I]88-elizabeth know none so handsome ; but in [the gallery]4486-the gallery [upstairs]3537-upstairs [you]3191-ma’am will see a finer , larger picture of [him]96-mr. darcy than this . [This room]4488-this room was [[[my]88-elizabeth late master]4489-my late master ’s favourite room]4490-my late master ’s favourite room , and these miniatures are just as they used to be then . [He]4489-my late master was very fond of them . ”[88-elizabeth] This accounted to [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth for [Mr. Wickham]142-wickham ’s being among [them]2010-them . [Mrs. Reynolds]192-mrs. reynolds then directed [their]2011-their attention to one of [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy , drawn when [she]128-miss darcy was only eight years old . “ And is [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy as handsome as [[her]128-miss darcy brother]3181-her brother ? ”[157-mr. gardiner] said [Mr. Gardiner]157-mr. gardiner . “ Oh , yes -- [the handsomest young lady that ever was seen]4492-the handsomest young lady that ever was seen ; and so accomplished ! [She]128-miss darcy plays and sings all day long . In [the next room]4493-the next room is a new instrument just come down for [her]128-miss darcy -- a present from [[my]157-mr. gardiner master]4479-my master : [she]128-miss darcy comes here to - morrow with [him]4479-my master . ”[157-mr. gardiner] [Mr. Gardiner]157-mr. gardiner , whose manners were easy and pleasant , encouraged [her]88-elizabeth communicativeness by [his]157-mr. gardiner questions and remarks : [Mrs. Reynolds]192-mrs. reynolds , either from pride or attachment , had evidently great pleasure in talking of [[her]192-mrs. reynolds master]1999-her master and [[his]1999-her master sister]565-his sister . “ Is [[your]192-mrs. reynolds master]4480-your master much at [Pemberley]12-pemberley in the course of the year ? ”[192-mrs. reynolds] “ Not so much as [I]157-mr. gardiner could wish , [sir]3234-sir : but [I]157-mr. gardiner dare say [he]4479-my master may spend half [his]4479-my master time [here]3067-here ; and [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy is always down for the summer months . ”[157-mr. gardiner] “ Except , ”[88-elizabeth] thought [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , “ when [she]128-miss darcy goes to [Ramsgate]35-ramsgate . ”[88-elizabeth] “ If [[your]192-mrs. reynolds master]4480-your master would marry , [you]192-mrs. reynolds might see more of [him]4479-my master . ”[157-mr. gardiner] “ Yes , [sir]3234-sir ; but [I]2014-mr. do not know when that will be . [I]2014-mr. do not know who is good enough for [him]4479-my master . ”[2014-mr.] [Mr.]2014-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner smiled . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth could not help saying , “ It is very much to [his]4479-my master credit , [I]88-elizabeth am sure , that [you]3234-sir should think so . ”[88-elizabeth] “ [I]3427-the other say no more than the truth , and what [everybody]305-everybody will say that knows [him]4479-my master , ”[3427-the other] replied [the other]3427-the other . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth thought this was going pretty far ; and [she]88-elizabeth listened with increasing astonishment as [the housekeeper]3647-the housekeeper added , “ [I]3647-the housekeeper have never had a cross word from [him]4479-my master in [my]3647-the housekeeper life , and [I]3647-the housekeeper have known [him]4479-my master ever since [he]4479-my master was four years old . ”[3647-the housekeeper] This was praise of all others most extraordinary , most opposite to [her]88-elizabeth ideas . That [he]2017-he was not [a good - tempered man]2018-a good - tempered man had been [her]88-elizabeth firmest opinion . [Her]88-elizabeth keenest attention was awakened : [she]88-elizabeth longed to hear more ; and was grateful to [[her]88-elizabeth uncle]579-her uncle for saying,-- “ There are [very few people of whom so much can be said]4501-very few people of whom so much can be said . [You]88-elizabeth are lucky in having such [a master]4502-a master . ”[579-her uncle] “ Yes , [sir]3234-sir , [I]88-elizabeth know [I]88-elizabeth am . If [I]88-elizabeth were to go through [the world]304-the world , [I]88-elizabeth could not meet with a better . But [I]88-elizabeth have always observed , that [they]4505-they who are good - natured when [children]4506-children , are good - natured when [they]4506-children grow up ; and [he]4502-a master was always [the sweetest tempered , most generous - hearted boy in [the world]304-the world]4507-the sweetest tempered , most generous - hearted boy in the world . ”[88-elizabeth] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth almost stared at [her]579-her uncle . “ Can this be [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ? ”[88-elizabeth] thought [she]88-elizabeth . “ [[His]4502-a master father]339-his father was [an excellent man]4510-an excellent man , ”[129-mrs. gardiner] said [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner . “ Yes , [ma’am]3191-ma’am , that [he]339-his father was indeed ; and [[his]339-his father son]771-his son will be just like [him]339-his father -- just as affable to [the poor]795-the poor . ”[129-mrs. gardiner] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth listened , wondered , doubted , and was impatient for more . [Mrs. Reynolds]192-mrs. reynolds could interest [her]88-elizabeth on no other point . [She]88-elizabeth related the subjects of the pictures , the dimensions of [the rooms]1996-the rooms , and the price of the furniture in vain . [Mr. Gardiner]157-mr. gardiner , highly amused by the kind of family prejudice , to which [he]157-mr. gardiner attributed [her]88-elizabeth excessive commendation of [[her]88-elizabeth master]1999-her master , soon led again to the subject ; and [she]88-elizabeth dwelt with energy on [his]1999-her master many merits , as [they]2022-they proceeded together up the great staircase . “ [He]1999-her master is [the best landlord]4514-the best landlord , and [the best master]4515-the best master , ”[88-elizabeth] said [she]88-elizabeth , “ that ever lived . Not like [the wild young men now - a - days]4516-the wild young men now - a - days , who think of nothing but [themselves]4516-the wild young men now - a - days . There is not one of [[his]1999-her master tenants]794-his tenants or [servants]1352-servants but what will give [him]1999-her master a good name . [Some people]4199-some people call [him]1999-her master proud ; but [I]88-elizabeth am sure [I]88-elizabeth never saw anything of it . To [my]88-elizabeth fancy , it is only because [he]1999-her master does not rattle away like [other young men]4520-other young men . ”[88-elizabeth] “ In what an amiable light does this place [him]1999-her master ! ”[88-elizabeth] thought [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth . “ This fine account of [him]1999-her master , ”[4017-her aunt] whispered [[her]88-elizabeth aunt]4017-her aunt as [they]2024-they walked , “ is not quite consistent with [his]1999-her master behaviour to [[our]2024-they poor friend]4521-our poor friend . ”[4017-her aunt] “ Perhaps [we]2024-they might be deceived . ”[4017-her aunt] “ That is not very likely ; [our]2024-they authority was too good . ”[4017-her aunt] On reaching [the spacious lobby above]2025-the spacious lobby above , [they]2024-they were shown into [a very pretty sitting - room , lately fitted up with greater elegance and lightness than [the apartments below]2027-the apartments below]2026-a very pretty sitting - room , lately fitted up with greater elegance and lightness than the apartments below ; and were informed that it was but just done to give pleasure to [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy , who had taken a liking to [the room]255-the room , when last at [Pemberley]12-pemberley . “ [He]1999-her master is certainly [a good brother]4522-a good brother , ”[88-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , as [she]88-elizabeth walked towards one of the windows . [Mrs. Reynolds]192-mrs. reynolds anticipated [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy ’s delight , when [she]192-mrs. reynolds should enter [the room]255-the room . “ And this is always the way with [him]1999-her master , ”[192-mrs. reynolds] [she]192-mrs. reynolds added . “ Whatever can give [[his]1999-her master sister]565-his sister any pleasure , is sure to be done in a moment . There is nothing [he]1999-her master would not do for [her]128-miss darcy . ”[192-mrs. reynolds] [The picture gallery]2030-the picture gallery , and [two or three of [the principal bed - rooms]2032-the principal bed - rooms]2031-two or three of the principal bed - rooms , were all that remained to be shown . In the former were many good paintings : but [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth knew nothing of the art ; and from such as had been already visible below , [she]88-elizabeth had willingly turned to look at some drawings of [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy ’s , in crayons , whose subjects were usually more interesting , and also more intelligible . In [the gallery]4486-the gallery there were many family portraits , but they could have little to fix the attention of [a stranger]3471-a stranger . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth walked on in quest of the only face whose features would be known to [her]88-elizabeth . At last it arrested [her]88-elizabeth -- and [she]88-elizabeth beheld a striking resemblance of [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , with such a smile over the face , as [she]88-elizabeth remembered to have sometimes seen , when [he]96-mr. darcy looked at [her]88-elizabeth . [She]88-elizabeth stood several minutes before the picture , in earnest contemplation , and returned to [it]2035-it again before [they]2036-they quitted [the gallery]4486-the gallery . [Mrs. Reynolds]192-mrs. reynolds informed [them]2036-they , that it had been taken in [[his]96-mr. darcy father]339-his father ’s lifetime . There was certainly at this moment , in [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s mind , a more gentle sensation towards the original than [she]88-elizabeth had ever felt in the height of [their]2036-they acquaintance . The commendation bestowed on [him]96-mr. darcy by [Mrs. Reynolds]192-mrs. reynolds was of no trifling nature . What praise is more valuable than the praise of [an intelligent servant]2039-an intelligent servant ? As [a brother]439-a brother , [a landlord]2041-a landlord , [a master]4502-a master , [she]88-elizabeth considered how many [people]3299-people ’s happiness were in [his]96-mr. darcy guardianship ! How much of pleasure or pain it was in [his]96-mr. darcy power to bestow ! How much of good or evil must be done by [him]96-mr. darcy ! Every idea that had been brought forward by [the housekeeper]3647-the housekeeper was favourable to [his]96-mr. darcy character ; and as [she]88-elizabeth stood before the canvas , on which [he]96-mr. darcy was represented , and fixed [his]96-mr. darcy eyes upon [herself]88-elizabeth , [she]88-elizabeth thought of [his]96-mr. darcy regard with a deeper sentiment of gratitude than it had ever raised before : [she]88-elizabeth remembered its warmth , and softened its impropriety of expression . When all of [the house that was open to general inspection]2045-the house that was open to general inspection had been seen , [they]2046-they returned down [stairs]523-stairs ; and , taking leave of [the housekeeper]3647-the housekeeper , were consigned over to [the gardener]2049-the gardener , who met [them]2046-they at the hall door . As [they]2046-they walked across [the lawn]2050-the lawn towards [the river]1992-the river , [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth turned back to look again ; [[her]88-elizabeth uncle]579-her uncle and [aunt]1241-aunt stopped also ; and while [the former]327-the former was conjecturing as to the date of [the building]2055-the building , [the owner of [it]2055-the building [himself]2056-the owner of it himself]2056-the owner of it himself suddenly came forward from [the road]1292-the road which led behind [it]2055-the building to [the stables]2058-the stables . [They]2046-they were within twenty yards of [each other]3216-each other ; and so abrupt was [his]2056-the owner of it himself appearance , that it was impossible to avoid [his]2056-the owner of it himself sight . [Their]2046-they eyes instantly met , and the cheeks of each were overspread with the deepest blush . [He]2056-the owner of it himself absolutely started , and for a moment seemed immovable from surprise ; but shortly recovering [himself]2056-the owner of it himself , advanced towards the party , and spoke to [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , if not in terms of perfect composure , at least of perfect civility . [She]88-elizabeth had instinctively turned away ; but stopping on [his]2056-the owner of it himself approach , received [his]2056-the owner of it himself compliments with an embarrassment impossible to be overcome . Had [his]2056-the owner of it himself first appearance , or [his]2056-the owner of it himself resemblance to the picture [they]2046-they had just been examining , been insufficient to assure the other two that [they]2046-they now saw [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy , [the gardener]2049-the gardener ’s expression of surprise , on beholding [[his]2056-the owner of it himself master]2061-his master , must immediately have told it . [They]2046-they stood a little aloof while [he]2056-the owner of it himself was talking to [[their]2046-they niece]2062-their niece , who , astonished and confused , scarcely dared lift [her]2062-their niece eyes to [his]2056-the owner of it himself face , and knew not what answer [she]2062-their niece returned to [his]2056-the owner of it himself civil inquiries after [[her]2062-their niece family]3710-her family . Amazed at the alteration of [his]2056-the owner of it himself manner since [they]2046-they last parted , every sentence that [he]2056-the owner of it himself uttered was increasing [her]2062-their niece embarrassment ; and every idea of the impropriety of [her]2062-their niece being found there recurring to [her]2062-their niece mind , the few minutes in which [they]2046-they continued together were some of the most uncomfortable of [her]2062-their niece life . Nor did [he]2056-the owner of it himself seem much more at ease ; when [he]2056-the owner of it himself spoke , [his]2056-the owner of it himself accent had none of its usual sedateness ; and [he]2056-the owner of it himself repeated [his]2056-the owner of it himself inquiries as to the time of [her]2062-their niece having left [Longbourn]7-longbourn , and of [her]2062-their niece stay in [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire , so often , and in so hurried a way , as plainly spoke the distraction of [his]2056-the owner of it himself thoughts . At length , every idea seemed to fail [him]2056-the owner of it himself ; and after standing a few moments without saying a word , [he]2056-the owner of it himself suddenly recollected [himself]2056-the owner of it himself , and took leave . [The others]511-the others then joined [her]2062-their niece , and expressed [their]511-the others admiration of [his]2056-the owner of it himself figure ; but [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth heard not a word , and , wholly engrossed by [her]88-elizabeth own feelings , followed [them]511-the others in silence . [She]88-elizabeth was overpowered by shame and vexation . [Her]2062-their niece coming there was the most unfortunate , the most ill - judged thing in [the world]304-the world ! How strange must it appear to [him]2056-the owner of it himself ! In what a disgraceful light might it not strike so vain [a man]3114-a man ! It might seem as if [she]2062-their niece had purposely thrown [herself]2062-their niece in [his]2056-the owner of it himself way again ! Oh ! why did [she]2062-their niece come ? or , why did [he]2056-the owner of it himself thus come a day before [he]2056-the owner of it himself was expected ? Had [they]2067-they been only ten minutes sooner , [they]2067-they should have been beyond the reach of [his]2056-the owner of it himself discrimination ; for it was plain that [he]2056-the owner of it himself was that moment arrived , that moment alighted from [his]2056-the owner of it himself horse or [[his]2056-the owner of it himself carriage]2068-his carriage . [She]88-elizabeth blushed again and again over the perverseness of the meeting . And [his]2056-the owner of it himself behaviour , so strikingly altered,--what could it mean ? That [he]2056-the owner of it himself should even speak to [her]88-elizabeth was amazing -but to speak with such civility , to inquire after [[her]88-elizabeth family]3710-her family ! Never in [her]88-elizabeth life had [she]88-elizabeth seen [his]2056-the owner of it himself manners so little dignified , never had [he]2056-the owner of it himself spoken with such gentleness as on this unexpected meeting . What a contrast did it offer to [his]2056-the owner of it himself last address in [Rosings Park]18-rosings , when [he]2056-the owner of it himself put [his]2056-the owner of it himself letter into [her]88-elizabeth hand ! [She]88-elizabeth knew not what to think , or how to account for it . [They]2070-they had now entered a beautiful walk by the side of [the water]2071-the water , and every step was bringing forward a nobler fall of ground , or a finer reach of the woods to which [they]2070-they were approaching : but it was some time before [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was sensible of any of it ; and , though [she]88-elizabeth answered mechanically to the repeated appeals of [[her]88-elizabeth uncle]579-her uncle and [aunt]1241-aunt , and seemed to direct [her]88-elizabeth eyes to such objects as [they]2070-they pointed out , [she]88-elizabeth distinguished no part of the scene . [Her]88-elizabeth thoughts were all fixed on [that one spot of [Pemberley House]21-pemberley house]2074-that one spot of pemberley house , whichever [it]2075-it might be , where [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy then was . [She]88-elizabeth longed to know what at that moment was passing in [his]96-mr. darcy mind ; in what manner [he]96-mr. darcy thought of [her]88-elizabeth , and whether , in defiance of everything , [she]88-elizabeth was still dear to [him]96-mr. darcy . Perhaps [he]96-mr. darcy had been civil only because [he]96-mr. darcy felt [himself]96-mr. darcy at ease ; yet there had been that in [his]96-mr. darcy voice , which was not like ease . Whether [he]96-mr. darcy had felt more of pain or of pleasure in seeing [her]88-elizabeth , [she]88-elizabeth could not tell , but [he]96-mr. darcy certainly had not seen [her]88-elizabeth with composure . At length , however , the remarks of [[her]88-elizabeth companions]1159-her companions on [her]88-elizabeth absence of mind roused [her]88-elizabeth , and [she]88-elizabeth felt the necessity of appearing more like [herself]88-elizabeth . [They]2077-they entered [the woods]2078-the woods , and , bidding adieu to [the river]1992-the river for a while , ascended some of [the higher grounds]2080-the higher grounds ; whence , in spots where the opening of the trees gave the eye power to wander , were many charming views of [the valley]1973-the valley , [the opposite hills]2082-the opposite hills , with the long range of woods overspreading many , and occasionally part of [the stream]2083-the stream . [Mr. Gardiner]157-mr. gardiner expressed a wish of going round [the whole park]2084-the whole park , but feared it might be beyond a walk . With a triumphant smile , [they]2077-they were told , that it was ten miles round . It settled the matter ; and [they]2077-they pursued the accustomed circuit ; which brought [them]2077-they again , after some time , in a descent among [hanging woods]2085-hanging woods , to the edge of [the water]2071-the water , and one of [its]2071-the water narrowest parts . [They]2077-they crossed [it]2071-the water by [a simple bridge]2087-a simple bridge , in character with the general air of the scene : it was [a spot less adorned than any [they]2077-they had yet visited]2088-a spot less adorned than any they had yet visited ; and [the valley]1973-the valley , here contracted into [a glen]2090-a glen , allowed room only for [the stream]2083-the stream , and a narrow walk amidst the rough coppice - wood which bordered [it]2071-the water . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth longed to explore [its]2071-the water windings ; but when [they]2077-they had crossed [the bridge]1979-the bridge , and perceived [their]2077-they distance from [the house]3075-the house , [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner , who was not a great walker , could go no farther , and thought only of returning to [the carriage]3286-the carriage as quickly as possible . [[Her]129-mrs. gardiner niece]1279-her niece was , therefore , obliged to submit , and [they]2077-they took [their]2077-they way towards [the house on]2096-the house on [the opposite side of [the river]1992-the river]2097-the opposite side of the river , in the nearest direction ; but [their]2077-they progress was slow , for [Mr. Gardiner]157-mr. gardiner , though seldom able to indulge the taste , was very fond of fishing , and was so much engaged in watching the occasional appearance of some trout in [the water]2071-the water , and talking to [the man]3163-the man about [them]2101-them , that [he]157-mr. gardiner advanced but little . Whilst wandering on in this slow manner , [they]2077-they were again surprised , and [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s astonishment was quite equal to what it had been at first , by the sight of [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy approaching [them]2077-they , and at no great distance . The walk being [here]3067-here less sheltered than on the other side , allowed [them]2077-they to see [him]96-mr. darcy before [they]2077-they met . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , however astonished , was at least more prepared for an interview than before , and resolved to appear and to speak with calmness , if [he]96-mr. darcy really intended to meet [them]2077-they . For a few moments , indeed , [she]88-elizabeth felt that [he]96-mr. darcy would probably strike into some other path . The idea lasted while a turning in the walk concealed [him]96-mr. darcy from [their]2077-they view ; the turning past , [he]96-mr. darcy was immediately before [them]2077-they . With a glance [she]88-elizabeth saw that [he]96-mr. darcy had lost none of [his]96-mr. darcy recent civility ; and , to imitate [his]96-mr. darcy politeness , [she]88-elizabeth began as [they]2077-they met to admire the beauty of [the place]3068-the place ; but [she]88-elizabeth had not got beyond the words “ delightful , ”[88-elizabeth] and “ charming , ”[88-elizabeth] when some unlucky recollections obtruded , and [she]88-elizabeth fancied that praise of [Pemberley]12-pemberley from [her]88-elizabeth might be mischievously construed . [Her]88-elizabeth colour changed , and [she]88-elizabeth said no more . [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner was standing a little behind ; and on [her]129-mrs. gardiner pausing , [he]96-mr. darcy asked [her]88-elizabeth if [she]88-elizabeth would do [him]96-mr. darcy the honour of introducing [him]96-mr. darcy to [[her]88-elizabeth friends]311-her friends . This was a stroke of civility for which [she]88-elizabeth was quite unprepared ; and [she]88-elizabeth could hardly suppress a smile at [his]96-mr. darcy being now seeking the acquaintance of some of [those very people]2105-those very people , against whom [his]96-mr. darcy pride had revolted , in [his]96-mr. darcy offer to [herself]88-elizabeth . “ What will be [his]96-mr. darcy surprise , ”[88-elizabeth] thought [she]88-elizabeth , “ when [he]96-mr. darcy knows who [they]311-her friends are ! [He]96-mr. darcy takes them now for [people of fashion]4524-people of fashion . ”[88-elizabeth] The introduction , however , was immediately made ; and as [she]88-elizabeth named [their]2106-them relationship to [herself]88-elizabeth , [she]88-elizabeth stole a sly look at [him]96-mr. darcy , to see how [he]96-mr. darcy bore it ; and was not without the expectation of [his]96-mr. darcy decamping as fast as [he]96-mr. darcy could from [such disgraceful companions]2107-such disgraceful companions . That [he]96-mr. darcy was surprised by the connection was evident : [he]96-mr. darcy sustained it , however , with fortitude : and , so far from going away , turned back with [them]2106-them , and entered into conversation with [Mr. Gardiner]157-mr. gardiner . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth could not but be pleased , could not but triumph . It was consoling that [he]96-mr. darcy should know [she]88-elizabeth had [some relations for whom there was no need to blush]2108-some relations for whom there was no need to blush . [She]88-elizabeth listened most attentively to all that passed between [them]2106-them , and gloried in every expression , every sentence of [[her]88-elizabeth uncle]579-her uncle , which marked [his]96-mr. darcy intelligence , [his]96-mr. darcy taste , or [his]96-mr. darcy good manners . The conversation soon turned upon fishing ; and [she]88-elizabeth heard [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy invite [him]96-mr. darcy , with the greatest civility , to fish there as often as [he]96-mr. darcy chose , while [he]96-mr. darcy continued in [the neighbourhood]3088-the neighbourhood , offering at the same time to supply [him]96-mr. darcy with fishing tackle , and pointing out [those parts of [the stream]2083-the stream]2111-those parts of the stream where there was usually most sport . [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner , who was walking arm in arm with [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , gave [her]129-mrs. gardiner a look expressive of [her]129-mrs. gardiner wonder . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth said nothing , but it gratified [her]88-elizabeth exceedingly ; the compliment must be all for [herself]88-elizabeth . [Her]88-elizabeth astonishment , however , was extreme ; and continually was [she]88-elizabeth repeating , “ Why is [he]96-mr. darcy so altered ? From what can it proceed ? It can not be for [me]88-elizabeth , it can not be for [my]88-elizabeth sake that [his]96-mr. darcy manners are thus softened . [My]88-elizabeth reproofs at [Hunsford]15-hunsford could not work such a change as this . It is impossible that [he]96-mr. darcy should still love [me]88-elizabeth . ”[88-elizabeth] After walking some time in this way , [the two ladies in front]2113-the two ladies in front , [the two gentlemen]3593-the two gentlemen behind , on resuming [their]3593-the two gentlemen places , after descending to [the brink of [the river]1992-the river]2115-the brink of the river for the better inspection of [some curious water - plant]2117-some curious water - plant , there chanced to be a little alteration . It originated in [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner , who , fatigued by the exercise of the morning , found [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s arm inadequate to [her]129-mrs. gardiner support , and consequently preferred [[her]129-mrs. gardiner husband]260-her husband ’s . [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy took [her]129-mrs. gardiner place by [[her]129-mrs. gardiner niece]1279-her niece , and [they]2120-we walked on together . After a short silence [the lady]590-the lady first spoke . [She]590-the lady wished [him]260-her husband to know that [she]590-the lady had been assured of [his]260-her husband absence before [she]590-the lady came to [the place]3068-the place , and accordingly began by observing , that [his]260-her husband arrival had been very unexpected--“for [[your]260-her husband housekeeper]4525-your housekeeper , ”[590-the lady] [she]590-the lady added , “ informed [us]2120-we that [you]260-her husband would certainly not be here till to - morrow ; and , indeed , before [we]2120-we left [Bakewell]51-bakewell , [we]2120-we understood that [you]260-her husband were not immediately expected in [the country]448-the country . ”[590-the lady] [He]260-her husband acknowledged the truth of it all ; and said that business with [[his]260-her husband steward]2123-his steward had occasioned [his]260-her husband coming forward a few hours before the rest of [the party with whom [he]260-her husband had been travelling]2124-the party with whom he had been travelling . “ [They]4527-they will join [me]260-her husband early to - morrow , ”[260-her husband] [he]260-her husband continued , “ and among [them]4527-they are [some who will claim an acquaintance with [you,--Mr . Bingley]85-mr. bingley and [[his]85-mr. bingley sisters]284-his sisters]4528-some who will claim an acquaintance with you,--mr . bingley and his sisters . ”[260-her husband] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth answered only by a slight bow . [Her]88-elizabeth thoughts were instantly driven back to the time when [Mr. Bingley]85-mr. bingley ’s name had been last mentioned between [them]2125-them ; and if [she]88-elizabeth might judge from [his]260-her husband complexion , [his]260-her husband mind was not very differently engaged . “ There is also [one other person in the party]4530-one other person in the party , ”[260-her husband] [he]260-her husband continued after a pause , “ who more particularly wishes to be known to [you]88-elizabeth . Will [you]88-elizabeth allow [me]260-her husband , or do [I]260-her husband ask too much , to introduce [[my]260-her husband sister]3345-my sister to [your]88-elizabeth acquaintance during [your]88-elizabeth stay at [Lambton]49-lambton ? ”[260-her husband] The surprise of such an application was great indeed ; it was too great for [her]88-elizabeth to know in what manner [she]88-elizabeth acceded to it . [She]88-elizabeth immediately felt that whatever desire [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy might have of being acquainted with [her]88-elizabeth , must be the work of [[her]88-elizabeth brother]3181-her brother , and without looking farther , it was satisfactory ; it was gratifying to know that [his]260-her husband resentment had not made [him]260-her husband think really ill of [her]88-elizabeth . [They]2127-they now walked on in silence ; each of [them]2127-they deep in thought . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was not comfortable ; that was impossible ; but [she]88-elizabeth was flattered and pleased . [His]260-her husband wish of introducing [[his]260-her husband sister]565-his sister to [her]88-elizabeth was a compliment of the highest kind . [They]2127-they soon outstripped [the others]511-the others ; and when [they]2127-they had reached [the carriage]3286-the carriage , [Mr.]2131-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner were half a quarter of a mile behind . [He]260-her husband then asked [her]88-elizabeth to walk into [the house]3075-the house -- but [she]88-elizabeth declared [herself]88-elizabeth not tired , and [they]2127-they stood together on [the lawn]2050-the lawn . At such a time much might have been said , and silence was very awkward . [She]88-elizabeth wanted to talk , but there seemed an embargo on every subject . At last [she]88-elizabeth recollected that [she]88-elizabeth had been travelling , and [they]2127-they talked of [Matlock]40-matlock and [Dovedale]42-dovedale with great perseverance . Yet time and [[her]88-elizabeth aunt]4017-her aunt moved slowly -- and [her]88-elizabeth patience and [her]88-elizabeth ideas were nearly worn out before the tête - à - tête was over . On [Mr.]2135-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner ’s coming up [they]2127-they were all pressed to go into [the house]3075-the house and take some refreshment ; but this was declined , and [they]2127-they parted on each side with the utmost politeness . [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy handed [the ladies]254-the ladies into [the carriage]3286-the carriage ; and when [it]3286-the carriage drove off , [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth saw [him]96-mr. darcy walking slowly towards [the house]3075-the house . The observations of [[her]88-elizabeth uncle]579-her uncle and [aunt]1241-aunt now began ; and each of [them]2127-they pronounced [him]96-mr. darcy to be infinitely superior to anything [they]2127-they had expected . “ [He]96-mr. darcy is perfectly well - behaved , polite , and unassuming , ”[579-her uncle] said [[her]88-elizabeth uncle]579-her uncle . “ There is something a little stately in [him]96-mr. darcy , to be sure , ”[579-her uncle] replied [[her]88-elizabeth aunt]4017-her aunt ; “ but it is confined to [his]96-mr. darcy air , and is not unbecoming . [I]579-her uncle can now say with [the housekeeper]3647-the housekeeper , that though [some people]4199-some people may call [him]96-mr. darcy proud , [I]579-her uncle have seen nothing of it . ”[579-her uncle] “ [I]4017-her aunt was never more surprised than by [his]96-mr. darcy behaviour to [us]2127-they . It was more than civil ; it was really attentive ; and there was no necessity for such attention . [His]96-mr. darcy acquaintance with [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth was very trifling . ”[4017-her aunt] “ To be sure , [Lizzy]88-elizabeth , ”[4017-her aunt] said [[her]88-elizabeth aunt]4017-her aunt , “ [he]96-mr. darcy is not so handsome as [Wickham]142-wickham ; or rather [he]96-mr. darcy has not [Wickham]142-wickham ’s countenance , for [his]96-mr. darcy features are perfectly good . But how came [you]88-elizabeth to tell [us]2146-us that [he]96-mr. darcy was so disagreeable ? ”[4017-her aunt] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth excused [herself]88-elizabeth as well as [she]88-elizabeth could : said that [she]88-elizabeth had liked [him]2145-him better when [they]2146-us met in [Kent]17-kent than before , and that [she]88-elizabeth had never seen [him]2145-him so pleasant as this morning . “ But perhaps [he]96-mr. darcy may be a little whimsical in [his]96-mr. darcy civilities , ”[579-her uncle] replied [[her]88-elizabeth uncle]579-her uncle . “ [[Your]88-elizabeth great men]4534-your great men often are ; and therefore [I]579-her uncle shall not take [him]96-mr. darcy at [his]96-mr. darcy word about fishing , as [he]96-mr. darcy might change [his]96-mr. darcy mind another day , and warn [me]579-her uncle off [his]96-mr. darcy grounds . ”[579-her uncle] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth felt that [they]2146-us had entirely mistaken [his]2145-him character , but said nothing . “ From what [we]2146-us have seen of [him]96-mr. darcy , ”[129-mrs. gardiner] continued [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner , “ [I]129-mrs. gardiner really should not have thought that [he]96-mr. darcy could have behaved in so cruel a way by [anybody]3171-anybody as [he]96-mr. darcy has done by [poor Wickham]142-wickham . [He]96-mr. darcy has not an ill - natured look . On the contrary , there is something pleasing about [his]96-mr. darcy mouth when [he]96-mr. darcy speaks . And there is something of dignity in [his]96-mr. darcy countenance , that would not give [one]3113-one an unfavourable idea of [his]96-mr. darcy heart . But , to be sure , [the good lady]4537-the good lady who showed [us]2146-us [the house]3075-the house did give [him]96-mr. darcy a most flaming character ! [I]129-mrs. gardiner could hardly help laughing aloud sometimes . But [he]96-mr. darcy is [a liberal master]4539-a liberal master , [I]129-mrs. gardiner suppose , and that , in the eye of [a servant]503-a servant , comprehends every virtue . ”[129-mrs. gardiner] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth here felt [herself]88-elizabeth called on to say something in vindication of [his]2148-his behaviour to [Wickham]142-wickham ; and , therefore , gave [them]2149-they to understand , in as guarded a manner as [she]88-elizabeth could , that by what [she]88-elizabeth had heard from [his]2148-his relations in [Kent]17-kent , [his]2148-his actions were capable of a very different construction ; and that [his]2148-his character was by no means so faulty , nor [Wickham]142-wickham ’s so amiable , as they had been considered in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire . In confirmation of this , [she]88-elizabeth related the particulars of all the pecuniary transactions in which [they]2149-they had been connected , without actually naming [her]88-elizabeth authority , but stating it to be such as might be relied on . [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner was surprised and concerned : but as [they]2149-they were now approaching the scene of [her]129-mrs. gardiner former pleasures , every idea gave way to the charm of recollection ; and [she]129-mrs. gardiner was too much engaged in pointing out to [[her]129-mrs. gardiner husband]260-her husband all the interesting spots in [[its]2151-its environs]2152-its environs , to think of anything else . Fatigued as [she]88-elizabeth had been by the morning ’s walk , [they]2149-they had no sooner dined than [she]88-elizabeth set off again in quest of [[her]88-elizabeth former acquaintance]2153-her former acquaintance , and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of an intercourse renewed after many years ’ discontinuance . The occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth much attention for [any of [these new friends]2155-these new friends]2154-any of these new friends ; and [she]88-elizabeth could do nothing but think , and think with wonder , of [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy ’s civility , and , above all , of [his]96-mr. darcy wishing [her]88-elizabeth to be acquainted with [[his]96-mr. darcy sister]565-his sister . [ Illustration ] CHAPTER XLIV . [ Illustration ] [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth had settled it that [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy would bring [[his]96-mr. darcy sister]565-his sister to visit [her]88-elizabeth the very day after [her]88-elizabeth reaching [Pemberley]12-pemberley ; and was , consequently , resolved not to be out of sight of [the inn]1810-the inn the whole of that morning . But [her]88-elizabeth conclusion was false ; for on the very morning after [their]2155-these new friends own arrival at [Lambton]49-lambton [these visitors]2159-these visitors came . [They]2155-these new friends had been walking about [the place]3068-the place with [some of [[their]2155-these new friends new friends]2162-their new friends]2161-some of their new friends , and were just returned to [the inn]1810-the inn to dress [themselves]2155-these new friends for dining with [the same family]2164-the same family , when the sound of [a carriage]3195-a carriage drew [them]2155-these new friends to a window , and [they]2155-these new friends saw [a gentleman]3470-a gentleman and [lady]427-lady in a curricle driving up [the street]3582-the street . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , immediately recognizing the livery , guessed what it meant , and imparted no small degree of surprise to [[her]88-elizabeth relations]583-her relations , by acquainting [them]583-her relations with the honour which [she]88-elizabeth expected . [[Her]88-elizabeth uncle]579-her uncle and [aunt]1241-aunt were all amazement ; and the embarrassment of [her]88-elizabeth manner as [she]88-elizabeth spoke , joined to the circumstance itself , and many of the circumstances of the preceding day , opened to [them]2155-these new friends a new idea on the business . Nothing had ever suggested it before , but [they]2155-these new friends now felt that there was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such a quarter than by supposing a partiality for [[their]2155-these new friends niece]2062-their niece . While these newly - born notions were passing in [their]2155-these new friends heads , the perturbation of [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s feelings was every moment increasing . [She]88-elizabeth was quite amazed at [her]88-elizabeth own discomposure ; but , amongst other causes of disquiet , [she]88-elizabeth dreaded lest the partiality of [the brother]1247-the brother should have said too much in [her]88-elizabeth favour ; and , more than commonly anxious to please , [she]88-elizabeth naturally suspected that every power of pleasing would fail [her]88-elizabeth . [She]88-elizabeth retreated from the window , fearful of being seen ; and as [she]88-elizabeth walked up and down [the room]255-the room , endeavouring to compose [herself]88-elizabeth , saw such looks of inquiring surprise in [[her]88-elizabeth uncle]579-her uncle and [aunt]1241-aunt as made everything worse . [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy and [[her]128-miss darcy brother]3181-her brother appeared , and this formidable introduction took place . With astonishment did [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth see that [[her]88-elizabeth new acquaintance]2178-her new acquaintance was at least as much embarrassed as [herself]88-elizabeth . Since [her]88-elizabeth being at [Lambton]49-lambton , [she]88-elizabeth had heard that [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy was exceedingly proud ; but the observation of a very few minutes convinced [her]88-elizabeth that [she]128-miss darcy was only exceedingly shy . [She]88-elizabeth found it difficult to obtain even a word from [her]128-miss darcy beyond a monosyllable . [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy was tall , and on a larger scale than [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ; and , though little more than sixteen , [her]128-miss darcy figure was formed , and [her]128-miss darcy appearance womanly and graceful . [She]128-miss darcy was less handsome than [[her]128-miss darcy brother]3181-her brother , but there was sense and good - humour in [her]128-miss darcy face , and [her]128-miss darcy manners were perfectly unassuming and gentle . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , who had expected to find in [her]128-miss darcy as acute and unembarrassed an observer as ever [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy had been , was much relieved by discerning such different feelings . [They]2180-they had not been long together before [Darcy]96-mr. darcy told [her]88-elizabeth that [Bingley]85-mr. bingley was also coming to wait on [her]88-elizabeth ; and [she]88-elizabeth had barely time to express [her]88-elizabeth satisfaction , and prepare for [such a visitor]2181-such a visitor , when [Bingley]85-mr. bingley ’s quick step was heard on the stairs , and in a moment [he]85-mr. bingley entered [the room]255-the room . All [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth ’s anger against [him]85-mr. bingley had been long done away ; but had [she]88-elizabeth still felt any , it could hardly have stood its ground against the unaffected cordiality with which [he]85-mr. bingley expressed [himself]85-mr. bingley on seeing [her]88-elizabeth again . [He]85-mr. bingley inquired in a friendly , though general , way , after [[her]88-elizabeth family]3710-her family , and looked and spoke with the same good - humoured ease that [he]85-mr. bingley had ever done . To [Mr.]2184-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]129-mrs. gardiner [he]85-mr. bingley was scarcely [a less interesting personage]2185-a less interesting personage than to [herself]88-elizabeth . [They]2186-they had long wished to see [him]85-mr. bingley . [The whole party before [them]2186-they]2187-the whole party before them , indeed , excited a lively attention . The suspicions which had just arisen of [Mr. Darcy]96-mr. darcy and [[their]2186-they niece]2062-their niece , directed [their]2186-they observation towards [each]3692-each with an earnest , though guarded , inquiry ; and [they]2186-they soon drew from those inquiries the full conviction that one of [them]2186-they at least knew what it was to love . Of [the lady]590-the lady ’s sensations [they]2186-they remained a little in doubt ; but that [the gentleman]287-the gentleman was overflowing with admiration was evident enough . [Elizabeth]88-elizabeth , on [her]88-elizabeth side , had much to do . [She]88-elizabeth wanted to ascertain the feelings of [each of [[her]88-elizabeth visitors]1369-her visitors]2192-each of her visitors , [she]88-elizabeth wanted to compose [her]88-elizabeth own , and to make [herself]88-elizabeth agreeable to all ; and in the latter object , where [she]88-elizabeth feared most to fail , [she]88-elizabeth was most sure of success , for [those to whom [she]88-elizabeth endeavoured to give pleasure]2194-those to whom she endeavoured to give pleasure were pre - possessed in [her]88-elizabeth favour . [Bingley]85-mr. bingley was ready , [Georgiana]153-georgiana was eager , and [Darcy]153-georgiana determined , to be pleased . [ Illustration : “ To make [herself]88-elizabeth agreeable to all ”[153-georgiana] In seeing [Bingley]85-mr. bingley , [her]88-elizabeth thoughts naturally flew to [[her]88-elizabeth sister]328-her sister ; and oh ! how ardently did [she]88-elizabeth long to know whether any of [his]85-mr. bingley were directed in a like manner . Sometimes [she]88-elizabeth could fancy that [he]85-mr. bingley talked less than on former occasions , and once or twice pleased [herself]88-elizabeth with the notion that , as [he]85-mr. bingley looked at [her]88-elizabeth , [he]85-mr. bingley was trying to trace a resemblance . But , though this might be imaginary , [she]88-elizabeth could not be deceived as to [his]85-mr. bingley behaviour to [Miss Darcy]128-miss darcy , who had been set up as [a rival to [Jane]89-jane]2196-a rival to jane . No look appeared on either side that spoke particular regard . Nothing occurred between [them]2197-we that could justify the hopes of [[his]85-mr. bingley sister]565-his sister . On this point [she]88-elizabeth was soon satisfied ; and two or three little circumstances occurred ere [they]2197-we parted , which , in [her]88-elizabeth anxious interpretation , denoted a recollection of [Jane]89-jane , not untinctured by tenderness , and a wish of saying more that might lead to the mention of [her]89-jane , had [he]85-mr. bingley dared .
